answer: The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The features of the setting that affect the cyclist is the lact of information on were to go and the lack of water. This was a problem because he needed water for his trip and directions on were to go. Consequently, the cyclist was hampered by the environment, creating difficulties for navigation and hydration, ultimately impacting the journey's progress.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in a negative way. He was in the desert, which is dry and hot. ìI was traveling through the high deserts of California in June."(Kurmaskie @NUM1). Also, the temperature was hot and made every thing around him hot, ìbrackish water faling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees" (Kurmaskie @NUM1). Since he was in the desert, there was no escape from the sun. The text states, ìThe sun was beginning to beat downî(Kurmaskie @NUM3). The cyclist was all alone in the road with none around him either so into he passed out, no one could help him. ì and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgous day in Juneî(Kurmaskie @NUM1). "About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ëtowní but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town." (Kurmaskie @NUM3). The lack of people meant no readily available assistance or resources. These harsh, isolated conditions contributed to the cyclist's growing sense of vulnerability. The settings that the cyclist was riding in wasn't good ones and so they negativly affected him; causing him to be dehydrated and tiredin the end.

Everyone travels to unfamiliar places. Sometimes we get lost and ask locals for directions which may not be a good idea. The setting affected the cyclist. He had a perfectly good map but asked older men who look like they havenít been out in ages. The old men apparently havenít been out because they gave the cyclist the wrong directions. My advice would be to not listen to anyone no matter their age if you have a perfectly good map with you. Also try to know where you are going at all times. ìYes, sir!î Therefore, relying on your own resources and preparation is often the best strategy for navigating unfamiliar territories.

I believe the features of the cyclist affected him because he was impatient and trustworthy. He took the old man's advice to take an hour off his time by taking a shortcut. If he would have stayed true to the map, he wouldn't have almost died of heat, but his impatience got the best of him, so he took the shortcut. After his experience, he knew he has to stick to the map and not trust people who haven't seen changes in the last few years. He learned a hard lesson about trusting his own judgment and the reliability of established routes over the fleeting promises of strangers, ultimately realizing the value of patience and self-reliance.

The setting effects the cyclist because if the setting were different, the story would not have made sense. The setting of the story is hot and dry with scattered ghost towns. When he reaches the first “town” he sees “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a coral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule.” If the setting did not have the problem of no water, so there would be no conflict in the story. In the story the speaker says, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California,” that are very hot and dry, and he says, “This causes the problem of it being hot and dry if the setting was a forest in @DATE1 he wouldn’t have as much of a problem needing water,” which would have made the story much less exciting, demonstrating how crucial the desert environment is to the cyclist's predicament and the overall narrative's tension.

There were many features of the setting that affected the cyclist. For instance, it was extremely hot and dry. Also it was nearly deserted, almost all of the places he crossed were deserted. Another feature of the setting was a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule. This desolation likely amplifies the cyclist's feelings of isolation and the oppressive heat adds to a sense of struggle, making the journey seem even more arduous.

The cyclist was riding through a tower-like rock formation when he stopped for directions. These old men, sitting in the shade, told him to take a short cut and he did, promptly getting lost. He found himself in a ghost town in the desert, tumbleweeds rolling past abandoned buildings. In conclusion the desert is hot.

The effects of the cyclist situation, if it doesn't change, could hurt a lot of people's feelings because they seemingly don't care about the cyclist. I'm one of those people who doesn't care about it because it doesn't affect me or anyone I know personally. It is a big deal to white people, some of whom blow things up over it. They're talking on TV and on the radio, making all this stuff up, they say. I don't believe it until I see it for myself. That's not for black people because it hasn't done anything for us. We really don't care about the effects of the cyclist issue because it has no impact on our lives or community.

The essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî describes a manís bicycle ride through California. Now, California is very hot during the summer, which is when the cyclist is riding. This setting greatly affects the manís journey. It made it very difficult for him to finish his ride. He drank most of his water in the beginning of his ride so he gets very dehydrated. The text states, ìThe water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.î He also mentions the sun beating down on him relentlessly. As you can see the setting makes this manís bikeride very hard. The oppressive heat, combined with his dwindling water supply, transformed a challenging ride into a true test of endurance, emphasizing how environmental factors can significantly impact even the most determined endeavors.

In the story, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî written by Joe Kurmaskie, represents how certain conditions can affect a cyclist. The cyclist was biking through the desert to reach Yosemite National Park, but on his journey he encountered many tough conditions to make it difficult to get there. First of all, the desert was very hot which makes travel very difficult. For example the text states, ìthe sun was beginning to beat down.î The intense heat makes any task difficult because the sun drains a personís energy. Secondly, the trip was very long so the cyclist had a hard time conserving water. For instance, the man drank so much water, he almost ran out; ìThe water bottle contained only a mouthful.î Running out of water in the desert can lead to dehydration which can cause death. Joe Kurmaskieís story, ìRough Road Ahead. Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î represents how certain conditions of an environment can affect a cyclist.

The setting of the author’s “shortcut” affected his performance and strength tremendously. Whether it was the hills, heat, or barren landscape, all three took their toll on Joe Kurmaskie. Not only that, but his lack of water depleted his energy as well. “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” The hills were a tough thing to pass since Joe was being drained of energy. He overcame this exhaustion when a building came into view. “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited with what I believed was my last burst of energy. I maneuvered down the hill.” The author overcame all the problems he faced even though it was difficult. He seems to have written this piece to exaggerate how important it is to keep going when you want to give up, demonstrating resilience in the face of adversity. Winston Churchill once said, “success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage it takes to continue that counts.” I believe that @PERSON2 agrees, highlighting the universal value of perseverance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist very much so! The cyclist is riding through the hot desert. Meaning he needs lots of cold water to keep him hydrated. The longer he rides in the hot sun, the more he sweats, the more likely he will get dehydrated. Electrolyte imbalance is also a concern. If he was riding in the rain or snow it could possibly slow him down also, because he would be cold and his muscles might get stiff and not be able to move as fast. Therefore, the environmental conditions significantly impact performance and well-being. This is why the setting affects the cyclist very much so.

There was many features that affected the cyclist such as heat and lack of water. The cyclist was drinking a lot of water throughout the story and ends up only having little water left. ìI eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.î That shows he wasnít prepared with enough water for his trip to Yosemite. Without water he/she would die from the heat. ìWide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke" This states that he understood the danger of not having enough water in his system, and the possibility of severe consequences. Features such as water and heat affected him/her throughout the story. Not having enough water could make him/her lose more sweat and the heat is making him lose even more sweat which can cause extreme heatstroke, highlighting the critical role water plays in maintaining bodily functions under strenuous conditions.

The features in the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. Initially, when the cyclist went through the road with the big snake in the middle of it made him keep cautious and very unease. Furthermore, the desert and nothing around gave the cyclist a feeling of abandoness and no help for when he is in trouble. Finally, the cyclist is greatly relieved when he sees the bait store and that people are there. The features in the setting greatly affected the cyclist on his ride.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, greatly affect the cyclist and put him through many hardships that he probably could have avoided. The old cottagers told him about a path they thought was right, but was hard and did not get him to the right place. The features of the setting are described as "flat road was replaced by short rolling hills," soon becoming steeper and rockier, significantly increasing the difficulty of his journey and leading to unforeseen challenges. These unanticipated conditions, stemming directly from the setting, clearly contribute to the cyclist's struggles.

In the essay Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit the author Joe Kurmaskie uses the features of the setting to affect the cyclist. The cyclist is affected by these features because he sees the same setting (the desert) for several miles, he has no water and, the road has a lot of hills. The cyclist could been affected by seeing the desert and no scenery changes for a while. When you look at one same scene for hours you could start to get tired and bored with everything, and the lack of visual stimulation can impact one's mental state. So this cause him to be very drowsy and bored. Also the cyclist had no water as none of the fountains were cold water. Having no water out in the desert could make you dehydrate and faint, and dehydration can significantly impair physical and cognitive functions. Ultimately, these environmental factors combine to create a challenging and potentially dangerous situation for the cyclist.

Many different characteristics in a setting determine the outcome of an event there. In the story, "Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the cyclist's journey was affected by a few weather-related things. The heat was an extreme element that slowed him down and in most cases deterred him from reaching his maximum level of ability because it caused fatigue. Also, the time of year in which this takes place greatly affects the cyclist, determining daylight hours and temperature consistency. Lastly, the type of road and amount of ground that he has to cover also affects his performance, influencing his speed and stamina. Overall, setting can be a determining factor in a journey as these elements significantly influence the cyclist's experience.

The setting of the story affects the cyclist in many ways. Since he is riding in the California desert, he always feels very hot and is always in constant thirst. In addition to this the area he is riding in appears to be quite desolate. He finds nothing but old abandoned buildings. He doesn't find anyone. No people or cars, or any sign of modern civilization. This causes him to feel a little unnerved as if something happened to him nobody would know about it, a feeling amplified by the sheer emptiness surrounding him. This is especially prevalent when he becomes dehydrated; his vulnerability is heightened by the unforgiving landscape. In those ways, the cyclist is very much affected by the setting, which actively contributes to his physical struggles and psychological state throughout his ride.

In the story ìRough Road Aheadî by @PERSON1, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way the setting affects the cyclist is, in the desert, the cyclist drank more water than before. For example, the text states ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. You will drink more water in a desert than in a forest. The arid environment necessitates increased hydration to combat the intense heat and prevent dehydration. If you go cycling, be aware of the settings around you because they will affect you. Therefore, one must adapt their fluid intake to match the demands of the surrounding environment.

Some features of the setting affected the cyclist. First the cyclist followed the old codgers' advice of how to get to Yosemite National Park. Their advice was no use and didn't help her in the end. Next, "a tarlike substance oozed out" of what she thought was going to be water, leaving her disappointed and without refreshment. Then the terrain changed to "short, rolling hills," which wasn't helping her bike, making the ride more strenuous. Lastly, "tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake" slowed her down considerably. All of these road blocks in the setting affected the cyclist, hindering her journey and making it more difficult to reach her destination.

The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the lack of water, out of date information, and rolling hills. The rolling hills would make the ride more physically taxing, increasing his need for water. If he had up to date information then he would probably have got water from a town thatís not empty or almost empty like a ìghost townî as the cyclist said. This lack of reliable information combined with the demanding terrain creates a challenging situation for the cyclist.

The cyclist has a couple of things to consider if he is racing, and if the wind is blowing, then there's a problem with balance and aerodynamics; he also has to follow traffic law and ride on the right side of the road, ensuring his safety and the safety of others. Therefore, cyclists must always be mindful of external factors and regulations.

ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî had a rough setting between hazardous things and the death defying heat. The cyclist had to endure the pain of dehydration and determination. He had been given bad directions that almost caused him his life. He was travelling through a desert and claimed the temperature was 110. Also, the cyclist had to ration his water because it was ghost towns in which our character passed through. He used nature skills he'd once learned and began to suck on pebbles which take the mind off thirst and uses saliva to help refresh your throat. Throughout his adventure everything kept this young man from getting water and to whenever there was water any faster. He had survived and wouldnít ever take shortcuts again, realizing that sometimes the longer route is the safer route, and that lesson was learned through hardship and thirst.

An example of the setting affecting the cyclist is when he has the lock of water in a ghost town in just eliterat. He finds the water, but a tar-like substance comes out and it tasted like battery. When he left, he had to go through rough roads, which meant he couldn't travel that fast because of the road's condition, slowing his progress considerably.

The cyclist had a very hard time getting to Yosemite National Park. This is because the sun was out, and it was in the middle of June. It was so hot out the cyclist became dehydrated faster than he would have on a cooler day, quickly depleting his water reserves. When he pumped the handle of the old rusted water pump, he said the water felt, "somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." The cyclist also had to deal with a lot of "short rolling hills," which was much more difficult to bike on than flat roads, constantly forcing him to shift gears. On top of everything else the roads were in very bad condition, so you had to watch for rocks in the road, making the journey slow and precarious. Ultimately, the combination of heat, hills, and hazardous roads made the cyclist's journey to Yosemite an arduous ordeal.

The cyclist in the story is at first confident in accepting the old menís help, and doesnít seem to suspect anything is wrong when he first starts out. The way the men directed him seem all going for his water supply is all in store, and the first land mark, a ghost town now, is exactly where it is supposed to be, confirming the old men's directions. The next ìtownî he hits doesnít have anything that could replenish his diminishing water supply and he starts to feel troubled, a gnawing anxiety creeping in with each dry swallow. However he was told the next town wasnít further, so he pressed on, fueled by dwindling hope. Then the scenery makes a drastic change, the flat roads becoming hills, the sun beating hotter- it really look like a desert after tumbleweeds even go past! The cyclist continues on, despite being very dehydrated, his lips cracked and his vision blurring. The next thing to come along is an old juice building that almost seems to mark him on how he has no water, a cruel reminder of his parched state. He keeps on, however, driven by sheer will, and at last sees a shop where he can get water. The canging scenery sends the cyclist from confidence to worry, to hopelessness and lastly, relief, marking a journey defined by deception and the desperate need for hydration.

Well I would put it like this is that the weather had everything to do with it because the poor weather can make you tired and upset, making you easily angered; so now it makes you upset and then stressed. Therefore, the weather significantly contributed to the negative emotional state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in two ways: physical and mental. Physically, the terrain impacts the cyclist. Long and winding roads can cause exhaustion. A steep incline against gravity is also exhausting. Temperature is crucial to a cyclist's physical ability; riding in extreme heat can be unbearable. The cyclist can also be affected mentally. A deserted or desert-like terrain can trigger thoughts of dehydration and even death. Sighting dead animals or bones might induce fear of mortality. Circling vultures could inspire fear, especially if these elements combine in the same location simultaneously. Therefore, the setting's physical and mental challenges can greatly affect the cyclist's performance and well-being.

The settings of the story were grveling. While the cyclist was riding along, the sun was beginning to beat down on him. The cyclist began to sweat due to the heat and thus he drank just about all of his water. Now the cyclist was experiencing major heat, sweat, and dehydration. The California desert is a grveling place to be, especially in June. Luckily, the cyclist did come up to a camp and found fresh food and water, before he would eventually continue his way to Yosemite National Park. He refilled his water bottles and ate some fruit, feeling much better prepared for the rest of his journey. The cyclist appreciated the unexpected kindness as he began pedaling once more toward Yosemite.

As the cyclist is traveling to Yosemite National Park, he comes across many features in the area that affects him. First, he takes directions from some old guys who don’t know anything about the changes in maps because they never leave their porch. At first, it affects him in a positive way, because he thought he had a good shortcut to Yosemite. However, the affect later came negative because it turned out to be a shortcut that never existed, adding unnecessary miles to his journey. Another feature that affected him was the setting which was a desert-like area. The heat made it harder for him to ride his bike, and he also drank a lot of his water. This later resulted in him becoming dehydrated and significantly slowed down. A positive affect was when he found the bait shop, where he rehydrated himself and got some new directions, ultimately putting him back on the right path towards Yosemite.

The features of this setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The setting is a desert so by common knowledge you know that it is going to be hot and dry. Because it is hot the cyclist needs more water because he is getting dehydrated, and when he is low on water, because it is dry, his mouth gets dry. Also, because he is in the desert, he sees wild, sometimes dangerous, animals; in the story he sees a ridiculously large diamondback snake, which I believe are venomous. Because of the extreme heat of the desert, he realizes that he had an increased chance of dropping from heatstroke. The writer said that the desert had short, rolling hills and rough road ahead, which would leave the cyclist worn out, and because of this terrain, the cyclist's speed is affected.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. One example is the hot sun that was beating down on him made him very thirsty. Another feature is the rough road that wore the cyclist out and made him tired. My last example is the old juice factory with the picture of a refreshing cup of juice on it made the cyclist feel like giving up because he thought he would die of dehydration. These are my reasons as to why the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. The relentless heat intensified his craving for water, the uneven terrain sapped his physical strength, and the tantalizing image of juice served as a cruel reminder of his parched condition, pushing him to the brink of despair.

In the essay the author writes of rough roads the cyclists had to overcome to reach their ultimate goal. These challenges, both physical and mental, tested their endurance and resilience, pushing them to their limits. The cyclists persevered through treacherous terrain and inclement weather, demonstrating unwavering determination to achieve victory. The journey, fraught with difficulty, ultimately underscored the magnitude of their accomplishment, proving their mettle and solidifying their place in the annals of cycling history. The arduous path amplified the sweetness of their triumph, making their success all the more deserved.

Understanding, realistic, and mood—all are reasons how setting affects the story. If a book has a good setting, then the book might be pretty good. When you have a well-developed setting, it’s more understandable what the characters are going through. And if you have a good setting, it makes it more realistic. So, when you read it, you won’t be thrown off; the mood of the story sets it all off, because usually books have their ups and downs. That’s why authors chase the right mood, to create a compelling and believable narrative overall.

The setting of the story affected the cyclist by making him dehydrated, which could lead to a heatstroke. "I could drop from a heatstroke," this shows that it was hot out, and he was feeling bad. The intense heat of the day was clearly taking its toll on his body, as the risk of heatstroke highlights how the environment was negatively impacting his physical condition.

The terrain during the cyclist’s journey greatly affects him. For example, the first terrain that he experienced was not very hilly, but rather flat and soothing. The author stated, “I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” This shows that he was energized and happy. However, the reader can predict that the journey will not remain this joyful, because the cyclist is basically in the desert during the summer, in which it is extremely hot, and such conditions are rarely easy to endure for long. Then, the cyclist experiences hilly terrain that sucked the life from his body, especially because he had no water left. The cyclist said, “sometimes life can feel so cruel", emphasizing that the cyclist mood had changed from enthusiastic to tired and forlorn. This change of mood from the terrain can be connected to real life, as obstacles are included, in which the person must persevere and be strong to overcome, in which the cyclist finally did, demonstrating that one's environment and challenges can profoundly impact one's emotional state, demanding resilience in the face of adversity.

The features in the story greatly effect the cyclist. One feature of the setting that effects the cyclist is the heat. At first, the story says that the pine trees cooled the cyclist, but eventually the forest turned into a desert, and the heat poured down on him, making it hard to cycle because of the intense temperatures. Another feature that effected the cyclist was the lack of water. As he moved away from his beginning point, the cyclist was drinking lots of water to stay hydrated during his ride. But when he needed to refill, the water was brown and hot, so the cyclist didn’t take any because of its undrinkable condition. The lack of water plus the heat formed one giant obstacle that potentially could have killed him, but through great determination the cyclist got through this troubling time, showing resilience against the harsh environment.

The narrator in this story goes through a tough journey insisting of hope, challenge physical pain, despair, and relief. All of these are further developed by the settings where they take place, For example after taking advice from old men at a campsite, he is on his way through the deserts of California. If he had been almost anywhere else, his journey could have been much better. He could have gotten more reliable advice, or had been in a place where the towns were not miles and miles apart, isolating him further. Also, at one point he reaches a snake on the road, baking in the sun. This could symbolize a decision, which was to go and how it will affect the outcome of his trip, or perhaps the decisions he had already made. To take advice from strangers and better yet he should use it. The irony continues as he becomes dehydrated and the flat land turns hilly, increasing the physical demands. If that werenít to happen he could have been more successful and healthy on his trip. The setting in this menís story are necessary for if to have plot line and have the humour it possesses, particularly the dark kind that arises from hardship. If he were in the city, for example, he would not get lost and stranded, and therefore would have no story. In conclusion, the harsh environment of the desert is integral to the narrator's experience, creating the challenges and ironic situations that define his journey and give the narrative its unique, humorous edge.

The setting in the story changes many times. It starts in an area with rivers and pine trees. Then the cyclist arrives at a town. After that he is pounded by the hot sun and along a hilly road. With not much water left, the cyclist uses all the energy he had to get to a town where he could get something to drink. The setting was what made the cyclist's journey a hard one, as the shift from a cool, wooded area to a hot, exposed landscape presented significant challenges to his endurance and hydration.

The features of the settings affect the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit". It is early morning and everyone is still asleep as the protagonist wakes up searching for something to occupy his time. When he pulls up to the first place, he observes that the residents seem old and perhaps a little eccentric, and he notices the dilapidated condition of the buildings, thinking the houses are falling apart. He then leaves and his eye catches the sight of wide, rolling hills. In conclusion, considering the early hour, the aging population, and the state of disrepair, I would never do all the riding he did.

The setting effects the cyclist because he is in the desert with no water and doesnt know where he is going. The harsh sun beats down, and the sand stretches endlessly, disorienting him. The old men on the porch gave him wrong directions now he is lost in the desert. Dehydration sets in, blurring his vision. The cyclist find the will power to keep on moving and he finds help along the way. He pushes onward, driven by a primal urge to survive. He finds another old man there that offer him directions but he says he has a map. This reinforces his resolve to trust his instincts and find his own path to safety.

The setting in the story discouraged the biker very much. As he follows the advice of the elderly men and starts off his journey he notices that there is, ìno one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.î He uses tone words to describe how had things are when he says, ìThe water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.î He describes in exhaust how hard his journey is getting, emphasizing his growing fatigue. He describes the intense heat in the desert of California, pedaling up, ì one long, crippling hill.î The terrain did not make his ride easy at all, further compounding his difficulties. The factor of weather, rolling hills, and the shortage of water take a tall on him; these elements combined to create a truly arduous experience. If he were on flat terrain on a cool day then he would have been first fine, suggesting a more manageable and pleasant ride overall.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist a lot. The hot sun beating down on him makes him sweat and makes him thirsty, constantly draining his energy. The bumpy roads and hills make him work harder, straining his muscles with each rotation of the pedals. The abandoned places make him lose hope, the desolate scenery a constant reminder of isolation. If faced with these obstacles I would have been affected in the same way, feeling the physical toll and the creeping despair. As I believe any human would be, these environmental factors are universally challenging, impacting both the body and the mind.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The features of the setting, or nature, affect the cyclist because they are wearing her out. The cyclist is going to the city of Yosemite, but some guys gave her a short cut. Through this shortcut are hills and heat and lack of water. @CAPS1 describes this by saying, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited.” @CAPS1 is excited that there is a building that @CAPS1 might get some water from. Also, @CAPS1 wiped the sweat from her eyes, meaning it is hot outside and @CAPS1 is sweating and losing water. The arduous terrain and weather conditions are physically taxing on the cyclist, as evidenced by her sweat and desperation for water. Therefore, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist's journey and well-being.

The three most important features of the setting that effect the cyclist are the ground he is traveling, the towns he passes, and the availability of water. The ground the cyclist is riding over is important because the rougher the terrain, and the more hills there are, the more energy he must use, and the less distance he can travel. @PERSON1 is riding fine until he must travel the rolling hills which consume his energy, exhausts his water, and causes dividing hope. As he approaches towns, his hope increases but soon fades due to the realization that the town will be unable of giving him relief. When he pumps out water that tastes like ìbattery acid,î his hope once again diminishes. As he sees the bait and tackle shop, he knows he can make it there and that when he gets there he can recover. These three features of terrain, towns, and water are what effects the cyclist the most.

In the story of ìrough road ahead :do not exceed posted limitî the setting affected the cyclist. In the middle of the desert during the summer the cyclist was low on water. The old men gave him the wrong directions, so mainly it is the old guys thought he dies. The cyclist survives, but the heat and the season he was riding, along with the near-fatal experience, will probably bring another water bottle next time.

Some of the features of the setting affect the cyclist like the road was bad; it had bumps all over that made it much harder, and it also took up a lot of strength. Also, the neighborhood of two hundred degrees after that became a road with a bunch of hills, further impacting the cyclist's energy and slowing their progress.

In the story many different settings affected the author in many different ways. In the very beginning of his journey he came across a ghost town. He reacted to the features of this setting with humor and hope. "I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." He still has hope that he would end up safe and in the right place. The next setting was an abandoned shed with a water pump and a fork in the rode. He grew worried when he saw that no near town was still in sight. "This sight was troubling" when the features of the next setting caught his eye he was desperate and devastated. "At some point, tumble weed crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake" He was on rough terrain in the middle of the desert with little water, when he reached the abandoned ice factory all his hope was lost and he was planning his death. "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean." Finally, when he reached the fish camp, he was relieved "I had overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, Kiss them and buy some bait." He was overjoyed and overwhelmed because he had survived, showcasing how dramatically setting can impact one's emotional state.

Ghost towns are not exactly the most inviting place for a cyclist running low on water supply. In “Rough road ahead: do not exceed speed limit” the cyclist is affected in many ways by his surrounding settings. Starting off on a warm day with the sun bright starts off as a good thing, while his mood is still fresh and happy expressions play on his face. But as he moves on he speaks of how “The sun was beginning to beat down” expressing his remorse of listening to the old men that led him on their “shortcut.” Along the road he comes to his first let-down, a ghost town with “one ramshackle shop, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest male.” He tries to pump the water from the pumps but gets a “battery-acid” flavor and is forced to continue onward with little left to drink. This affects his mood to pity for himself and anger at the men who put him into the predicament. By the end he is relieved though when he comes to GARY & SON FISH CAMP, a place with a working sink full of cold water. He says he “had an overwhelming urge to seek out GARY & SON, kiss them and buy some bait.” His thankfulness is expressed to men he doesn’t even know but because they were the light at the end of his long, dark and very exhausting tunnel, showing how crucial the environment is to the cyclist's emotional state.

In “Rough Road Ahead,” a solo cyclist encounters several challenges. The changes in his environment directly affect the completion of his journey and his health. As the narrator makes his way to Yosemite National Park, his first encounter with his environment, none of the old men, acknowledges his need for water. The text states, “I had been rationing my water pretty regularly... in the high deserts of California in June.” Disappointingly, the truck stop’s water supply from the pumps was not adequate for his consumption, only forcing him to seek elsewhere to quench his thirst. Next, he experienced rolling hills; by expending more energy, he continued onward, still in need of water. His speed lost its quickness as thoughts of his crippling dehydration distracted him. Worse came his challenges, making his way to a bait shop as the heat beat him unmercifully. The change in his environment challenged his health and created an obstruction that nearly deterred him from his goal, illustrating how environmental factors posed a threat to both his physical well-being and his progress.

The features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the main character, the cyclist. In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the features of the setting affected the cyclist. The setting of this story greatly affects the cyclistís attitude and adversities. The path of the cyclist is through California deserts, which are dry and hot. Another element of the setting that affected the cyclist was the terrain. If the setting had been in a more urbanized area, the cyclist could have gotten help from other people, which would have made his ordeal very easy. The features in the setting are not very good for the cyclist. He’s in California in June, and it’s very hot. It’s pretty much a desert, the sun beating down mercilessly. When he stops for water, desperate for relief, the pump he finds does not have any more water in it except for a few drops. Also, the few drops that he does get taste like battery acid. So this is not very good for the cyclist, leaving him in a precarious and dangerous situation.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the author changes the mood by not only telling us how the cyclist feels, but also by describing his environment. As he's leaving the “reservoir compound,” he’s feeling pretty good because he’s just leaving “the serenity of an early-summer evening” and he’s headed toward “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite.” He’s in a beautiful setting and this affects the cyclist because he’s anticipating another one. However, when he moves to the “ghost town” and the “sun was beginning to beat down” he’s less confident and becoming more doubtful about the men's advice. Still, he’s optimistic, finding it funny that it was once “a thriving little spot.” Next, when the cyclist comes to “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral,” he knows that things are in bad shape and he is desperate for water. However, all they have is a “tarlike substance,” so he moves on, having no choice. When he comes to the “rough road tumbleweeds and a ridiculously large snake,” it affects the cyclist by letting him know that things are at their worst and he can either give up, or keep pushing through. He doubts it could get any worse, and so does the cyclist. Finally, at the end the cyclist enters a rather modern bathroom” and things are back to civilization for him, so he feels relaxed, relieved and much better, showcasing how the shifting landscape mirrors the cyclist's fluctuating emotions throughout his journey.

There are 3 features of the setting that affects the cyclist on his journey. There is a lack of water, in the middle of nowhere, and nobodyís there. Due to lack of water, this feature really affects the cyclist. He will need water in all to move and get through his journey. Water is the main thing he should have. He could end up getting dehydrated and might cause him to die right in the middle of the street. Therefore water is one feature that affects the cyclist. Furthermore heís in the middle of nowhere. There is no buildings or nothing around, not even gas stations so where it is can stop and if he had money he would be able to buy about 2 or 3 bottles of water and maybe even a few snacks. That is another feature that will affect him. Lastly nobodyís around town in able to help him out or anything. Letís say that he gets lost and heíll need direction to get wherever heís going well thereís nobody around in able to help him get around or anything. In conclusion those are the 3 main features that will defentily affect the cyclist. These conditions create a challenging and potentially dangerous environment for the cyclist, emphasizing the importance of preparation and self-sufficiency.

The setting in the story affected the cyclist by him going through obstacles to get to town. The setting was in a desert in California in June. The cyclist also had a lack of water, his throat parched from the arid air, and when he found a pump he said it was black and tasted like battery acid, offering no relief. And then he stopped for directions, hoping for a shortcut, but the men gave him the oldest set of directions, likely sending him further out of his way. So the cyclist said he would stick to his trusty map, trusting its accuracy more than the unreliable locals in this harsh environment.

In the text, the features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist. For example, the text states, ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, or structure of any kind.î This made the cyclist very lonely and they started to lose hope of finding water, feeling isolated and exposed in the barren landscape. Secondly, the text stated, "In an ironic twist the building abandoned years easlier, by the looks of it-had been a Welchís Grape Juice factoryî This made the cyclist lose more hope, after he thought the building would have people in it and he got excited at the prospect of human contact and assistance, only to be met with disappointment. Lastly, the text states, ìGRAPE AND @CAPS1íS FISH CAMPî The sight of this building gave the cyclist hope and happiness for finding a place to get a drink, signaling a potential end to their thirst and a return to civilization. The settingís features greatly affect the cyclist's feelings, demonstrating how the environment can impact one's emotional state and sense of well-being.

The features of the setting made the cyclist’s ride longer and harder than he expected. When the cyclist first headed out the road was flat and smooth. Halfway through his trip the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. The cyclist continues to pedal even though he was slowed down to 12 mph. The hills made the ride slower and harder because of the increased exertion required to climb them. Towards the end of the hills he had to make it over one long, crippling hill. The word "crippling" is used to show the physical affect that the hill had on him, implying a great deal of strain. The hills were a feature of the setting which made the cyclist’s ride longer, harder, and more physically demanding.

There are numerous features in the setting that affect the cyclist. For example, the rough road made for difficult riding. Sun, amount of miles, people all are reasons why the setting affects the cyclist. For example, the sun was beating down on him every time and the cyclist seemed to complain that it was so hot. The setting is like a desert with no water or people civilizations anywhere around him. This made him more worried because if he died, no one would know for days or weeks probably. There were several features that the cyclist encountered, and all of them affected the cyclist. For example, “several rusty bumps,” is a quote of the text explaining that he wasn’t riding on smooth ground; he was riding on rough, hard, bumpy ground. Also, he had a huge lack of water; he was water depleted. He couldn’t even go the speed limit, he was going 12 mph, he could have been going 55 mph. “Rough roads ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit,” this is another quote expressing the dangers in the ride that he was risking, adding to the challenging conditions. The setting in ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî was a very large factor of the story that was actually the cause of the protagonistís problem throughout. First it started off with the large hills he had to ride up, making him work harder and tire himself out quickly. Next the big problem was the heat of June, ì and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because î The heat was so really bad because it made him hot, thus depleting his water supply [which he needed to survive] and it gave the large, almost inevitable risk of falling from a heatstroke and dying. The relentless sun beat down, baking the asphalt and radiating back up, intensifying the feeling of dehydration. The heat also made the abandoned Juice Factory all the more ironic and bitter for the protagonist. ìA sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen.î In this desolate landscape, the factory served as a cruel reminder of what he lacked: refreshment and escape from the oppressive conditions. @CAPS1, in the unbearable heat with no water left and @CAPS2 knows how many miles left to cycle, this really made him feel like the sorriest, unluckiest man in the world. The setting overall, seemed almost crafted to make the protagonist not only suffer from the natural elements, but from things that seemed meant purely taunt him for it. The harsh environment, with its physical demands and psychological torments, truly became an antagonist in itself, exacerbating his struggles and pushing him to his limits.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is hard to go far on a bike when the place you are riding is dry, abandoned, quiet, hot, cold, and straightforward. The features of the setting affected the cyclist very much. The text says, “The sun was beginning to beat down” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The hot sun was making the cyclist sweat profusely. The hills the cyclist had to ride up were wearing him out considerably. He was getting tired faster as he exerted more energy to climb them. The text says, “I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink” (Kurmaskie @NUM3). The modern bathroom had good, cold water readily available. This allowed the cyclist to drink from it without hesitation. The water replenished the cyclist, allowing him to regain some of his lost strength and continue his ride. Therefore, the environmental features had both negative and positive impacts on the cyclist's journey, influencing his physical state and ability to proceed.

The features of the setting in the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î greatly affected the cyclist. In the beginning of this manís journey he was confident in his abilities. ìI rode in the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.î The cyclist was prepared for an exciting day and the setting supported this feeling. "The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them." As the setting began to change and his water ran out, the cyclist's attitude changed. He was ìtraveling through the high deserts of California in Juneî without much water and begun to feel desperate. As more and more abandoned buildings and deserted towns appeared he went into despair. ìAt some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously larg snake - it really did look like a diamondback-blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.î The unforgiving terrain and isolation intensified his fear. He was in the middle of nowhere with no one around and because of this setting he lost hope of surviving. He thought he was going to die of heat stroke, not having any water left, on these short rolling hills and under the extremely hot sun. Ultimately, after enduring the harsh environment, he found his way back to civilization. The cyclist was affected by the features of the setting, going from confidence, to desperation and despair, and then to relief, the changes in setting caused his change in attitude throughout this journey.

The cyclist lost hope because he was in the California desert in June. The cyclist started to lose hope because there was a rusty water pump that pumped out battery-acid tasting water; each sip was a struggle. When he saw the sign “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” he was very cautious, slowing down considerably. The cyclist thought for sure that he was going to die out there, under the relentless sun. The cyclist also felt lonely because in the text it says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The cyclist was in the California desert, and that isolation, coupled with the harsh conditions, made him think he was going to die out there, alone and forgotten. His dwindling water supply and the desolate landscape contributed to his despair.

In "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, he describes his trying biking trip through California. In the essay, he describes the weather with "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." While this June does not directly characterize the weather, the reader can confirm a clear image of the sweltering heat of a desert in the summer. When the author comes across the "ghost town" followed by the dilapidated shack, and finally the sign that read "Rough Road Ahead," his hope of finding Yosemite Park was gone. The hopelessness of the situation made the author want to give up, thinking that he was going to die out in the desert from dehydration and exhaustion. This can be related to anyone that has been lost in unfavorable conditions, and the feeling of helplessness and fear that goes along with it. It feels like everything is against you, with nothing working in your favor, and this is what the author experiences in his description of his trip in "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," illustrating the universal feeling of despair when facing seemingly insurmountable obstacles.

The setting affected the cyclist; the exhaustion was getting to him. What made it worse was that he was out in the heat, sweating, which also caused dehydration. The relentless sun beat down, amplifying his fatigue, and with each drop of sweat lost, his strength diminished further, making his already difficult ride even more challenging.

To begin with a feature that affect the cyclist was a lack of water this is shown when the speaker says when I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid-thats was one of the biggest factors he had risked. This tainted water source highlights the harsh conditions and the lengths he had to go to in order to simply survive the journey. The risk associated with hydration underscores the extreme nature of his undertaking.

As the reader listened and followed the directions of the old-timers he faced many issues and also learned a lesson. As he began to ride into the day break of morning he had strong legs and even a smile on his face. As time went on he soon became close to out of water and experienced a loss of energy. The hot summer day made him sweat and he began to think that the birds would pluck at his body as if he would die on his ride to Yosemite. When he finally got to a town he soon refreshed himself, and learned that he would start to follow his own way of getting to places. He realized that while advice is helpful, personal experience and intuition should also guide his journey, ensuring a more adaptable and successful trip.

The features of the setting in the essay ìDo not exceed the posted speed limitî affected the cyclist in a negative way. The more and more he rode, he thought more negatively and had alot of doubt. The bleak and desolate environment, therefore, actively undermines his resolve and fosters a sense of hopelessness that permeates his thoughts.

The features in the setting are very effective to the cyclist. He is in a desert area of California and he has limited water supply. It is very hot and very dry. The features of the setting strongly affected the cyclist. The rolling hills were the cyclist’s most challenging problem because they were long and crippling. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit.” The cyclist’s mood seems to change as the road and setting does. In "Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit," the cyclist's journey takes a turn for the worse. Initially, the author savors the tranquility of a campground near Lodi, California. He then seeks directions from "old-timers" who, from his perspective, "sounded so sure of themselves when pointing off landmarks and spouting off towns I would come to along this breezy route." Trusting their confident guidance, the cyclist sets off, unaware that their advice would ultimately prove detrimental to his ride.

When the old guy asked if he knew the way and the cyclist confidently replied, "Yes sir! I own a very good map," he believed he was prepared. He thought he was going to die, imagining his demise in this desolate landscape. He said, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” It was a hot summer day, the sun beating down mercilessly, and there were tumbleweeds and snakes by the road, adding to the sense of desolation and making him feel hotter and more thirsty than he would be if it was cooler and if there was a big river flowing by the road, offering relief. But it was hot and dry in California, almost desert-like, and it made him feel like he was dying because he was in the middle of nowhere; therefore, the setting profoundly affected the cyclist's physical and mental state, pushing him to the brink of despair.

This cyclist had the conditions of the land to deal with. He didn't have too much water with him, and there wasn't a good source anywhere near him that he could see. He just had to keep going. He also talked about how the road was rough, a seemingly endless stretch of cracked asphalt and loose gravel. This was conflicting on how long it took him to get to the next place with water. Moreover, he was in a desert area. The air was dry and hot, the heat was making him sweat, and that was leading him to become dehydrated, forcing him to ration his dwindling supply even more carefully. The cyclist knew he had to carefully manage his resources and push through the challenging conditions to reach his destination and replenish his water.

In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the features of the setting effect the cyclist. They effect the cyclistís confidence, and hope. Also, because there are so many almost-buildings and ghost towns, this gives him a palpable haze of uncertainty that he will be able get the water, a shimmer of hope intertwined with the desolation. The oppressive heat and abandoned structures combine to create an environment of both physical and psychological challenge for the cyclist.

Almost all of the cyclist’s surroundings are old and barren, the landscape seemingly untouched by time. Hot, desert-like weather intensified the harshness of the environment. The road itself was hard to ride on, adding to the challenge. “Flat Road was replaced by short rolling hills,” further impeding his progress. So his ride was a very rough and tiresome one, a true test of endurance against the unyielding elements and unforgiving terrain.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by how much confidence in where he’s going and how he’s gonna get there. Having no water can diminish resolve and impact the cyclist's belief in his ability to complete the journey.

If the sun had not been so blaring and the road so treacherous, perhaps the journey would have been easier. Also, the elevation often bothers the author because he had to get over it while battling dryness and dehydration.

When cycling or doing any outdoor sport, the setting matters greatly. If it's cold you need a jacket. Hot you need water. Depending on how secure it could be life or death. It could be really hilly and you might get tired, and if you have no water you could die. Also, it depends if it's in a city, suburb, small town, desert, highway; all these factors play a huge roll in cycling. Considering these environmental variables is crucial for preparation; ensuring appropriate clothing, hydration, and safety measures are in place will help to ensure a safe and enjoyable experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in negative ways. The cyclist was in California in June weather. If it wasn’t so hot, he wouldn’t have needed water as badly. He wouldn’t have been sweating as much. Also, there weren’t any buildings or cars around, so there wasn’t anyone to help him. ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structures of any kind.î These features of the setting could affect the cyclist. Because of the isolated and hot environment, the cyclist faces a greater challenge in obtaining assistance and staying hydrated.

In the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î written by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One feature that affects him is that he is cycling ìthrough the high deserts of California in Juneî(Kurmaskie). This affect would mean that the author would be dehydrated faster because of the intense heat and dryness. The cyclist, author, is dehydrated before he can make it to the next town because he ìgathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in [his] mouthî(Kurmaskie) hoping to stimulate saliva production. This action illustrates how the harsh desert environment directly impacts his physical state, pushing him to desperate measures for basic hydration.

In the essay Do not exceed posted speed limit by Joe Kurmaskie, the surrounding setting affected the cyclist. The setting was somewhere outside Lodi, California in early summer. The cyclist took advice from some old men that led him to difficult places to get out of. As the sun made things hotter and his water started to deplete getting to Yosemite was much harder. The cyclist was traveling through high deserts of California in June. When the terrain started to change from flat road to rolling hills the cyclist pushed himself even harder to get to his destination. The sun and hot air dehydrated him faster. After traveling over, "along, crippling hill,î  the cyclist had to stop and even tried sucking on a pebble in an effort to take his mind off thirst. When he found a habited store he was exhausted and relieved. These features of the setting had a big effect on the cyclist, as the weather dehydrated him while the terrain exhausted him.

The settings in the essay affected the cyclist mentally and physically. The fact that he was riding through the desert in June affected how long his water supply lasted. If he had been riding in the spring then his water supply would’ve lasted longer and he would’ve had more energy. Since the town the old men had told the cyclist about was abandoned that also affected the cyclist because he had to keep on going even though he was getting weaker. What affected the cyclist most, I think, was when he arrived at the bait store. If that had been abandoned like everything else, the cyclist would’ve died. Luckily though it wasn’t, and he was able to drink water. The factory affected him mentally because the picture of the boy was haunting him in a way due to the fact he was drinking juice, something the cyclist couldn’t do. All in all, I think the conditions that the cyclist was in affected him greatly, highlighting how environmental factors can influence one's physical and mental state. Since I’ve fainted from dehydration before, I know how it feels to be without water. First you get a headache; then your mouth dries up and desperation sets in, and finally you get dizzy.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affects the cyclist's physical and mental state. There are negative and positive effects for each state. The physical effects of the cyclist because of the settings are apparent throughout the story. For example, when the cyclist reaches Mr. Patterson and Bill’s Fish Camp, he is able to hydrate once again. This positive effect makes the cyclist healthy and safe once again. The setting impacts the cyclist very substantially. This can be seen when the cyclist is in the comfortable camp around Lone Pine. He feels happy in this area. This positive effect prepares the cyclist to go on the trip to Yosemite. Also, when the cyclist reaches the “Ramshackle Station”, with several rusty pumps, and a corral, he feels troubled. He is negatively affected mentally by the little amount of available water. In addition, the cyclist felt "sad" and "hopeless" when cycling in the dry, arid terrain. The cyclist is in the worst mental state in this place. Finally, the cyclist felt relieved upon seeing the fish camp. He describes the feeling by saying that his troubles are now “behind” him. The setting's positive effect in this instance changes the mental state from negative to positive. Setting was the main factor in deciding upon the cyclist’s physical and mental state. Setting affects the cyclist’s physical and mental state in positive and negative ways almost equally in the story.

The setting made the cyclist feel lonely. The cyclist lost hope quickly because she never saw any people or water on the way. The cyclist said they saw a “ghost town”. Before he got to the fish camp the cyclist saw no one and was becoming dehydrated. This caused him to lose hope, and at some points he thought he was going to die. For example, he says, "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” The barren landscape, devoid of any sign of life, amplified his despair. It is clear that the setting affected the cyclist in a very negative way.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he was in a forest with uneven terrain and thick roots. This was a bumpy trip with a lot of troubles along the way, navigating fallen branches and slippery leaves. This was a long trip, testing his endurance and skill. But he made it through, tough with a story to tell in the end, a testament to his perseverance against the challenging forest landscape.

The setting of the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî effects the cyclists physical and emotional attitude. In the beginning of the essay the cyclist, ìrode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on [his] face.î It was not too hot yet in the morning. So, the cyclist was happy and strong. He was confident he could conquer anything. As the day grew on ìthe sun was beginning to beat downî He was beginning to drink lots of water but he was still confident and strong. ìI came to a ramshackle shed [and] several rusty pumps the sight was troubling. ìThe cyclist was travelling in the hot deserts of California. He was becoming tired and thirsty. He had to save as much water as possible. The pumps were dry and added to his despair. What started as a confident ride into the desert became a survival ride. Once the cyclist findswater he is relieved. He feels more confident and can ride to his destination. The weather and setting can affect us emotionally and physically just like in the essay, the cyclist became tired both physically and emotionally as the hot, sunny day went on.

As the cyclist begins his journey, he is confident & exited to have been offered new directions from some ìold wise menî which promise a shortcut. This water supply is mediocre & attitude willed against the flat and hilly terrain, untill he realizes the directions are way off target. The cyclist was making his way to Yosemite when he came to the first ìtownî but it wasn't a town but more of a ghost dwelling, sun-bleached and desolate. As he continued hoping the shortcut offered by the old ìcodgensî would actually materialize, he realized he was utterly alone in the hot desert wt a depleting water supply & dwindling spirit. He was disturbed that he had chosen to follow the advice from the older men and through his his pain & dispair, encouraged himself by deciding he would never listen to their type again. The cyclist felt skrewed over, yet through his will & determination, by rationing water & mentally choosing to cycle for each hill one at a time, he endured his physicall, emotional & mental trials and lived to learn the valuable lesson of never consulting old ì codgersî on mapping issues, because their information would most likely be out datted. His experience underscored the importance of relying on current and reliable resources for navigation.

The whys the setting affected the cyclist is that the hotter it was, the more water that he drank to stay hydrated and regulate his body temperature. Also, the further he traveled, the more tired he got, which caused him to get hotter and expend more energy, which in turn caused him to drink more of his water to replenish his fluids and combat fatigue. Therefore, the environmental temperature and distance directly influenced his hydration needs.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly in his determined ride. At first, he seemed at ease, talking about the cool pines and rushing rivers he was going to encounter once getting to Yosemite. After a strenuous ride, he started to get nervous and wonder if he was even going to survive. He was running out of water, and he thought he saw a diamondback. Once he reached the rolling hills, he saw a posted speed limit sign saying not to exceed the speed limit of 55 m.p.h. He was doing a water-depleting 12 m.p.h., wondering how he was going to survive. At the end of the rolling hills, he came to an old Welch's grape factory, wondering why his life was so cruel. After that, he was determined to survive and make it to his destination. He picked out spokes on the horizon and rode towards them, making his way across the desert. He finally made it to "Olly and Wilber's Fish Camp," where he knew he was safe and would survive. The harsh landscape had tested him, but his resolve ultimately led him to safety.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the author uses features of the setting to show the effects on the cyclist. The features of the setting affected the cyclist because they figured that they were old enough and seen what was going on and been through that situation that they were well experienced and knew more about what was going on, so the people should listen to them, feeling entitled to be heard due to their perceived experience within that particular environment.

After the cyclist spoke to the old timers who hadn’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office, his confidence in them began to wane. He entered the desert happy, hopeful, and determined. As his water reservoir began to disappear, and he approached the sight of the old shed, canal and a couple water pumps, he began to feel touched by a sense of foreboding. He made an attempt to get the water from the pumps, but it was hot and tasted like battery acid. As he rode on, his confidence only faded more. He travelled through the desert, narrowly avoiding a ridiculously large snake, and was running low on water. Finally he saw a building in the distance, which ironically enough was an abandoned juice factory; a sign featuring a lemon sipping on some succulent icy liquid teased ruin, and he began to lose hope. He didn’t think he would make it to his destination, or anywhere else for that matter. Although after approaching the old factory, he came across a bait shop where his hope and energy was refounded, giving him the strength to continue.

There are many features in the setting that will affect the cyclists. One feature is the climate. The setting in the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” significantly impacts the cyclist in three ways.
