Another way the setting affected the cyclist was the surroundings. In the story it said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind” (Kurmaskie). That says there's no one around to help him if he gets hurt or needs assistance. Also, there's nowhere nearby to replenish his water supply, compounding the problem of dehydration and highlighting the isolation of his location. Thus, the harsh desert environment significantly impacted the cyclist's well-being and increased the difficulty of his journey.

Many of the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The most obvious and direct feature would be that this adventure took place in the “high deserts of California in June.” Considering that passage says blistering heat; high meaning it's going to be closer to the sun, deserts, where the world is hot, California, which can be smoggy, and June, which is the middle of summer, the cyclist would be contending with intense solar radiation and minimal shade. Also, the closest water supply was “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees,” rendering it undrinkable without significant cooling. There was a “long crippling hill” to climb, all while the sun was beating down. All of that would most obviously affect the cyclist by making him tired, which he vividly explains by expressing his fears of losing consciousness, highlighting the very real danger of heatstroke and exhaustion in such an environment.

In the story, ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One example is when the cyclist says ìI noticed the terrain changing, Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.î This affects the cyclist because it makes him work harder when he is dying of thirst, especially on a hot summer day. It makes his muscles work harder and use his strength more. In the summer time it is extremely hot. When the cyclist is biking it is very hot, he says ìÖ in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.î After this quote he is explaining the difficulty of getting frustrated and thereís no cold water. This affects the cyclist and makes him think about water, not bothering to think about where he is; he could be lost. He didnít have a good map to begin with, and the heat and thirst only compound his navigational challenges. Therefore, the oppressive heat and changing landscape directly impact the cyclist’s physical and mental state, highlighting how the setting becomes an antagonist in his journey.

As the cyclist goes on his trip, he is met with many dreary places and people. For starters, the old men he knew he shouldn't have trusted but did anyway. This led him through the desert. Even in a car the desert can be a very despairing place. On a bicycle it must be even worse knowing that if you run out of water no one will be there to save you from dehydration. Just the endlessly bleak landscapes also played a role in the cyclist's feelings. Another bad feature is the endless amount of abandoned towns and spoiled water. Every time he thought he was saved he was put down again by that fact. For example he had to pump for minutes only to get bad tasting water, only a tease of hope. Finally just when his strength was about to give out he found the bait place & water and that dramatically improved his mood and a place to rest too bad there was another old man there, isn't it?! It seems the cyclist's journey is fated to be filled with disappointment.

In the essay, the features of the cyclist affect the setting because the readers wouldn't have thought that he was in that bad of danger if he hadn't been going through the desert. When the cyclist got to the grape factory, he stated that he was almost dehydrated, suggesting the harshness of the environment had taken its toll. And then, when he got to the bait shop, he drank from the faucet, further emphasizing the cyclist's desperate need for water due to the arid conditions. These details highlight how the cyclist's condition directly reflects and is affected by the severity of the desert setting.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there were rolling hills that went up and down, and it took a lot of strength. Also, he barely had water because it was so hot he kept drinking and ran out of water early. In the story it says when he was riding that “He barely noticed that the sun was starting to beat down.” This quote shows it was starting to get hot, increasing his thirst. Also, in the story he says “I checked my water supply,” which means he’s starting to realize his water is running short, adding to his worry. So in all, the setting is hot and has no water source, and the rolling hills require exertion, so the cyclist is being affected by all of this.

Setting was an important factor in the story. I was in a desert, a place where there is a lack of water. And I was on a bike, which is dangerous because you are using your feet to move, which takes out energy and uses water from your body, making the already scarce resource even more critical to conserve.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was biking up hills in extreme heat. He also had a short water supply while headed in the wrong direction, further increasing his dehydration and disorientation under the scorching sun. Thus, the harsh environment severely hampered his progress.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The directions given to the cyclist by the elderly were incorrect, and he got lost along unfamiliar roads. The lack of water led to the possibility of sucking pebbles to forget about his thirst and the increasing dryness in his mouth. The rolling hills caused the cyclist to use more energy as he constantly adjusted his gears and pedaled harder. These were the affects the setting had to the cyclist, ultimately impacting his journey and physical state.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. The sun beat down, and the road stretched endlessly. When she biked around a bend, ìmy troubles, thirsts, and fear were all behind me.î The sudden shade and a gentle breeze offered immediate relief.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie, a cyclist set out on a bike ride in the heat of summer in California where he would be staying. He met some old people who gave him a "short cut." As he found out, most of the places he was told about were abandoned ghost towns without a single drop of drinkable water. If he were in a different setting, like by a river or spring, he would just stop and drink from that. Or even if he was in a more populated, industrialized area, he could stop in any building and ask for a drink; but he was in the dry, hot, abandoned hills of California without any water. The sun beat down mercilessly, baking the earth and reflecting the heat back up at him. Under these conditions, he grew tired, thirsty, dehydrated, and desperate for a drink; finally, he came upon a bait shop that had water there, a welcome sight after his ordeal. The bait shop offered not just water, but also a brief respite from the relentless sun, marking a turning point in his challenging journey.

During the cyclist's journey, he was affected by the setting frequently. When he was cycling, it became very hot to him, but at first, it wasn’t so bad. “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely Noticed it.” This proves that the cyclist knows it was getting hot, but it did not affect him initially. Another thing that affected him was the time that he was traveling in. “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly and I was traveling through the high deserts in California in June.” This proves that the cyclist was constantly drinking because of the time of day and year he was out, implying he was trying to combat the heat. All of this shows that the setting affected the cyclist on his ride.

I think that the features of the setting really do affect the way someone rides a bike because certain places have certain terrain. Some types are not always good for a bike rider because if it's bumpy, then someone could fall off the bike, especially if they're going fast. Also, if it is dark, you might not even be able to see where you are going, then you could hurt yourself very seriously, perhaps breaking a bone or getting a concussion. That's why riding a bike can be dangerous. Also, if you're in the type of environment where everything is smooth, like a paved bike path, then you might be able to have a nice, safe bike ride.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by changing him physically. He was in the California desert in the middle of June without any water left. This was taking a physical toll on him. His physical effect was making him feel hopeless as well. He says, “It was a sad hopeless laugh mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself." So the way he was suffering from dehydration physically effected his emotional state because he felt as though there was nothing he could do. Had he been in another place, for example a forest in Oregon, where it does not get nearly as hot as Southern California, he would not have been suffering from dehydration, nor have been in such an isolated place. His cycling could be compared to the climbers who were lost in the snow storm in the Himalayas. Instead of dehydration and heat stroke, however they suffered from hypothermia. Had they been on a different mountain, there would have been no snow storm and they would be fine. The outcome of this story and the climbers was determined by their setting, showing how crucial the environment is to the experiences within it.

The conditions gave the cyclist no hope at some points because the heat of the land and the features of the setting were so harsh he had no hope, like when the cyclist says, "I hope I make it to the horizon," because there's nothing else to compare. He can't say, "Let's ride to the next building or mailbox" because there are none. The endless desert features make the cyclist feel that it's just him; no one can help him; he'll die of dehydration. Then the features get worse; he sees the Welch's Grape Juice billboard, giving him little hope of survival, then he finds out that it's deserted, and that's like the final thing he gives up. The cyclist, almost unconscious, then runs into the fishing store where he has a sip of water. So, the harsh and unforgiving features of the landscape were the main reason the cyclist lost hope during his ordeal.

The features of setting affect the author because it moves him dehydrated. The dessert sun sucked sweat out of him and he had no water to bring that would replace his electrolytes. Also, once the author had got into the hills he had lost a lot of his energy so peddling up was a lot of work. If I were the author I would also have gotten tired because you need water in your body to survive; the heat would have compounded the exhaustion, making the physical exertion even more draining.

The features of the setting in ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî affect the cyclist greatly. In the cyclists opinion things began pretty well. He had a positive attitude as it states ìwith strong legs and a smile on my face.î As the man moves on he comes to a fort of sorts. To him, the sight was troubling. Though troubling, he still had the confidence that he could continue. Next he noticed the changes in the terrain. He explained ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.î This means that he would have to peddle harder and with greater force in order to get over the hills, further depleting his energy. The weather was hot and the cyclist was running out of water. The possibility of heatstroke came to mind. ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kindî, as told by the man. His mind entered a state of sad, and hopeless thoughts, but he persevered and cycled on. At this point he was very thirsty and felt his death was near. He said ìI was going to die and the birds would pick me cleanî As he kept going he spotted an old guy in sight. He regained hope and moved ahead. The features of this story affected the cyclist physically and mentally. Physically he was tired and worn out. In this horrible state, mentally he was becoming negative and pessimistic about his travel. The setting's features interfered with the cyclist's physical and mental state, ultimately testing his resilience and highlighting the impact of environment on human endurance and mindset.

In this story, ìNo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, by Joe Kurmaskie I believe the setting greatly affect the cyclist. I believe this because when itís long downhill cool roads is fine, but if it is straight uphill roads and extremely hot he feels like he canít keep pedaling, especially when the sun beats down relentlessly. The cyclist gets very weary when the setting is out in the hot desert with no one around, which further impacts his morale, so the setting has a huge affect on the mood in this story. The environmental conditions, therefore, play a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's experience and emotional state, impacting his journey.

A cyclist is a bike rider. They can be in groups of different people, or they can be a solo cyclist. Some cyclists go for a few miles riding their bikes; some can go for more, like @NUM1 miles. Some go over hills, go through water; they do a lot with what they do, often pushing themselves physically. They have a lot of time on their hands to ride a bike that far, developing endurance and skill.

The setting is hot like desert, no one around, and very dry. Being hot outside affects the cyclist because he is sweaty and needs water. The relentless sun beats down, intensifying his thirst. Having no one around causes him to not get water which he needs for his journey. This isolation amplifies the danger of dehydration. These things make him weak and make it harder for him to find a place to get water, hindering his progress and jeopardizing his well-being as he desperately searches for any sign of civilization.

The setting affect the cyclist because it could be a good or bad thing. If a cyclist adjusts his own settings, such as tire pressure or seat height, that's generally good as it optimizes performance. However, if somebody messes with them unexpectedly, that could be bad, potentially leading to discomfort or even accidents. This shows the cyclist's settings play an important role.

California sunshine beat down as I pedaled, Yosemite my distant goal. My journey began hopefully enough, but soon I passed through a ghost town, buildings decaying under the relentless sun, a stark reminder of dreams faded. The sight planted a seed of doubt, and I pressed on with newfound caution. Later, the tall pines emerged, their scent a promise of cool mountain air, a feeling that these were my kind of trees, that "had my name written all over them." This brought a surge of hope. But then a rusty pump and ramshackle shed appeared, symbols of neglect in the desolate landscape. The hope quickly faded, replaced by a renewed sense of wariness. The hills demanded grueling effort. A rattlesnake slithering across the road made me pause, and the sight of an abandoned Welch's juice company, a relic of forgotten commerce, deepened my unease. Finally, I found water at a restroom, a simple act of salvation that washed away the accumulated anxieties of the road. Without these fluctuating landscapes and stark contrasts, my ride would have been a monotonous experience, lacking the emotional peaks and valleys that made the journey a true challenge. It was the push and pull of the setting that ultimately shaped my experience, creating a narrative far more compelling than a simple bike ride.

Winding hills, limited water, and poor directions are the troubles of this cyclist. First, he gets very bad directions from a group of old men who haven't been outside of their porch in a while, their memories of the road faded and twisted. Then, he goes through the first town and, thinking he'll find water later, doesn't fill his water bottles. Soon after, he gets lost and runs out of water, his throat parched under the blazing sun, but thankfully finds a fishing store where there is water and people who give him a better map. With renewed hydration and improved guidance, he can finally continue his journey with a sense of hope.

No water, and no direction effects the cyclist. Water effect cyclist because he said in the essay ìI could drop from heatstroke" (Kurmaskie), showing the immediate danger of dehydration. Also no direction is another big one. It is important because without direction he is going to rideing for a long time, exacerbating the lack of water and increasing his risk. In conclusion water and no direction was the cyclist problem in the story.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he thought he packed enough water, so he began on his way. He drank most of his water less than halfway to his destination. He didn’t realize how hot it was, the sun beating down relentlessly on the shadeless road, until he got down to his last couple of sips of water. He started to become dehydrated. He remembered the old men said that the next town was about eighteen miles away, so he kept on going. When he reached the town, there was nothing to drink, just an old rundown factory baking in the heat. He took some rocks and sucked on them; he went over a bump and swallowed it. He said to himself next time he would just go by what the map said. Everything he had gone past on the way had been rundown and abandoned, reflecting the harshness of the environment. Finally, he reached a bait shop and went inside the bathroom and got some water, relieved to have finally found respite from the unforgiving landscape.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist a great deal. For example, it was hot and hilly, causing him to get dehydrated. He went down this rusty, bumpy road, which didn't help his dehydration. And another example would be he found a place where he could sit and plan and find the best way to get where he was going. Thus, the features of the setting affected the cyclist.

The cyclist goes through many natural settings that affect him. First of all he rides into barren land. The cyclist portrayed this barrenness by saying ìit fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.î This was in response to the first ìtownî he came across, a place clearly devoid of life and resources. Next he speaks of a large snake that came close to him which is dangerous, but luckily he manuvers out of its way, narrowly escaping a potentially deadly encounter. But the worse setting the cyclist had to deal with was the lack of water. This is a threat to any living creature, and the cyclist's thirst grew more intense with each passing mile. But in the end he found some water and the story ended fine, illustrating his resilience and the crucial role of the environment in his survival.

In the essay ìRough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the setting relates to how the author is feeling. At first, when the author sees the abandoned first ìtownî he is not too worried about it and moves on. ìI chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.î The author is okay, and still has enough water, so the harshness of the environment doesn't register. Next he starts to get low on water, and he becomes more panicked; which in return makes the day seem even hotter. ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of california in June.î Now that the author is low on water, the day seems worse. Afterward he continues on and runs into a rattlesnake, which makes him even more panicked. ìand a ridiculously large snake. It really did look like a diamond back-blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.î This close encounter amplifies his anxiety. Finally, when he got to the bait store and drank from the sink; things didnít seem so bad anymore and there was no more talk about water nor the heat. As a result the setting was related to the authorís moods. The external environment mirrored, and was influenced by, the author's internal state of mind throughout the journey.

The features of the setting did affect the cyclist in this small story. In this story the setting is a hot dry terrain which can be better explained by the name California. This heat of the desert climate seems to start have an effect on him about after he reaches the first town. I know this by his statement. "This place might have been a thriving little spot at time –say, before the last war-but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chucked, checked my water supply and moved on. The the sun was beginning to beat down." The summer heat is thriving how during this ride and he is drinking lots of water. So this setting does affect him greatly it causes him to use his water supply and it causes him to begin the process of dehydration. I know how the summer heat can affect you during physical activities. At times it feels like you are going to die but that building is always around the bend just for the cyclist. Therefore, the harsh Californian desert environment significantly impacts the cyclist, influencing his resource consumption and physical state.

In Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit, the features of the setting are devastating to the cyclist's condition. Traveling "through the high desert of California" is surely never an easy task to begin with. Without proper hydration, people often suffer heatstrokes or pass out, sometimes even perishing; it is entirely worse for this cyclist because of the effort he is exerting, pedaling over "short, rolling hills." Even worse, the trail a few very old, eccentric men set run on doesn't do much in the way of helping with a depleted water supply. The first town the cyclist comes across easily fits "the traditional definition of a ghost town," and the only other water pump he comes to emits only sewage and incredibly hot brackish water. Therefore, the heat is only made worse by the look of water on the cyclist's path. This combination of features in the setting causes a great deal of distress to the cyclist, almost pushing him to death. The harsh, unforgiving environment, combined with the physical exertion and the false promise of relief, creates a truly life-threatening situation for the cyclist.

There are many ways the setting affected the cyclist in this story like the weather, supply of food and water, wrong estimation for old people and the road. First off the weather was very dry and it was two hundred degrees, so it made you sweat and hard to breath. The cyclist's energy was quickly depleted under such extreme heat. The supply of water was harsh, not much around at all, and when he tried to get water the pumps would pump out not water, which left him severely dehydrated and weakened. The weather and water supply were two major affects on the cyclist, ultimately hindering his progress and threatening his well-being.

In the beginning of the story the author is happy, but towards the end grows upset. "I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my faceî (@NUM1). This shows how the author is in a good mood and happy to be there. She is on a journey, and no one can touch her. Then the story takes an unexpected turn. ìWith what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,î (@NUM2). After getting lost in a town that seems distant from any living things the author hears people! She is extremely reliefed to have found anyone of help to her. She gets water and is forever greatful for the kindness shown. The setting is horrifying to her because you will feel like you cant even if you live there! She felt alone and that she would die in that place. If the setting was in a city surrounded by buildings the author would still feel some security even without water, ultimately making her experience much less frightening.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The reasons were the water and the hills. One reason was water because his water were cooled down after he refilled it all the way up. My last reason is because of the rolling hills, which made the ride more physically demanding. Therefore, the cyclist's experience was noticeably shaped by these environmental factors.

There are features such as blazing heat coming off the sun, ìshort, rolling hillsî, and no water. There was also the fact that the rider thought he was in the middle of nowhere. This has a great effect on the cyclist, both physical and emotional. The relentless sun beats down, exacerbating dehydration, while the unending hills demand constant exertion. The isolation amplifies feelings of despair. The heat, lack of water and constant up hill riding can take a lot of energy out of someone and make it extremely hard to ride. Not to mention there isnít much hope left so that eliminates the whole mind over matter thing. All the features of the setting put together can lead to major trouble, creating a perilous situation for the cyclist and diminishing their chances of success.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. After about @NUM1 miles, when in need of water supply the cyclist found a rusty pipe which a tarlike substance came out, then a brackish water substance. While cycling, you are in need of clean water. Next, the terrain changed from being flat to very hilly. In need of water, the last thing you need is to be challenged more physically. Later on down the road, there were no cars or any buildings in sight. When you are feeling the worst, you would want someone to be near in case you fall, but no one was in sight on that road. Lastly, seeing the old Welch's Grape Juice Factory would affect the cyclist. Seeing that image of a drink factory right in front of you but not in business has to make them feel like he/she will never make it. These specific and unfortunate features of the setting undoubtedly took a toll on the cyclist's physical and mental state, compounding the already challenging situation and potentially diminishing their resolve.

The features in the setting dramatically affect the cyclist. Everything was fine until he ran out of water and reached the hills. Now if he was in Callala, he wouldn’t have dehydrated. But the hills were sure to play with his mind, testing his endurance with each incline. The most important setting is the Welch's grape juice factory. He would have had all of the grape juice he wanted, but it was abandoned, a silent, rusted monument to forgotten industry. An ironic twist, as he calls it, a bitter reminder of what could have been. And the last one is the bait shop that saves his life, where an old man offers him directions and a much-needed drink of water, proving that help can be found in the most unexpected places. Ultimately, the setting's harshness and unexpected kindness shaped his journey.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist because he was in the middle of no-where with no water or direction. I was doing a water-depleting @NUM2. Sometimes life can feel so cruelî. By saying he was doing @NUM2 when it should have been @NUM1 was saying he was getting very exhausted and he needed water to get him feeling refreshed once again. The relentless sun and barren landscape surely amplified his thirst and fatigue, making his situation even more dire. Also, the fact that there was no one in sight to give him direction effected him too because he didnt know where the next refuge was. ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. ì From the mans point of view, he probably thought civilization was many more miles away and he probably could not make it that for. This isolation, coupled with his dehydration, would undoubtedly lead to increased anxiety. The setting effected him by making him probably begin to stress or panic a lot for the most part, as the vast emptiness and lack of resources contributed to a growing sense of desperation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example he feels dehydrated and tired because he is riding through the desert and has a lack of water. I often feel this way when jogging for extended periods of time. The men in the story who "haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office" also add to the story. Due to their role, the cyclist takes an unmarked shortcut that turns out to be horrible. The Welch’s factory affects the cyclist because it increases his thirst and causes him to once more think about it. The sign showing grape juice looks irresistible to him and drives him to keep forward in search of anything to drink. The terrain change also affects the cyclist because it causes him to have to work ever harder to get up hills now rather than just ride flat terrain. All these environmental factors combine to create a challenging and compelling journey for the cyclist, influencing his physical state and decisions along the way.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The relentless sun beat down, intensifying the need for hydration. The heat made him drink more so he ran out of water more quickly. Then he would try and conserve water by not drinking and this would cause him to dehydrate more because he was losing body fluid in sweat secondly, in paragraph @NUM2 it says, îFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills,î These hills affect the cyclist because he would need to use more energy to cycle up the hills. The features of the setting directly affects the cyclist. ìI was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.î This affects the cyclist because in June it is very hot and going through a desert makes it worse, so he would continue to drink water until he has no more. The relentless sun beats down, increasing the risk of dehydration and heatstroke. He is also using energy which is making him sweat and drink more water. ìOne ramshackle shed. Several rusty pipes and a corral that couldnít hold the lamest mule greeted me.î This could also cause a problem because he canít renew his water source, which means he has to conserve it, and canít use as much energy. Both of these things factor into the setting, in a desert with no water, affecting the cyclist more than cycling in a cold day. The cyclist in, ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî, was affected greatly by the features of the setting. First of all the weather was extremely hot and hot weather just makes you feel exhausted and like you canít do anything. The sun beats down on the black asphalt, radiating heat back up and intensifying the feeling of fatigue. Also no one is in sight. She is all alone making her feel small and helpless. The author is obviously dieing of thirst and with nothing around her she acts even thirstier. The lack of any visible respite from the sun and heat heightens the desperation for hydration. The setting effected the cyclist by the rough roads, the cyclist having a hard time pedaling over the roads, his tires struggling for purchase. The snake, a venomous-looking viper, scared the cyclist on his ride through the "town," which was more of a desolate collection of buildings. The fact he was running out of water was compounded by the well water he found tasting like battery acid, making him even thirstier. The setting was very rough on the cyclist, turning what should have been a simple ride into a true ordeal.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him tired, scared, thirsty and cause him to worry. The setting was a hot California day in June and the cyclist was riding through the heat and over the hills and difficult terrain. The cyclist describes the land when he says, ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.î He also says, ìOver one long, crippling hill.î As the cyclist gets further and further, he has more doubt. Fear and thirst start to get to him. He says, ìIt didnít really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.î When the cyclist finds the bait shop he has almost lost all hope, feeling the arduousness of the ride. On his way to the shop he says, ìSlowly gaining elevation while losing hope.î At the end, the setting makes the cyclist regain his strength as he sees the bait shop; when he sees it, he says, ìThen, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst and fear were all behind me.î The features of the setting put the cyclist in an unsteady ride of fear, hope and confidence, showing how powerfully the environment can impact one's physical and mental state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by helping him get water for his thirst and getting back on the road to go wherever he is trying to go. But the only thing is that he didn't never say anything about getting his bait for the fish. Also, the cyclist was affected because he almost died from thirst and having no road, making the available water and path especially crucial for his survival and journey.
He raced, trying to get to Yosemite for some rushing river.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Having desert roads makes you want to just lay there and not try to go any further, because you don't know where the end will be, and the heat can be draining. As for grassy, flowery land, it gives more of a sense of route, and makes you want to keep going and see many things, inspiring exploration. Hills and varied terrain make it harder to keep going but present more of a challenge, and a good workout at the same time, pushing physical limits. Ultimately, the setting undoubtedly affects the cyclist's experience and motivation.

When the cyclist first receives directions to Yosemite Park from the "old timers" he met, he was pretty confident that they knew what they were talking about. To his dismay, these elderly men sent him through life-threatening conditions in a deserted area. As the cyclist begins his journey through the hot, June weather, he "rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face." As he continues forward, he notices that there are no buildings, cars, or people of any kind. He passes abandoned towns and creeps into the desert flat land, a stark contrast to his initial optimism. The flatland, however, morphs into crippling hills with tumbleweeds and snakes awaiting. Not only is the terrain suddenly different, but the cyclist is rapidly deteriorating. Tiredness and lack of water make the cyclist think "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean." It was amazing that through all this, the cyclist was able to reach a small fishing camp where he is quickly replenished. "Gary and Wilber's Fish Camp" saved the cyclist from almost certain death, teaching him to always just use his map, and to perhaps be more skeptical of folksy advice in the future.

In the essay ìRough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed posted Speed Limit.î The features of the area the cyclist rides through affect him greatly. For example when the narration says, ìAt some point, humble weeds crossed my pathî (Kurmaskie @NUM1), the cyclist's spirit seems low, perhaps symbolizing obstacles. The tone of the cyclist from the quote above shows despair creeping into his mind. Also, another good example is when the narration says, ì@CAPS1 hill, a building came into viewî (Kurmaskie @NUM1), suggesting progress and the possibility of reaching a destination. The cyclist sounds more hopeful than before. That is how the area the cyclist enters affects him, influencing his emotions and outlook during the journey.

The cyclist is affected by many features of the desert. The main feature is the heat. "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." He’s also running low on water, "The water bottles only contained a few tantalizing sips." He’s faced by extreme heat and lack of water. He wipes the sweat from his brow, feeling the grit of the desert on his skin. He’s tired and has a long way to go, the sun beating down relentlessly. So far, all of the towns have been deserted, amplifying his sense of isolation. Finally, he reaches a bait shop and thankfully refills his water and promised himself to stick to the map in the future, learning a valuable lesson about the desert's harsh realities.

In the essay the setting affects the cyclist in different ways. For example, the course must have been tough because he was dehydrated, suggesting high temperatures and lack of water sources, and it says that there are rolling hills and rough roads, contributing to physical exhaustion. Another example is there were dangerous animals like snakes that he came across, posing a direct threat to his safety and adding a layer of psychological stress. In conclusion, these are some reasons how the setting affects the cyclist.

The terrain described in this essay add affect to the strugles of the cyclist. Ultimately, the harsh environment amplifies the cyclist's ordeal and underscores the magnitude of his achievement.

The unforgiving environment thus presented a series of escalating challenges, hindering his progress and threatening his well-being.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead : Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. In conclusion, this is how the features of the setting affects the cyclist, pushing him to his physical and mental limits.

The features affect the cyclist in a big way. For one the heat beating down on him made him sweaty, hot and tired. Some of the things that affect the cyclist was the lack of water. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips; water is of big importance to sport men. Rolling hills, open terrain, and high deserts are all features of the setting that affect the cyclist. Lastly, high deserts would affect the cyclist because he has to pedal for miles on end in rough, dry terrain, putting strain on him overall and making hydration even more critical. Therefore, these environmental factors create a challenging landscape for the cyclist.

In the case of the cyclist in the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting has an enormous effect on the biker. Predominantly, the weather causes him to feel dehydrated. He says that he “had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly.” He tries to get water from the old well, demonstrating just how much he needed water. The water in this pump, the owner said, was, “somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” If the water has reached such a high temperature, the reader infers that it must be hot outside; the author implied this when he says it is California in June, it is a clear day, and the sun was beating down. Another aspect of the setting, the lane, dirty, “ghost town” infested land, had a large effect on the cyclist. As he begins to lose hope, he cannot see any signs of modern life; “there was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This empty land makes the cyclist himself feel empty. Most literally, the fact that the setting was unknown to the cyclist affected his confusion. He didn’t know the best path to his destination and therefore relied on others for aid, further emphasizing the impact of his unfamiliar surroundings. Because of this reliance, he ends up lost and alone, thus solidifying the setting's influence on his physical and mental state.

In the essay titled “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed the Speed Limit,” the setting changes, and so does the mood of the essay as well as the mood of the cyclist. For example, towards the beginning of the essay, at the reservoir, the essay states, “At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early summer evening.” This shows how, towards the beginning of the essay, the cyclist is happy, just woke up, and is getting ready to go on a nice bike ride; however, this all changes when he gets directions from a couple of “old-timers.” From that point on, his trip goes downhill, and the essay states, “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town,’ a ghost town.” “The sun was beginning to beat down.” This also shows that the setting of a ghost town and a setting with the sun beating down is affecting the mood of the essay and the mood of the cyclist, as well as when he goes another twenty miles to a different ghost town with only a few rusty water pumps containing acid-flavored water. At this point, the cyclist is very worried because it's hot and he has no water, while knowing he has another thirty miles to go. Thirty miles of rolling hills and hot sun, while seeing a “Rough Road Ahead” sign and a diamondback snake, he is sure he is going to die. However, it all changes when he sees a different sign, one for a bait shop. This clearly demonstrates how the author, Joe Kurmaskie, effectively utilizes the setting to influence and shape the overall mood and emotional tone of his narrative.

The dusty, dry setting has a serious effect on the cycling author. It got so long and hot that, “Ö@CAPS1 blues tune 'summer time' rattled around in my deteriorating brain.” The relentless heat, combined with the parched landscape, was clearly taking its toll, his thoughts becoming fragmented and repetitive. He has spent so long cycling through heat, his brains starting to shut down, a consequence of the grueling conditions. It's also because there is very little water left for him, exacerbating the physical and mental strain. Another problem is that every building/town except the last building is deserted, offering no respite or assistance. So without any chance of being refueled and restocked, it's the author v.s nature, a stark battle against the elements. Plus, as the author states, the directions came from old people who, “haven't left their porches since Carter was in office.” The world has greatly changed since then. Towns have become deserted, buildings rundown but the roads are kept in shape, a strange juxtaposition of decay and maintenance. The towns the old people mentions are now ghost towns, and are no help to the author, rendering their outdated guidance useless and highlighting the author's increasing isolation and vulnerability.

As the cyclist continues on his ride, changes begin to occur in the surroundings, which ultimately affects the cyclist’s attitude. When first starting out on his journey to Yosemite, the cyclist started out that morning, “with strong legs and a smile on my face.” He had received information from a few of the older locals that would help to cut the amount of time it took to arrive at Yosemite National Park. However, as he was riding, the cyclist realized that perhaps the older men’s travel advice was a little out dated, the once-smooth asphalt giving way to cracked and uneven surfaces. With barely any water left to hydrate himself, and being surrounded by nothing but more road and desert, the cyclist couldn’t help but laugh. “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” At this point, the cyclist was mad at himself for not just using the map that he had brought with him instead of listening to the locals. Although the cyclist remained determined to find water, he had begun to lose hope when he suddenly came across a bait store, a small oasis in the arid landscape. Here he was able to rehydrate himself with a cold bottle of water, and with his renewed spirit, continued on his journey, this time using his map and feeling more confident about reaching his destination.

The cyclist was riding on a rough, bumpy, dangerous road. He had to be on the look out for animals that might try and hurt or even kill him. Since he had no water he was dehydrating. Also, the road was hot and not very well taken care of; it took more energy to get through it. The sun beat down mercilessly, adding to his exhaustion as the uneven surface jarred his bones with each rotation of the pedals. His throat felt like sandpaper, and his vision started to blur. He knew he needed to find shade and water soon, or his ride could end tragically.
