Many things can effect a cyclist and how they ride, in this essay many things effected him such as the setting of the story. One of the problems of the setting was there were no stores or even people, another and most important thing was the lack of water around him. This isolation amplified the challenges he faced on his ride. So many things can effect a cyclist while they are riding inculding there suriondings, ultimately impacting their performance and endurance.

The second photograph better communicates ideas similar to the ideas expressed in the essay "A sea worry," because the story is about a boy who surfs as a job & in the second picture a boy is surfing. The author says "my son body-surfs. He says it’s his ‘job’." That quote was explaining that he’s a body-surfer & it’s his occupation. Therefore, the visual representation of a surfer in the second photograph directly aligns with the son's described activity and profession within the essay, making it the more suitable choice.

Condition the cyclist is in affect a lot of how they ride. One example of this is, ìI was travelling through the high desert of California in June.î Due to this fact the cyclist had went into a ìdehydrated stateî because of not having much water. When your travelling in hot weather areas without much water your body will become dehydrated from sweating. Cycling in different conditions will affect cyclists diffently, so preparation and awareness of environmental factors are essential for a safe and effective ride.

Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in ìRough Road Ahead.î First, the scorching heat of the desert in June was a major problem that had him to the brink of dehydration. The intense sun beat down relentlessly, sapping his strength. In the text it states, ìI could drop from heatstroke in a gorgeous day in June (@CAPS1).î This shows the effect the exposure to heat had on @NUM1 cyclist. Also, the terrain posed a threat to his well being during the story. The uneven and rocky ground made it difficult to maintain momentum. In the text it says ìI toiled on(@CAPS2).î This shows the increase in effort in strain the terrain caused on the cyclist during his adventure. Ultimately, the harsh environment significantly challenged the cyclist's endurance and ability to persevere.

In the story ìDo not Exceed Posted Speed limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. It being hot affected him because it made him more thirsty, and the relentless sun beat down, intensifying his dehydration. Then him being out in the middle of the desert made it so he couldnít get any water, with no signs of civilization or respite in sight. The hills made him tired and weak as he struggled against the inclines. All of the features in the setting had an affect on him, which made him powerless and thirsty, highlighting the harsh and unforgiving nature of his environment.

The features that effect the cyclist are that he is riding his bike in the desert and doesnt have any water. That effects his journey because he is dehydrated so he needs to find water fast so it is making him get to Yosemite slower because he needs to find water, impacting his speed and route. That is a feature that affects the cyclist, ultimately hindering his progress.

In the story the setting has a large affect on the cyclist. After taking advice from old people he ended up in the desert with no cars, buildings, or people. He was running low on water and had no way of getting anymore, and he was really dehydrated. Consequently, he got really tired and almost gave up because of the heat and lack of water. All this was caused by the harsh and unforgiving setting he was in, demonstrating the environment's powerful influence.

The setting of the place was “ghost town” as the author said. It was a hot summer day in June, the sun beating down mercilessly, so of course the cyclist would be dehydrating. There was no one around, the empty buildings and deserted streets amplifying his isolation, so he couldn’t ask for help. It was like an old town, a relic of a bygone era, because he ran into old men who seemed out of touch, lost in time, and they knew nothing of the new world because they told him the wrong directions. His hope for reaching his destination dwindled with each incorrect turn, emphasizing the disorienting effect of the ghost town.

The setting affected the cyclist in a few different ways. At first it helped him. ìThe sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed. The cool pines and rushing riversî This is saying the pines and rivers helped him forget the sun. Later on the setting was against him. There was no place to get water and he was becoming dehydrated as the day wore on and the terrain was getting rougher, making the ride more difficult. There were no people around to help him, but there was a snake slithering across the path, adding to his stress. All these features were working against him until he finally made it to a bait store, a welcome sight after the difficult journey. This bait store gave him water and a good map, turning his fortunes around and allowing him to continue his ride with renewed hope.

In the story Rough Road Ahead by Joe @PERSON1 it tells of a cyclist heading for Yosemite National Park, and the problems he faced. For example the heat was a major issue the cyclist had to face. In the story it said “Drop from heatstroke,” illustrating how the challenging environment negatively impacted him. Indeed, the intense heat was a major element of the setting that significantly affected the character's journey, highlighting the difficult conditions he had to overcome to reach his destination.

The features of the setting affected the authorís story a lot. It affected it by making the trip seem more difficult to the reader. This was made possible by telling how hot it was and explaining how the road was full of bumps or hills. The story says ìover one long, crippling hill.î This makes the reader think the trip is very hard since he has to ride up so many hills. But if the road wasnít as hilly then the trip would seem less difficult. This would also make it as if that the old guys gave good directions. But the whole point of the difficult setting is to show how arduous the journey was, influencing the reader's perception of the events.

As soon as the cyclist gained information about which way to go, he set off through tall, cool pines. They gave him a feeling of confidence, and physically cooled his body down. As he headed down the road, he encountered various small towns—none of which looked promising—which gave him a feeling of despair, in accordance to his lack of water. Even further into the journey, he found one last town, and a rundown welcheís factory. This increased his thirst and gave him a feeling of spite towards the old men who had given him advice. However, he soon found a bait house where he could get water and escape the heat. For this he was satisfied and grateful to the owner, solidifying his resolve to never again trust the old men.

The setting affects a lot in a cyclist. For example, if you are in a city, you feel rushed, tired, and overwhelmed. But in a forest, you are happy and a bit less stressed because of the calm and nature. A setting sets the mood and also the attitude in the story; it influences the cyclist's experience and therefore their perspective. Thus, the environment deeply shapes not only physical feelings but also emotions.

The features of the setting affect the author's disposition as well as his ability to complete the journey, thus creating an obstacle the author must overcome. At the end of paragraph five, the author writes that "I was traveling through the high deserts of California." This setting is important because it adds a sense of urgency to his trip when he starts to run low on water, making the journey more perilous. This is similar to when I was backpacking and a bear got most of our food; our normal backpacking trip had become more of a game of survival. So, the water issue was clearly the main point of conflict that the author presented in the setting. He also writes that "Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This aspect of the setting also affects the cyclist because it makes it much harder for him to progress than if it was a downhill road, impacting his stamina and speed. In short, the setting of the story presents the main points of conflict to the author and thus was essential to the essay.

In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the unbearable setting effects the cyclist with its harsh conditions. At first, in the cyclistís own words, ì things began well enough.î However, this soon changes. The road is long and filled with obstacles, like jagged rocks and relentless hills, and the cyclist has hardly any water to sip. He does not give up, though; in the text it says, ìgot back on the bike, but not bothered gathered up a few peldder and stuck them in my mouth.î He does this in order to reduce his need for water and continues, ignoring the toll the setting brings upon him, demonstrating a remarkable resilience in the face of adversity. This shows his determination to push forward despite the challenging environment.

The cyclist is affected by the setting in "Rough Road Ahead" because the road is a place, and if it is rough or unknown, it directly affects the traveler, who is the cyclist. If it is a hill, then the cyclist would have to climb it, expending more energy. In the text it said, "over a long crippling hill," the "crippling hill" part stresses that the setting is a hill, and the word "crippling" suggests the difficulty the cyclist faces due to the terrain. This demonstrates the setting's impact.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because there is no water, hills, and deserts. When the cyclist saw water, wanting to jump in, all he thought about was that the water they did have tasted like battery acid. Then the hills slowed him down, making it harder to reach any potential water source. The desert just amplified his thirst and made him want water even more intensely. These harsh environmental elements significantly impacted the cyclist's physical and mental state throughout his journey.

There were many features in the setting that affected the cyclist. One was the extreme heat during the June heat in California. The speaker said that he could have died from heatstroke. The rough road was also a problem for the cyclist. The bumps, hills and wildlife affected the cyclistís journey. The thing that most affected him was the lack of water. It was such a problem that he had to suck on stones to take his mind off thirst. As you can see, these problems in the story affected the speakerís journey to Yosemite National Park.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. He is riding in the desert where there is low to no rain. This means that he can’t collect any water to drink if he runs out. Also, deserts are hot, the sun beating down relentlessly. The heat will speed up the dehydration process so he will need more water to survive. If he runs out of water, he will die a slow, agonizing death. The cyclist finds a building, but it is abandoned and empty, offering no respite. All these features of the setting affect him. Since he can’t find water, he has to conserve what he has, rationing every drop. Also, the heat is killing him, sapping his strength. It doesn’t help to have an abandoned building be the only one he finds, a cruel reminder of his isolation. During the whole time that there is death in the air, the desert with nothing growing, no water, the cyclist is thinking about his death, his mind consumed by despair. As long as he thinks about his death, there is only more death, his hope dwindling with each passing moment. As soon as he puts the pebbles in his mouth to stop thinking about death and being thirsty, focusing on the physical sensation instead, he sees a bait shop which saves his life, a beacon of hope in the desolate landscape. He thought about surviving, and immediately found a shop to quench his thirst, proving the profound impact of mindset on his fate, highlighting how a shift in perspective turned his survival.

The setting affected the cyclist greatly throughout his ride. ìThe water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke (pG @NUM1 kurmaskie).î This quote is saying that because of the heat, the rough terrain and the length of his ìshortcutî his running out of water. Thatís when he realizes he could die from heatstroke because he listened to a bunch of old men. The harsh environment, combined with his dwindling supplies, underscored the severity of his situation and the potential consequences of his decision.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He is in the desert and has a low supply of water. Without water, he tires very easily. On top of that, he has to pedal a bicycle. So, he is thirsty and tired from being in the desert. This is how the setting affected the cyclist, creating a challenging and exhausting ordeal due to the harsh environment and limited resources.

Setting affects the cyclist. The cyclist has to worry about the road condition. If the road condition is bad then the cyclist must reduce his/her speed. The cyclist also has to worry about if it is day or night. If it is night, they must be careful due to cars not being able to see them, perhaps by using reflective gear or lights. In the text, the cyclist was in extremely hot weather. This is dangerous to cyclist if they are not prepared with things such as water, and could potentially lead to heatstroke. Therefore, awareness of the setting is crucial for a cyclist's safety.

The setting affects the cyclist because he believes that he has a nice, short, flat distance to travel to get to Yosemite, but instead, it is a long, hilly(rough), hot journey. He only prepared himself for a quick ride, bringing only enough water for that ride, and wasn't prepared for the reality of his ride. First of all, he is riding in the middle of the day (the hottest part) in the "high deserts of California in June." I know when I go to camp here in Lone Pine during the summer, I drink six to seven liters, but the author only mentions a "few bottles of water," which aren't going to help him in that heat. Secondly, the cyclist believed that the old men had given him a safe path to follow, but instead, he came across a "ridiculously large snake. It really looked like a diamond back." That is a poisonous snake, and the cyclist was barely able to "ease past" it because of his lack of water. Lastly, the cyclist expected the old men to give him an easy path on a flat terrain when, in fact, it was "replaced by short, rolling hills," which means you have to put more effort (using more water) to climb the hills. The setting definitely affects the cyclist because it makes it more difficult for him to reach his destination, but without a few bumps in the road, how is he to learn a life lesson?

The cyclist is affected by the features of the setting a lot. For example the dry hot place makes him thirsty. Then the ghost towns make it hard to get supplies. Also the bad road slowed him down. The bad roads even would probably hurt him and his bike; the roads also would make him work harder, expending more energy to navigate the uneven terrain and potential hazards. Therefore, the environment significantly impacts the cyclist's journey, influencing his physical state and the challenges he faces.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many bad ways. For example in the text it says how “I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state”. This shows the cyclist was struggling to navigate the terrain while also battling physical discomfort. Meaning that he had trouble being in a place he didn’t know well and he was dehydrated, making the ride more difficult. In conclusion the setting did affect the cyclist.

First the bike encounters flat roads in the desert which are very easy to navigate through; when he gets to his first town he still goes on trying to get to Yosemite, then after is going low so he looks for some more water to help him go. Then he kept going and he experienced a fork in the road. After the fork he kept going and he then faced another problem: an old person told him to go @NUM1 miles to the town and he didn’t trust the guy. The biker, after some hesitation, listened and he went on down the road. He then faced his next problem: the flat road started to get very wary with short high and low hills. These hills reduced his stamina greatly. Then he had to deal with a rocky and bumpy desert road. He then had to face a snake and he had to avoid it so it didn’t attack him. Finally the biker faced his last long hill and, thankfully, he found a bait and tackle shop with lots of water, enabling him to replenish his supplies and continue his journey.

In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the cyclist is affected by the features of the setting, exacerbating his discomfort. The cyclist is lost, has only found dirty water, and is moving on rough ground. The features of the setting are “cool pines and rushing rivers,” however, the cyclist comes to find that the “rushing river” is not so refreshing when he tries to drink it. He also encounters a terrain change, from flat road to short, rolling hills that make his journey harder. There is a sign, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” also the name of the passage with a limit of 55 mph, while the cyclist is only going 12 mph, further emphasizing his slow progress. Ironically, he finds a picture of a boy drinking grape juice at the factory, which causes him to hang his head in misery due to his intense thirst, highlighting his suffering. Finally, he comes to a fish camp, where he encounters the owner who, ironically, tells him he'd be better off using his map, underscoring the cyclist's misdirection and compounding his frustration. Thus, the environment serves to amplify the cyclist's negative experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is going to be on the road a long time. The features of no buildings, no people and no cars, affect on the rider is that he feels helpless when he is low on water because there is no one to ask for assistance. The ghost town doesn’t help him because the old man told him about it and he thought he would be able to get more water, but there was nothing there. The grape juice factory affected him because he thought he would get a drink but it was abandoned, crushing his hopes. These environmental factors combined to significantly impact the cyclist's journey, particularly as his resources dwindled and the promise of finding supplies proved false.

Features of the setting would affect me if I was the cyclist because, I would be thinking I was going to die just like he did because there is nothing to look at, no breeze, wind, he seen a snake, he had no water. He went through three towns that had nothing. The sun was setting down on him, it was hot, he had no hope left. The desolation of the landscape, the oppressive heat, and the lack of resources all contribute to a feeling of despair. Who knows, maybe if he would have just went with what the map had said, he would have been fine, ultimately highlighting how the environment's harshness, coupled with poor decisions, led to his predicament.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The cyclist is running out of water and is in the intense heat in the high deserts of California in June. The tumbleweeds that cross his path add to the desperation. Not only do the features of the setting affect the cyclist physically by dehydrating him in the heat, but also mentally. The sun beats down mercilessly, and the dry air saps his strength. The cyclist encounters rolling hills, tumbleweeds, rattlesnakes, and ghost towns. Each hill climbed feels like a monumental effort. The sight of abandoned buildings whispers of failure, and the threat of rattlesnakes keeps him on edge. All of these make the cyclist start to give up hope. In conclusion, the features of the setting affect the cyclist physically and mentally.

The features of the setting greatly impacted the cyclist. First the setting at the middle of the story was empty and no place to get water. This filled the cyclist with doubt and despair, he/she thought they would die from dehydration. The setting also made the cyclist thirsty because of the extreme heat radiating off the barren landscape. Finally the cyclist was filled with regret because they regretted listening to the old men; the cyclist didn’t make it where he/she wanted to go and was now stranded. Therefore, the environment played a critical role in shaping the cyclist's emotional and physical state, ultimately leading to feelings of remorse.

The author thinks that the desolate setting means he is not getting any closer to his destination. However, he found out that there were still people around. He panicked and thought he was going to die. The places were deserted and he thought the trails led nowhere. He was a little scared at the fact he might die because everything around him was in a sense dead, with the dry landscape and lack of any visible life contributing to the feeling of impending doom, solidifying the fear.

The setting really affected the cyclist. Since he was in the desert on a bike he was going to be hot and tired. Which would come from the sun coming down on him. He was hot where it said ìwide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt,î and the relentless sun beat down on his exposed skin. This really shows how the desert environment impacted his physical state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they are extreme and do not change. The cyclist was riding on a small road in the desert. In the desert it was very hot, the sun beating down relentlessly, and because of this the cyclist was sweating a lot and getting dehydrated. Also because he was in the desert, with its vast and featureless landscape, he had no sense of direction. Also the towns are all run down with nothing in them, so the cyclist couldn’t get any water to drink to rehydrate himself, the abandoned buildings offering no respite. Only when he comes to a small bait shop close by did he finally get water. Therefore, the unchanging and harsh desert environment is the key element affecting the cyclist's struggle.

The setting really affected the cyclist a lot. The sun and hot weather dehydrated him. He also had pretty much ran out of water. In the story he says, "The bottles contained only a few drops," this shows that he had drank almost all of his water. Then it says, "the growing realization that I could drop from a heat stroke" shows the heat was affecting him, pushing him to his physical limits and highlighting the challenging conditions he faced.

The setting was calm and peaceful as he started out riding his bike. He was smiling and his legs were strong. As he hit the @NUM1 town and saw a ramshackled shed, rusty pumps, and a corral, he begun to be troubled b/c he was running out of water. As the flat rodes were replaced wI short, rolling hills he became even more troubled. When he saw a building he became happy but when he found out it was run down he was sad, thirsty, and tired. When he finally saw an old man and told him he had a map he became a little happier b/c he was going to get to Yosemite. As the setting became worse his mood became worse b/c he had less and less water and felt very hopeless. But when he saw the man he became happy b/c the map was going to help him, giving him hope that he would make it to his destination after all.

The setting of this story is very rigorous. At the beginning of the story, the boy was fine. He had a bottle of water with him so that he didn't get dehydrated. When he was riding, he started to feel the sun get higher into the sky, though he could barely feel it because of the pines that shaded the road, and the cool feel of the river. The cyclist got to the second town on his journey and he had been drinking his water all day and was about out. He had found a water pump. He got down on his knees and pumped with all his might, but all that came out was brackish water. He just feared the water and stated that it tasted like battery acid. He began to ride again. Not two miles up the road, the terrain changed. Not only was it rolling hills, it was also getting hotter. He was majorly dehydrated because he was out of water except for a few tantalizing sips. Dry sweat circled his shirt and he was afraid he could suffer a heatstroke. Where he was at was in the middle of nowhere, with no buildings, cars, or structures in sight. Over one of the hills, he saw a building come into view. He wiped the sweat off his eyes to make sure it was not a mirage. By the looks of it, it had been a Welch's factory. He was so dehydrated and tired that he could see a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth. There is only one problem: it is abandoned. This person was imagining things. He got back on his bike and stuck pebbles into his mouth. This was to help take his mind off being thirsty. In this harsh environment, the cyclist's desperation underscores the power of thirst and the mind's capacity to conjure illusions when pushed to its limits.

I read ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî written by Joe Kurmaskie in the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist by accepting advice from ìold timers who havenít left the confines of their porches @CAPS1 was in officeî. The relentless sun beating down and the cracked, uneven asphalt present immediate physical challenges, while the locals' outdated counsel further hinders progress, creating a disconnect between the cyclist's expectations and the harsh realities of the road. Ultimately, the environment shapes the cyclist's experience, forcing adaptation and highlighting the contrast between perceived wisdom and practical application.

In the essay ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. First, the sun is making the cyclist hot and dehydrated. He states ìThe sun was beginning to beat down,î and as a result, the cyclist had to ration his water. Also, the hills of the country roads forced him to exert more energy. Going up and down hills take alot of work you have to use alot of energy. The cyclist says ìlong flat stretches were replaced by short, rolling hills.î These hills demanded more from him physically. Furthermore, there were snakes in the road, which make the cyclist timid looking out for snakes so he would not get bit. Againg the cyclist states ìa dimond back-blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me.î He was constantly on alert. Moreover, there was an old factory that gave the cyclist hope and then crushed his hopes. The factory even made him more thirsty. In conclusion, there were many affects on the cyclist due to the setting, creating a challenging and emotionally taxing ride.

The features of the setting take their toll on the unfortunate cyclist. For example, I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June. The deserts of California especially in June are hot and dry and caused the cyclist to use much of his water supply very quickly. As he "toiled" on, the terrain features became even more trying, over one long, crippling hill. By this time the cyclist barely had enough energy to make it over a hill from all the wear and tear his body was put through by the features of his setting, proving just how detrimental the environment can be.

The setting to this story has an encouraging impact on this story, because he is alike ride. The terrain in the story sounds rough where he seen a sign marked, ëRough road ahead do note exceed posted speed limit.î He already has to go up and down hills with rocks and no water. Such a setting and a really athletic ride can be devastating, but also makes the journey all the more rewarding as he overcomes each obstacle.

The feature of the cyclist and the settings aren't that good. There are incidents that are a problem. One is the bad weather. There is a temperature that makes it feel pretty close to 100 degrees. He stops at a water pump, water comes out but it is really not cool. He takes two little sips and it's like battery acid. If he were to drink a lot of that water it would probably kill him or make him very ill. He needs something because there was another town 20 miles down the road so he has to find something to keep him going. As he is going down the road he sees a sign: Rough Road Ahead. Even though he is going 12 mph he could still hit a hole and go flying over his handle bars. If he does go over his handle bars he could run into the snake he saw then get eaten by the birds because he wouldn't have any energy to get up. There are some interesting scenes in the story, but these issues detract from the overall experience.

Heat, water supply, energy-all are features of setting that can affect a cyclist. First, is heat. When it is too warm out it makes it more difficult, and more inconvenient to ride. Second, is your water supply. If you are riding, and begin to run low on water, you're in trouble. The author describes, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips”. If you aren't prepared enough for your cycling journey, it will be extremely inconvenient when you run out of supplies. Planning your water stops or carrying enough hydration is essential. Lastly, is energy. If you run out of energy while cycling, you have nothing. Your energy is what keeps you moving and motivated. “With what I believe, was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill,” the author describes. Proper nutrition and pacing are crucial for maintaining stamina. When you are out of energy, your ride is over. All of these aspects are important to have before deciding to go on a cycling journey, highlighting the need to consider environmental factors and personal preparedness for a successful and safe cycling experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by dehydrating him due to the heat and lack of water, causing him to see mirages. He loses strength going over the many hills, which sap his energy. And there is a very large snake he has to ride by that could have bitten him, posing a significant threat. These environmental challenges greatly impact the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when you have hills to climb and little water, you will get dehydrated, impacting performance. Also the heat from the desert is so hot that it also can make you dehydrated, causing fatigue and potential heatstroke. If you don’t pace yourself and don't drink enough water, rationing it strategically, you will be less likely to reach your goal. Your rest is a big thing for if you don't have energy, you will not get far, as muscle recovery and alertness are crucial for navigating the challenging terrain and extreme conditions, ultimately hindering your success.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the hills made it hard for him to ride his bike up and he was breathing heavily as he pedaled. He was also afraid of the grass because it was tall and scary looking, making him think something might be hiding in it. These environmental factors influenced his ride.

In the story ìDo not exceed Posted Speed limitî a cyclist takes a journey through terrain to get to Yosemite. In that part of California there are not a lot of towns or people. The road he is riding on is very dangerous and long. It is very dry and hot out there, but he presses onward despite the harsh conditions.

The setting can affect a cyclist in a lot of ways. One way setting affects cyclist is when it is hot, it is harder to cycle long distances. I say this because in the story the narrator says “and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke…” This illustrates how the environmental conditions, particularly high temperatures, can pose a significant threat to a cyclist's physical well-being and endurance. Another part of setting that affects cyclist is the terrain they cycle on. For example it is much easy to cycle on flat smooth ground than it is on the rolling hills with rough, rocky ground. This is shown with the quote “ride down into distances I could see over the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” The challenging terrain influences the cyclist's mental state and the goals they set for themselves. Setting can have a great deal of affect on a cyclist, depending on if its smooth or rocky, or hot or cool.

In Joe Kurmaskieís ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed the Speed Limitî the features of the setting affects the cyclist a great deal. Each feature causing the cyclist to act. For example, in reaching the ëramshackle shedí the cyclist finds the water unusable; which causes him to conserve water and try to head for the next town. That action leads him deeper into the high deserts of California during June. Also as the terrain changes from flat road to short, rolling hills the cyclist must change his speed to better survive and continue in his dehydrated state. He downshifts, expending more energy to conquer the inclines, knowing the descents offer little respite in his weakened condition. The scarcity of buildings in this dry desert terrain causes the cyclist to try every ëshack or building he comes across for water. He risks time and energy hoping for a resupply. In this story the features of the setting dictates the actions of the cyclist in his quest to survive in the desert a lot.

The cyclist in the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî is about a great adventure gone bad. He has every thing he needs but some how it turns out bad. He get low on water & the setting is horrible. He is on his way from a camp ground in Bridgeport, California to the Yosemite river. He gets bad directions from old guys at the camps ground. On his way he ran into two abandon towns & was running out of water then he came to a sign that said, ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.î He was pedeling over hills & becoming dehydrated when he tought he was going to die he came to a bait shop & got waiter & met an old guy who was going to give him direction & he decided he better stick to the map. Even though the setting got worse through the story & stuck it out & made it to the end, ultimately demonstrating resilience in the face of adversity.

Heat, hills and ghost towns ñ all are features of setting that affect the cyclist. First, the oppressive heat dehydrates and exhausts him, almost causing him a heat stroke. He starts drinking more often, desperately trying to replenish his fluids, and nearly runs out of water. Next are the relentless hills. They can take massive amounts of energy to climb, forcing him to strain every muscle in his legs. Which adds to his dehydration, making each upward push a monumental effort. Finally, the desolate ghost towns. They make his journey seem hopeless, amplifying his feelings of isolation and fatigue. Which could cause him to lose the will to carry on, questioning whether reaching his destination is even possible. These combined elements of the environment present formidable obstacles.

The cyclist is in the desert which @NUM1 degrees with water that tastes like battery acid. The relentless sun beats down, blurring the already hazy horizon. The desert makes him see the mirages, shimmering pools that vanish upon approach, the cruel tricks of heat and exhaustion. Sweat stings, finding its way into his eyes, momentarily blinding him with a salty film.

In the story, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the author tells a story about when he took advice from “old folks” and became lost. The setting greatly affected him and his journey, for example “tumbleweeds crossed my path, and a ridiculously large snake…” and a “crippling hill.” These quotes explain that the setting was quite desolate and, at times, scary, contributing to the feeling of isolation and uncertainty that the author experienced as he strayed further from the familiar highway. The unfamiliar landscape served as a constant reminder of his misjudgment.

He’s in a very hot climate, in a desert, so he needs lots of water, but he has a limited supply. The sun beats down mercilessly, baking the sand and reflecting heat back up. He's riding on hills, which makes it even harder, each incline a draining effort under the scorching sun. He can’t find any towns that aren’t abandoned, their empty buildings standing as silent testaments to the harshness of the land, offering no respite or chance to replenish his dwindling water. Therefore, his situation is becoming increasingly precarious.

In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way it affected him was time because of the rough road he had to go slower so it took him longer to get to the town. Also because the road was harder to peddle on he got thirsty and the water from his bottle was really hot from the sun beating down on it. Ultimately, the harsh environment posed challenges for the cyclist, influencing his journey and comfort.

There were several features of the setting that held an affect on the cyclist in this story. For one, the cyclist was riding in a hot desert. This condition normally prevents one from obtaining water. Seeing as how water was a necessity for the cyclist, the lack there at due to the desert created the conflict of dehydration. Additionally, the town that was abandoned triggered a spark of doubt in the cyclist’s mind. The cyclist now had to ride with his brain in doubt and his body in desperate hope. By the time he/she reaches the old factory, the cyclist is extremely dehydrated, his lips cracked and vision blurring. Now his head is screaming with annoyance and his body is screaming with lack of water. This abandoned juice factory almost completely wiped out the cyclist hope. A man is little to nothing without hope. Therefore, this abandoned factory had a negative affect on him. Now, the only reason he continues is out of his/her desperation of survival, an instinct in all of us. In conclusion, the desert removed water and the abandoned homes and factory removed hope and all three created a negative affect, making the journey a true test of endurance. The cyclist is lucky to have survived.

The setting affected the cyclist, because he didn’t know if he was going to die or live. He had used up all his water because it was so hot and his mouth was dry. The sun beat down mercilessly on the barren landscape, creating a shimmering haze on the road ahead, further intensifying his anxiety.

In the short story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, he shows features of the setting played that affects the cyclist in many different ways. A setting the cyclist faces is that its so hot he keeps drinking water, and worrying that he is going to run out. Kurmaskie writes, ì I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in 1984). He even mentions the sun beating down, further emphasizing the oppressive heat. This is what the cyclist gets affected by throughout the whole story as he realizes he could die of heatstroke if he doesn't watch how much water he's drinking. Also, this is what a lot of people normally face which is a challenge cause of dehydration, revealing how the harsh environment presents a tangible threat and underscores the cyclist's vulnerability. The constant need for hydration becomes a central conflict, shaping his decisions and highlighting the precariousness of his journey through the scorching desert.

With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid place, things change. A better piece of advice for the solo cyclist? Never take travel advice from old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches. The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. Rough road ahead. Do not exceed the posted speed limit. Essentially, adapt to the present conditions and heed immediate warnings rather than relying on outdated perspectives.

Many things about the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist. The terrain in this story is hilly and filled with deserts. This contributes to the cyclist’s nagging sensation for a drink of water, as the arid climate exacerbates his thirst. The ride on the hills and through the desert also tire him out dramatically. Not to mention while he is severely dehydrated, and when he finds the water it is “tarlike” and “in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” The cyclist in this story really must want to get Yosemite National park if he is willing to go through all this trouble. The old men he asked in Lodi, California hadn’t left the town in decades and gave the cyclist faulty directions that could have killed him. So he asked for directions and was given inadequate information, which made life very difficult for the cyclist, ultimately emphasizing the challenging and unforgiving nature of his journey.

The setting of ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î affect the cyclist so many ways. First of all, the cyclist is riding in a desert, in mid- June, with the heat ìbeginning to beat downî on him. This feature of the setting causes the cyclist to drink more water, but when his supply of water was running low, he was unable to drink much water to hydrate himself, leading to discomfort. The cyclist began to realize that he ìcould trap from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.î Moreover, the long distance and changes in the terrain that the cyclist was travelling, affected him. The distance on which to cyclist was travelling to Yosemite National Park, consisted of hours and miles of riding, testing his endurance. Over vast changes of terrain. The ìflat road was replaced by short, rolling hillsî, which affected the cyclist speed and energy to finish his trip, making the journey more physically demanding. Thus, the harsh environment and challenging landscape significantly impacted the cyclist's experience, influencing his hydration, physical exertion, and overall sense of vulnerability.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making him go the wrong direction, influenced by an old man. One crucial feature was the tough, ghost-town-like environment. The features of the setting will affect the cyclist because the roads are hilly, and he is old, so it will be hard for him to ride up them. When he did try to get some water, the weather was so hot that the water from the pump came out hot, offering no relief. Well some features of the setting like the hotness is effecting the cyclist, for example he was riding through the high deserts of California and was drinking too much of his water. In the essay ìRough Road Aheadî by Joe Kurmaskie he accepts directions from old men for a shortcut to Yosemite National Park. The setting affects the cyclist by it being so hot, him not having anything to drink, nowhere to get water or food and him maybe seeing mirages. In “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist because he was thirsty and he thought he was going to die. The features of the setting have a big impact on the cyclist. One feature is the hot weather and area he is in. Nature has an affect on everyone, even when they don’t think it does. Especially for cyclists traveling anywhere or everywhere. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. First, the town the cyclist first comes upon is described as a ghost town. He really had to push himself to trudge up and down each hill, battling fatigue. His determination finally led him to, "Gary and Wilber's Fish camp…" (pg @NUM2). He finally found hope, signaling a potential respite from the arduous journey and a chance to recover. Thus, the challenging terrain and initial desolation significantly impacted the cyclist's physical and mental state, making the discovery of the fish camp a crucial turning point.

In the story "Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the ride had a largely negative effect on the cyclist. All these points demonstrate the detrimental impact the challenging environment had on the cyclist's overall experience.

The desert-like land affected the cyclist by making him tired and causing loss of body water, therefore making him need water to go on. The features of the bike ride to Yosemite through California in June affect the cyclist. Some of the features were it was hot high deserts, and no water. In the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî there are many features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. Many of these features affect him in a negative way. Many features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, the heat was the main part of nature that threw him off. The setting effects the cyclist in many ways, first is that it is very hot in the desert, which can lead to dehydration and exhaustion. The setting affects the cyclist in almost everything he does and everything he faces. The setting is a hot day in June in the desert. There are many hills and the terrain changes a few times. And because this caused him to become hot and tired he also drank his water more quickly than if he was pedaling on a flat paved road in a cool day. The features of the setting in the story affect the cyclist by describing that he is in a desert-like area in Lodi, California. They say it is very hot and there is sand everywhere. The features of the setting that affect the cyclist are the terrain, the lack of provisions and the power of self-determination. The terrain affected the cyclist by having he/she ride through rough paths in order to reach their destination; steep inclines, uneven surfaces and strong headwinds could all impede their progress. For example, if you walk on sharp rocks, you are bound to reach some rough spots where it seems you can’t walk. But that is where self-determination kicks in. The power to keep yourself moving even though there might be obstacles in your way; you know there will be a better path or a reward at the end. Another example of a feature is a lack of provision on your trip; without adequate food and water, the cyclist’s physical strength and mental focus would diminish. When you don’t have the right provision to keep yourself energised you can’t get over your obstacles or even push yourself to do anything. This interplay between external challenges and internal resolve demonstrates how significantly the features of the setting affect the cyclist.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the terrain has a negative effect on the author. He claims that “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie). This shows that he had been drinking his water too fast due to the heat from being in the desert at summertime. This rapid water consumption highlights the immediate physical demands the landscape imposes. After travelling for a long time with no water, he lets out a chuckle thinking of how he shouldn’t have taken the old men's advice. He explains that “It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.” This is an example of how badly the terrain had affected him. It's gotten to him so much that he applauds himself for having the energy to feel sorry for himself, demonstrating the psychological toll of the harsh environment. Ultimately, the terrain's impact is evident in both his physical struggles with dehydration and his mental state, reduced to finding solace in self-pity.

First of all he is travelling through a desert in California in June so the weather is extremely hot, reaching scorching temperatures, and the cyclist needs water. It frustrates him that when he finds water, not only is it hot but it tastes like battery acid, a metallic tang clinging to his tongue. When the cyclist decides to conserve some of his water and go to the next town to get more water, there is another setback. The condition of the road is so poor, riddled with potholes and loose gravel, that the cyclist cannot go more that 12 mph. Thus, if he ever reaches the next town, he still will have to wait longer for the much needed water, travelling at 12 mph under the relentless sun. The snake, a sidewinder slithering across his path, is also another setback that the cyclist was fortunately able to escape, swerving just in time. Thus his major concern is the lack of water, a constant, gnawing anxiety that overshadows everything else.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. At first, it was a bright, shiny day, the sun glinting off his bike, and the cyclist was happy, feeling the wind on his face. He reaches the first town, which is a ghost town, with empty buildings and silent streets, and it makes him sad, a sense of loneliness washing over him. Riding on, he begins to lose water, his throat growing parched. The once bright, shiny day began to beat the heat down on the cyclist, the sun's rays now oppressive. He reached a ramshackle shed, offering little shade, and began to lose hope, feeling the exhaustion set in. He loses water quickly and becomes more dehydrated, his muscles starting to ache. The terrain becomes slopes and hills, testing his endurance, and the ride becomes harder, each push of the pedal a struggle, when he reached the grape drink factory his hopes were almost gone, the sweet, artificial scent a cruel reminder of his thirst. But just over the hill was a fishing shop, a beacon in the desolate landscape. He used his remaining energy to speed down the hill, the promise of water fueling him, to get water and get his energy back, the setting ultimately offering a chance at survival.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, when it says, "The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them," the features of this setting are making the cyclist determined to explore and conquer the landscape. Another example is when it says, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake – it really did look like a diamondback blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me," the challenging features of the setting are making him brave and courageous as he faces unexpected obstacles. The last example is when it says, "I hung my head," implying a difficult or disheartening environment. The features of this setting are making the cyclist have despair, perhaps due to exhaustion or setbacks encountered along the way. That is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist's emotions and resolve throughout the journey.

In the essay “Rough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is affected both positively and negatively by the setting. Setting is the surrounding in which the story takes place. In the story, a cyclist loses his way and is put in danger because of it. The setting of the story can be described as mountainous with many rolling hills. The author describes the setting by saying, “two miles into the next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing.” The change in terrain made it more difficult for the cyclist. However, he also used the land to give him hope that he was almost there. He told himself that he’d make it if he made it over the next hill. The setting of the story gave the cyclist both hope and problems in his journey to survive.

The cyclist was affected by the fact that he took advice from some old men whose information was not accurate. Then he cycled along the desert which was very hot, the sun beating down mercilessly. He had a limited supply of water and that also affected him in a very bad way, each sip carefully rationed. He almost had a heat stroke a few times, his vision blurring and head pounding. He was probably angry that he took these men’s advice and got himself into this predicament. Then when he finally found the fish camp, he was overjoyed with relief, a wave of gratitude washing over him. But at the same time, if he had asked someone else for directions, he would not have been in this situation in the first place. So it’s really confusing because he probably felt relieved and mad at the same time, a mix of emotions swirling within him. And then the other old man asked him did he know the best way there. He was right to say yes because if he didn’t, the old man would have gave him some more messed up direction and he would have been out there again, about to have another heat stroke, thus making his agreement a necessary act of self-preservation.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by rush he /she got when speeding down the hill. The fresh morning air fills their lungs, no limits just you and your feet pushing the pedals. Speeding, going as fast as you can with your heart pounding in your chest and the wind whipping past. No boundarys, when you can go where you like, when you like, exploring hidden paths. No people to get in the way of you and your need for speed, just the open road and the thrill of the ride. This freedom and exhilaration are deeply connected to the setting.

In the short story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the setting profoundly affects the cyclist's journey, both mentally and physically. Unaware of his exact location, the cyclist's experience is shaped by the environments he encounters. The old towns and desolate desert landscapes he passes through begin to take a toll, leading him to remark, "The sight was troubling." As he continues toward California in the June heat, the arduous journey intensifies its grip on him. The heat and lack of resources contribute to his growing despair. For example, he says, "I got down my hands and knew working the hands of the rusted water pump with all my strength." This illustrates his weakening state and desperation for water in the barren landscape. Despite his initial determination, the unforgiving setting gradually chips away at his hope, contributing to his growing sense of self-pity. Ultimately, the setting plays a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's internal and external struggles throughout his journey.

Directions from well-meaning but misguided older people in June, and a lack of water all impacted the rider on his journey. The older people's promised shortcut proved incorrect, leading him astray. It was June in California, so the heat would have been intense and draining. He had already consumed most of his water. Without finding another water source, he faced a life-threatening situation. These factors significantly influenced the rider's experience and well-being on his trip.

The features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The features in the story changed the speaker’s mood throughout his journey. For example, in the beginning, he came across a deserted town, adding to his sense of isolation, so he was cautious. Next, he came across a fork in the road, symbolizing uncertainty, which was troubling to him. Then he passed a snake, heightening his anxiety, and had the obstacles of the hills, testing his endurance, which made him become determined. Finally, his determination changed to relief when he reached Gary and Wilber’s fish camp, a sign of civilization and the end of his arduous ride. In conclusion, the setting in the story greatly affects the cyclist by changing his moods and attitude towards his journey, shaping his experience from apprehension to eventual relief.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed Limit,” is about a man that follows some bad directions and in the middle of a desert is stuck without water. He starts to lack confidence in the directions when the setting changes. He said, “After fourty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first town it fit the traditional definition of ghost town.” He had been told this was a thriving town but was left with nothing. This was a big let down and the cyclist wasn’t so positive this had been the right choice. He keeps on riding and finds another dissetling sight. “One ramshacle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that wouldn’t hold in the lamest of mule greeted me.” @CAPS1 was another place said to be good but all he got was battery flavored water, a taste that did nothing to quench his thirst. On the last strech of his bike met with rough rolling hills, a diamondback looking snake slithering across his path, and an abandoned juice factory that offered no refreshment. All of this brang his spirits lower and lower until he thought he would die out there, alone and dehydrated. The cyclist ended up finding a store, a beacon of hope in the desolate landscape, but he was discauraged by the environment he was in, a hot and could have died if he had not found it. The journey, fraught with disappointment and the constant threat of dehydration, left him shaken, a stark reminder of the perils of blindly trusting directions in the face of a harsh environment.

In the essay, the cyclist is greatly affected by the features of the setting. Under the conditions he could barely survive and make it to his destination. The relentless heat and barren landscape are clearly taking their toll. It is clear that the features of the setting are affecting him when he states, “The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can be so cruel.” In his efforts he is slowly getting weaker, and the sign he sees only makes him feel worse because it seems to him that it mocking him with unattainable speed. He also states, “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you had left to circulate. With any luck I’d hit a bump and ledge one in my throat.” This shows he is ready to give up completely and wouldn’t care if he died, highlighting the despair the environment has instilled. From the author’s tone, it is clear that the features of the setting do affect the cyclist, pushing him to the brink of physical and mental collapse.

Features of the setting such as the hot sun, no water, and ìGary and Wilberís Fish Camp,î greatly affected the cyclist. The relentless heat bore down on him, making each pedal stroke a monumental effort. Also, the fact that the only water around felt ìsomewhere in the neighborhood of two-hundred degreesî and ìhad the flavor of battery acidî prevented the cyclist from drinking it and put him in a ìdehydrated state.î This lack of potable water further exacerbated his already precarious situation in the harsh environment. ìGary and Wilberís Fish Campî affected the cyclist by solving his problem of dehydration, since there was cold water available for him upon arrival. Therefore, the environmental conditions of the desert significantly challenged the cyclist, while the Fish Camp ultimately provided much-needed relief.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. In the passage, the features of the setting affect the cyclist because every time he comes along something different a new idea about his survival comes into his head. In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting had a major impact on the character. The cyclist is beginning at what seems a fine idea and place, the sun glinting off the fresh asphalt. Then the conditions become hot, dreadful, and maybe sticky with melting tar. The features of the setting in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist in many ways. The first of which would definitely be the lack of water the cyclist had, and the fact that there wasn’t anywhere around for miles to resupply. From the text it read “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This evidence from the text proves to the reader that the cyclist was getting worried, and emphasizes his isolation. Another part of the setting would be the obvious element of temperature. The cyclist is out in the hot, relentless desert. “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The author here, by using the elements of nature, is trying to make the reader concerned/scared for the main character, illustrating the very real danger he faces. The final key element was the distance he had to travel and the road conditions. Although the desert is generally flat, he began to notice some hills in the road; such a long distance, including the heat and inclines, could be deadly. The setting’s elements greatly affect the cyclist in this story.

The cyclist of “Do not exceed posted speed limit” was greatly affected by the setting of his bike ride, which caused him pain and displeasure. The lone biker in ìRough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limitî by @PERSON1 is strongly affected by the features of the landscape. The setting affected the cyclist by the people from Lodi getting him going the wrong way, and he had to survive from there. It was very dry, with no water or anything until the next stop was the bait store, so he was determined to get to that next destination, even though he did want to give up. But then a guy asked him if he wanted directions, and he said he was not going to be fooled twice, distrustful after his earlier misdirection.

It can’t be known as, "easy" to ride through a desert on a bike. Adding rough pavement, rusty water pumps, and not so friendly animals adds to the discomfort as well. The cyclist in this story encountered all these things, making his supposedly pleasurable ride turn to a semi brutal experience. “it got down on my hands and knee, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. Alike substance ooed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees,” This quote shows how the conditions of his water supply where, which eventually lead him to dehydration. It lead: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED SPEED LIMIT.” This quote also shows how the riding conditions were making the cyclist have a harder time keeping speed. “at some point tumberweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake-it really did look like a diamond back-beaked the majority of the pavement in front of me.” Moreover, this quote show of some of the dangers the cyclist encountered. If these features did not appear, then maybe the story would be describing a nice bike ride, but once you read about them, it becomes more of a disaster.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. It was so hot where he was that he kept drinking his water without realizing it until he only had a couple of sips left. The terrain also made him thirsty because the more he had to go up and down hills, the more he would drink. The fact that he did not see any town except a ghost town for miles affected him because he did not think he was going to make it to the next town. The oppressive heat, combined with the arduous landscape and isolation, significantly impacted his morale and physical state. The setting played a major role on the cyclist because it affected him that much.

Setting plays a big role in this story. Without being in the desert in the hot summer there would not be a conflict. There would be no importance in saving the water so he would not dehydrate. And the long flat roads are a symbol that the journey has still got a far way to go, but as straight roads turn into hills it shows that there is a change in the journey and something better is about to happen, signifying a shift in circumstances and offering a glimmer of hope for a more positive outcome.

The setting affect is used to a great extent in the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The cyclist had been going for a very long time when he came to the first town, and there was no water. At this point, you can tell that he has lost confidence in the “old timers'” directions. From this quote, “a ton-like substance oozed out,” this shows how, after 80 miles of pedaling, when he was supposed to have come to two towns by that point, his one chance of water had been depleted. The next time the setting affect is used is when he comes to a building that was rusted out. He said, “I hung my head.” This shows how he almost completely lost all hope and that he was sure that he was going to die, highlighting the setting's impact on his emotional state and diminishing chances of survival.

The cyclist is affected by a couple different things. First, he is given directions that are out of date, causing him to lose valuable time and energy, and then he has to deal with the intense heat of the weather in the early summer of California. If that wasn't enough, he then runs out of water, which he needs very badly to combat the dehydration. He runs into a couple more problems, like startling a big snake sunning itself on the road and coming to a factory that used to make juice, a place he thought might offer respite, but it was now run down and empty, offering no help. After all of these obstacles, the cyclist pulls through, demonstrating resilience, and makes it to a fishing store, where he finally gets water and replenishes his depleted supplies, resolving his immediate crisis.

During the cyclist's biking adventure he encounters several interesting situations. Each experience is in response to the setting in which it takes place. For example, this young man starts out confident with a bright hope of eventually reaching Yosemite National Park. The first spot he comes to is a ghost town. This sight doesn't immediately affect him, however it greatly adds on to the long term effects. He decides to continue on his trek, reaching the next ghost town; at this time he is becoming dehydrated due to his lack of water supply. He decides to keep pursuing his goal and figures there must be water up ahead in the next town. In order to get to the next town he must encounter some precarious situations, including some changes in terrain, such as steep inclines and rocky paths. Eventually, after reaching a source of running water, he is overjoyed with happiness and relief. As evident in the provided text, this man was affected by each feature of the setting. The different settings greatly affected his nature of confidence, slowly chipping away at it until the discovery of water renewed his spirits.

The setting effects the rider because if itís hot you get thirsty and you have no water. This kind of question is hard to answer because the environment significantly impacts the rider; for instance, intense heat can lead to dehydration if the rider lacks sufficient water. Therefore, understanding the setting is crucial for addressing the challenges the rider faces.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making the journey more dangerous and difficult. For example, in the reading it states that ridiculously large, poisonous diamondback snakes blocked the majority of the pavement. So, the cyclist had to keep his/her balance to ease past them, a precarious situation demanding focus and control. The terrain also changed into short, rolling hills, making it even more difficult to maintain speed and requiring greater physical exertion. These environmental challenges combined to significantly increase the overall difficulty and danger faced by the cyclist.

The features in the setting of the essay affect the author in one major way, dehydration. There are several features that cause the author to dehydrate. First off, he is riding through a desert located in California. This means that there is intense heat from the sun constantly beating down on him. Also the change from “flat road,” (Kurmaskie) to “short, rolling hills” also affected him, getting dehydrated. This change caused him to use more energy to climb up the hills which means he used more water because he got thirstier faster; he was exerting himself more in the heat. All of these elements combined to create a situation where the author was losing fluids rapidly, emphasizing how the harsh environment contributed directly to his dehydration.

The features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist. For example, the tough terrain made it very difficult for the cyclist to reach his destination, Yosemite. He was already very fatigued but had to overcome hills. In the essay, he states, “I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." These hills sapped his energy and slowed his progress. The setting features also affected the cyclist when he encountered the snake. He was dehydrated and could barely navigate around the dangerous snake. The cyclist explains, “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake, it really did look like a diamondback-blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased fast, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." The heat likely contributed to his dehydration, making the encounter even more perilous. The setting also affected the cyclist because there was no one around him to help. The cyclist describes, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The cyclist was all alone and had to rely on himself to make it to Yosemite. In conclusion, the features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist. He had to overcome rugged terrain without energy, avoid a diamondback snake, and make it all the way to Yosemite because there was no one around to offer assistance, highlighting the profound impact of the environment on his journey. As you can see, the features of the setting affect the cyclist.

The harsh features of the land around the cyclist caused him to confront nature. When he began his trip with advice from ìold coggersî he ìrode out with strong legs and a smile.î As he came to the first town, he describes it as a ìghost townî having no water and no human contact for some time. This should have been his cue to stop and turn around in hopes of another route to Yosemite. But with strong determination, he rode on. Through the miles he encountered a ramshackle shed, rusty pumps that offered no respite, snakes slithering across his path, and the wicked terrain. The short rolling hills tested his ìinner spiritî and caused his dehydration to further worsen. The land around the cyclist not only victimized his health but also caused a poor way to spend a vacation, turning what should have been a pleasant journey into a grueling ordeal.

The harsh features at the setting affect the cyclist by hindering his journey to Yosemite National Park. As the cyclist is traveling along ìThe high deserts of California in Juneî, some problems arise. The heat from the pounding sun in the desert takes a toll on the cyclist, causing him to drink more water and rapidly deplete his supply. This makes the journey more arduous, as the cyclist must constantly be aware of his hydration levels. The cyclist is also traveling through small ìghost townsî rather than stopping at appropriate rest stops in order to refill with water and relax. This lack of proper rest exacerbates the physical strain. Also while traveling he encounters hazards such as ìshort rolling hillsî through the terrain and even a snake. These unexpected obstacles further deplete his energy and increase the risk of injury. All of these features in the setting impair the cyclist's ability to maintain confidence in whether he will make it to his destination and his positive attitude toward the journey, making the already challenging ride even more mentally taxing. Ultimately, these environmental and situational factors conspire to create a significantly more difficult and uncertain path for the cyclist reaching Yosemite.

Cycling is a very good sport; people who do cycling are in shape. Also, they have strong calve muscles. I think it's also dangerous as well, since cyclists share roads with cars and trucks. Ultimately, the benefits and risks should be weighed carefully before engaging in this activity.

In the story the author says, ìThe sun was beginning to beat down trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state,î This gives you the idea that the heat is getting to him and is steadily depleting his water supply. He is physically struggling, and the sun is contributing to his weakening condition. At one point he almost gives himself up to despair and dies of dehydration. It seems that he will never reach his goal and he will continue to suffer in the grueling heat. I could almost feel the sweat and heat that the cyclist was feeling. Also, I could almost feel the lump in my throat when he says, ìwith any luck Iíd hit a bump and lodge a pebble in my throat.î This illustrates the depth of his desperation and the lengths his mind is going to for relief. The heat definitely affects this man's cycling in a bad way. He was exhausted and could not go on without water, and the oppressive heat was a major factor in his near defeat.
The cyclist thought it was hard, the steep incline burning his thighs. Also he was upset that the old timers gave bad directions, leading him further astray on the already challenging route.

The setting affects the cyclist in many ways. First, he couldn't get water from anywhere because he was in a desert with nothing but ramshackle sheds and rusty camps, offering no respite or resources. Second, there were short rolling hills and rough roads which made it hard to ride on, constantly challenging his stamina and control. There were tumbleweeds in his way and large poison snakes, adding danger and obstacles to his path. The heat made it hard to keep riding, sapping his strength with each passing mile. And there were no buildings, structures, or people around to give him a lift or water, leaving him utterly isolated. That is how the harsh desert setting profoundly affects the cyclist, hindering his progress and threatening his well-being at every turn.

In this essay by Joe Kurmaskie, a young man is baited into accepting outdated information by a group of old men. He pays for it later when on his bicycle, he is almost killed by heatstroke or dehydration. The setting is an excellent way to portray his feelings of hopelessness, despair, and fatigue. While he is just starting out, the road is flat and easy. It is cool and breezy, reflecting his initial confidence. When he begins to run out of water, the terrain becomes bumpier and harder, mirroring his increasing struggle. He sees empty plains, cracked, dry ground, and the hot sun, intensifying his feelings of isolation and desperation. He begins to despair even more. After a while when he thinks he can go no more he sees a store that once held gallons of grape juice. He laughs at the irony, a bitter acknowledgment of his predicament. The setting does do a wonderful job of describing his sense of helplessness, underscoring the harsh reality of his situation and the consequences of the old men's misleading advice.

In this passage, the cyclist was affected by the setting because if it had been anywhere else, he would not have suffered or learned at all. Because the setting had both a lack of civilization and water that he needed, that caused him to almost faint of thirst. This is an example of the setting affecting the cyclist. "With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill." This shows that had the setting been paradise, he would never have learned anything about his own resilience.

The features of the setting in the essay caused the cyclist to suffer and continue being determined. The author of the essay used phrases such as ëthe sun was beating downî and ìhigh deserts of California in Juneî to emphasize the extreme heat that caused the cyclist extreme thirst and heat exhaustion. The essay also says ìshort rolling hillsî, ìtumbleweedsî and ìlong, crippling hillî to describe the difficult terrain the cyclist faced that caused him to be tired and slower. These details highlight the physical challenge of the ride. Finally, the cyclist is faced with a ìrediculously large snakeî and plants and weeds which get in his way and force him to slow down, adding elements of fear and frustration to his ordeal. The harsh environment, therefore, tests the cyclist's physical and mental fortitude, ultimately fueling his determination to overcome these obstacles.
The setting effects the cyclist very much. By the very dry climates, the cyclist's hydration becomes a primary concern, impacting performance and overall well-being.

The setting in the story "Rough road ahead" plays a great role on the characters journey. Some features that are mentioned in the story are heat, rough road, long crippling hills and a abandoned Grape Juice Factory. The heat in the story drives the cyclist into a dying thirst. She does her best to conserve her water through out the trip but the dry dessert heat doesn’t allow it. Then comes the rough road ahead, testing her endurance. The cyclist trys to keep a steady and secure pass as she peddels along the bumps and breaks in the road. The long crippling hills are next in line; the cyclist has to use all her energy to work up the hill, each rotation of the pedals a monumental effort. She wipes the sweat from her eyes to make sure its not a mirage and then she see’s it the abandoned factory. This is where the cyclist loses all hope for if she didn’t receive water soon she is sure to be eaten by the birds. “Then, and easily as rounding a band, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me. Gary and Wilber Fish Camp.” She rushed to the bathroom to drink the refreshing water to the sink pride and accomplishment overwhelm her, showing how crucial the setting was in shaping her physical and emotional ordeal and ultimately, her triumph.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it gives him the feeling of hopelessness. At some points, tumbleweeds crossed my path and an adversely large snake. It really did move like a diamondback blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me." This shows that the cyclist is getting tired and seeing tumbleweeds, which usually represents a phase being completely deserted and deadly snakes that get in his way. This answers the question because it shows how the setting leads to his feeling of hopelessness.

The story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” was a rough, undergoing story about a cyclist going through rough climate and terrain.
