The features of a setting can affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, while he was riding in the hot sun he became very thirsty because he only had a few drops of water left. The rough, uphill terrain also slowed his pace considerably, making the journey even more arduous. That is how the setting can affect the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. They make it hard to concentrate, because of its heat; they make it unbearable. The setting has the affect of drowsiness and thirst, ìDry bitter land, longing, longing.î This makes the ride not only physically taxing, but mentally grueling as well.

In many ways, the setting affected his journey to Yosemite. If the setting wouldn't have been so bad, the long ride wouldn't have been as hard on his body. Since the setting was a very hot day in June, in a California desert, when he did find a well he said, “I followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” One thing about the setting is, if it wouldn't have been so hot, he wouldn't have needed as much water. And, if he would have gotten the water he needed because it was so hot, it wouldn't have been so physically draining on his body. I know it was physically draining because he said “I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.” The oppressive heat of the desert environment, with its scarce and unpalatable water sources, clearly amplified the physical challenges he faced. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the man was riding a bike through rough lands. His adventure wouldn’t have been an adventure if he was just riding his bike on a flat, smooth element. The fact that the hills were steep, rocky, and numerous is what made his bike ride what it was. The challenging terrain tested his endurance and skill, turning a simple ride into a memorable and demanding journey. Ultimately, it was the difficulty of the path that defined the experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist, starting with the old timers' advice of how to get somewhere. Then, the town they told him to go to was a ghost town. After he kept going, the place that they told him to get water was very old and rusty, and when he pumped it, black tar came out. Then, as he made his way into the desert, a snake came into the road, and he went around it. So, never take advice from old timers, as the harsh and unreliable environment ultimately proved their guidance to be misleading.

In the story, “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the features of the setting affect the cyclist by showing the rough conditions he went through, and somehow persevered through. The author states numerous times the lack of water, and the rolling hills made for a physically taxing ride. Followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees," further illustrating the harsh environment. This shows the struggle he went through and supports the setting of the story and how it affected his trip. This also shows how he persevered through his struggles and made an effort to finish, highlighting his resilience in the face of adversity.

The rider's condition was rough, from flat land to rolling hills. This would be hard for someone who is dehydrating, making each pedal stroke a monumental effort. There was a snake in his path so he went around it. This would be dangerous; he could blackout from lack of water and then get bit by the snake, compounding an already dire situation, proving that dehydration can introduce numerous risks.

The cyclist depicted in the essay is greatly affected by his surroundings. First, he describes a beating sun and pines and rushing rivers. All these items are very animated things. The river is even described as rushing instead of, maybe violent, emphasizing its vitality. The setting is active just like the cyclist, full of energy and life. Next, a ramshackle shed is acknowledged, as well as rusty pumps and a bad sounding corral. When these old, forsaken things are mentioned, it can be noticed that the cyclist starts being a little in despair, reflecting the decay he observes. And to tap that off, he drinks water that tastes like “battery acid.” Battery eats at skin just like the setting is eating at the cyclist, eroding his initial vigor and optimism, illustrating how powerfully environment can shape experience and mood.

In the essay ìRough Road Aheadî the setting is able to affect the cyclists emotions and moods in both positive and negative ways. As the author travels through the desert he is already upset because it is so hot and water is scarce, showing how the terrain is a negative influence on his well-being. Another example would be when the author first sees the old water pump and he is relieved, demonstrating a positive influence from the environment. However, the pump oozes a shiny substance he refers to as tasting like ìbattery acidî, immediately changing his mood for the worse. Finally, the act of putting pebbles in his mouth shows his desperation and willingness to try anything to survive, illustrating a new, albeit unusual, positive outlook driven by the desert's harshness. This positive outlook is short-lived, though, as a pump ìlodges in his throatî, making it yet another negative influence. All of these features, both positive and negative, propel him on his way to ìGary and will fish campî and ground an extra boost on his journey through the desert, showcasing how the environment directly impacts his resilience and determination.

The features of the setting affect him because it is hot and there is nowhere to go. An example from the text is when they said, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind." There was also a part where he got to a sign that said ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The speed limit was 55 mph, yet he was doing a water-depleting 12 mph, further emphasizing his struggle. Sometimes life can feel so cruel, and that's what affected the cyclist: the heat, the hilly roads, no water, snakes, rough roads, and most of all, no directions. All these elements combined to create a truly harsh and unforgiving environment that significantly impacted his journey and well-being.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because of where they were. It was like in the middle of nowhere, and seemingly every person they asked was having Alzheimer's symptoms. They got the wrong directions to the nearest town multiple times. The old guy told him it was @NUM1 miles down the road when he went @NUM2 miles and reached the next town. Frustrated, he said to himself he would never take directions from a guy that has Alzheimer's and hasn’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office; his experience demonstrates the challenges posed by unreliable information in a remote and isolated environment.

When the cyclist is in the serenity of an early sunset evening, the man enjoyed his cycling just hoping he could cut his time in half. Then, once he got the advice and headed down the road he saw a ghost town which is never good, casting a shadow of unease on his journey. Next he came to the fork and the town he came to had no water. On the way to the new town he came to the bumpy road and going @NUM1 he was out of water but finally after his determination he made it to a place that was very nice, a welcome reward after the trials. So as you can tell the features of the scenery road affected him greatly.

I think that the setting, with its vast and unforgiving desert stretching before him, made him find more courage inside himself to save his water after his canteen cracked, and go to the next town without any water. The sheer desperation of his situation, the knowledge that survival depended on his resolve, forced him to confront his fear. This harsh environment, devoid of comfort and teeming with potential dangers, stripped away any illusions and revealed a strength he didn't know he possessed, allowing him to undertake the perilous journey. Ultimately, the setting was instrumental in unlocking his inner bravery.

The environment affected the cyclist violently in the story “I Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” It seems that all of the harsh conditions of cycling in California wore down this kid who took some faulty directions from older people at one stop. The heat and lack of water supply made the boy dehydrated. It says in the essay, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen.” This explains how simply exhausted he had become due to the miles of cycling, and the beating down sun and total lack of water due to the absence of towns. He came to the point of almost dying from heat exhaustion because of the faulty directions of the old people, and the unforgiving landscape only exacerbated his predicament. Next time, he better make sure to keep extra water and stick to the map for directions to avoid such a dangerous situation again.

As the cyclist makes his journey towards Yosemite, the setting causes him much worry and concern. In the beginning, the narrator is content and excited. He is doing something that he loves, is heading for a beautiful destination, and has found a short cut to save him hours of time. He is confident in the directions given to him by the old men. However, as he continues down the winding road, his environment makes him doubt their judgement. The first town he comes to is entirely deserted. Though at first he laughs it off, he later realizes just how much trouble he is in if he doesn't come to a civilization soon. The cyclist runs across "ramshackle shed[s]" and shut down factories, and as his water supply sinks lower, the road seems to tantalize him with false hope. He passes a water pump (just what he needs), yet the water is something close to toxic and unusable. A road sign reminds him not to go too fast, though he might die if he doesn't pick up the pace. He is forced to look at a picture of a happy boy guzzling grape juice as he dehydrates. All these features of the setting, in addition to the overpowering heat and sun, drive the narrator to the breaking point, making him question his initial optimism and the wisdom of the shortcut.

The feature of setting affects the cyclist because everything that was happening years ago is happening now in today's world, meaning wars, rights, and etcetera. Today's feature is the same; everything is repeating itself. It is as if the challenges faced in the past are resurfacing, influencing the present landscape and, consequently, impacting the cyclist's journey through contemporary society. This cyclical nature suggests that understanding historical contexts is crucial for navigating current obstacles.

When riding a bike it may not seem to hard. For a cyclist every thing becomes more serious. The determination to win and be the best even if it kills you. After all was said and he faced the horror that nature brought him he knew he was wrong wrong for them and the intelligants, showing that the dedication of cyclists is often underestimated, and their expertise is hard-earned and genuinely valuable.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. The fact that he was in the California desert and the heat affected him because he had limited water and was using his energy riding the bike. The ìtownsî he came across also made an impact on him because of the fact that he couldnít get more water or a place to rest. This shows how the hilly terrain and dehydration and heat are affecting the cyclist, creating a truly challenging and harsh experience for him.

Two of the biggest setting in this story is the desert and rolling hills. This would effect the rider because of the dehydration that he would experience. Being in the desert would make it obviously hot, causing him to sweat a lot and lose crucial fluids. The hills would make it tough on his body because he would put extra strain to get up them, taxing his muscles and energy reserves. So all together, considering both the arid environment and the demanding terrain, this would be a hard bike ride, pushing the rider to their physical limits and requiring careful resource management.

In the story, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist experiences dehydration on his journey. The cyclist takes directions from older guys who look like they havenít left their porches in ages. He takes their advice and he then suffers in the long run because he cannot find water and it is a hot summer day. He hikes uphills in the heating sun and fears a heat stroke. There was no sight, not a building, car, or even a puddle to offer some relief. Thus, the cyclist's reliance on questionable advice leads to a difficult and potentially dangerous situation due to dehydration.

The setting will either affect the cyclist in a good way or a bad way. In the story "Rough Road Ahead" by Joe Kurmaskie, it affects the cyclist in both negative and positive ways. The story frequently mentions the lack of water. "When I tried a drop or two it had the flavor of battery acid." This shows that the heat made the water warm, so it did not cool him down effectively. But a good way it affects them is pebbles. "I read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to linger." This demonstrates that even though he has no water, the pebbles can provide some relief from thirst. This is how the setting affects the cyclist, in both a good way and a bad way, impacting his journey and well-being.

In this story it is clear how difficult the cyclist's journey is. He has to conquer wrong directions, lack of water, rattle snakes and fear of dying. However he shows great determination and control. An example of his determination is "The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make that." This shows his determination that he feels he can go on such a long journey. An example of his self-control is shown in paragraphs @NUM1 and @NUM2. When finding this building to be abandoned, and all things, juice, anyone use would have become frustrated and wanted to give up. But not this cyclist he controlled his anger and again showed determination. And it paid off in the end he found his water and survived. This story is a great story that shows determination and self control. The cyclist's success in overcoming these obstacles highlights the importance of inner strength and resilience.

Early in the morning, the cyclist is eager and ready to face the adventurous path that had been mapped out by the older travelers. He hardly noticed the sun was beginning to beat down. He was calm and was looking forward to the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite. Never once did he imagine what he had gotten himself into. As he began to approach the desert, he noticed he was running low on water. The strenuous activity of biking combined with the scorching heat of the desert began to take effect. The cyclist was so desperate for water that he had to put pebbles into his mouth. He had once read that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you have left to circulate. The cyclist was hoping for a way out of the misery he had come across. Dehydration took its toll, and he felt hallucinations. He was beginning to lose hope. The heat and the hills and the lack of water had the greatest affect on the cyclist. Had he not been riding through a hilly desert one afternoon in June, he would have been fine. It was the convergence of these factors that led him to such a desperate state, highlighting the importance of preparation and awareness when undertaking challenging journeys.

In the cyclist story, the setting took a huge roll on how the story thinned out. The water had a lot of effects on the cyclist. The setting of the story took place in the high deserts of California in June. As soon as you read that, you know something is wrong. In the story he says, the sun was beginning to beat down. This is going to affect him because he's riding through the desert on a bike, which causes him to become dehydrated. "I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." He's beginning to lose his mind because he has no water because of the setting. Everything about the setting causes the cyclist some problems. The heat, the setting, the lack of water almost costs him his life, showcasing how crucial the environment is to the cyclist's ordeal and the narrative's progression.

The setting affects the cyclist in a lot of ways. The first way is that he was riding in the middle of a desert in June. If he was riding in Alaska, it wouldn't be painfully hot. Also, the rolling hills probably didn't help; if it was mostly downhill, he would have been fine. Riding a bike up a hill when you're tired is near impossible, especially with the sun beating down. These environmental factors combined to make his ride incredibly challenging.

In the story ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the features of the path to Yosemite National Park greatly affected the cyclist. On the way to the park the cyclist came across a big snake that covered the road which greatly frightened the biker. Also the roads were long and very bumpy and windy. The road wasnít the most comfortable to be riding on. There was nothing in sight for the cyclist to see, offering no visual distraction from the arduous journey. The cyclist did not have much energy because he had no hope for him. The author states, ìÖ gaining elevation while loosing hope.î Lastly, the weather was hot and dry which tired the cyclist out. He had no water with him and with the weather he had no energy or hope to help him through the journey to Yosemite National Park, making the ride even more physically and mentally taxing. These combined challenges of terrain, weather, and lack of supplies significantly diminished the cyclist's morale and his ability to complete his journey.

In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed limit the cyclist expirenced a few life threating times during his adventure. The first feature was when was in a deseret with temptures of @NUM1 degrees and his lit bit of water tasted like battery acid. As he tried to keep going he lost hope and thought he was going to die. This affected him because as he lost hope he thought more negative about things and didnít think he would make it but the he got the agility to move on. In this story the setting affects the characters dramatically. The extreme heat and the tainted water pushed him to his physical and mental limits. Overcoming such adversity demonstrates how deeply the harsh environment impacted his struggle and eventual resilience.

The feature of the setting is making the cyclist frustrated, thirsty, and confused. The features are making him frustrated because he thought he was going the right way when he really was going out, leading to increasing disorientation and discomfort.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the features are what cause the climax of the story. An example of this would be the line, ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California.î This line shows that the author was in a very hot and arid place, being in a desert, but also that he has a low water supply, suggesting a challenging environment. These two conditions are what cause the climax, which is the possibility that he could collapse any minute from heat exhaustion, facing a potentially life-threatening situation. This is why the features of the setting directly and dramatically affect the cyclist.

Certain features of the setting affected the cyclist. In the essay by Joe Kurmaskie, he describes his experiences when he cycled through the desert. He "...arrived at the first town"...it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. At first, the cyclist was amused at this town and maybe a little skeptical of it because the old "codgers" told it to be thriving. Halfway through his journey, he stated, "sometimes life can be so cruel." Water was running low, and he still had a ways to go until he made it to the park, and he felt as if it would never end. All that he sees around him are hills of nothingness under the scorching sun with his limited amount of water. No buildings are around the cyclist, emphasizing his isolation. The ghost town and the lack of shade or succor are very features of the setting that make the cyclist feel like a fool for taking advice from older men, highlighting how the unforgiving environment amplified his regret.

The setting of the cyclist affected him by making him very hot and quickly depleting his water supply, meaning he would soon run out of water and dehydrate. For example, in the story the cyclist would frequently bring up the little bit of water he had left, and throughout the essay he talked about the dehydration he was experiencing and even the potential for death. Another example is the relief he expressed when he finally drank water from the sink. In conclusion, this illustrates how the harsh setting had a detrimental effect on the cyclist.

This paragraph tells about how careful you should be on the roads. This also talks about what you have to be aware of, such as other drivers and pedestrians. There are so many things that could happen, from unexpected stops to sudden lane changes. You have to take control when you're on the road, staying focused and making responsible decisions to ensure your safety and the safety of those around you.

The features of the setting in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie affects the cyclist in many ways. For example it states "This place might have been a thriving little spot before the last world war it fit the tradition definition of a ghost town." This statement is talking about the town he arrived at when he was trying to get to Yosemite. This would affect the cyclist because he was riding in confidence in the beginning, but then the first town he arrives in looks like a ghost town, which would bring his confidence a little bit lower than before. The desolation emphasizes his isolation. Just like when people travel when they know where they are going they feel good, but once they come to a place they don't know then they wont feel so confident. Another example is when he has to ride on rolling hills, and then comes across a "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" sign. This would affect the cyclist because then he would be frustrated and stressed out because he rode all that way and now he cant go any further, and that is not the place he wanted to be at. The jarring sign clashes with his expectations of smooth progress. Therefore the features of the setting in "Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie ultimately affects the cyclist's mood and journey.

The conditions that the bicyclist faced that affected his trip were various amount of things that could really screw your ride up. Some of the conditions were hot. It was very hot, and that makes it hard to think fast, move fast, and make good decisions. Another would be there was lose gravel, and that makes it tough to maneuver, and you have to watch your speed, so he's not going anywhere in a hurry. Also, there were lots of hills, and that makes for an uncomfortable ride and a tiring one at that. Adding to that, he was fresh out of water, and that can mean dehydration, again bad judgment, and even heat stroke or exhaustion. Another bad thing is he was in the middle of nowhere, so it's not like he could stop somewhere we asks for a drink too; there was nothing around for miles. These things show how rough the road was made because these conditions existed, ultimately making for a very challenging and potentially dangerous bicycle ride.

The setting was very hot and dry; it was a desert. This setting affected him because it was making him very dehydrated and hot. The sun beat down mercilessly, each mile an agonizing test of endurance. It was very hard for him to go any further, but he knew he had to keep going, his destination a distant shimmer on the horizon. Also, the land was very barren and everything around was parched, offering no respite from the heat. Clearly, the setting affected the biker, pushing him to his physical and mental limits as he battled the harsh environment.

The setting affected the cyclist because they were in California in June traveling back roads, with no place to stop for water. This combination of intense heat and isolation made the ride particularly challenging. If the cyclist would have followed the path they intended on following, the ride probably would have been more enjoyable and he/she wouldn’t have had to worry about a heatstroke or running out of water; access to planned rest stops and resources would have mitigated those risks. They would have been fine, suggesting the importance of sticking to planned routes, especially in demanding environments.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. There were hills and rocks, snakes and no buildings or people. The hills and rocks would make it much harder to to stay strong and be able to keep riding. The snakes also presented a danger, adding a constant threat of a bite. The abandoned building and there being no people, could affect him emotionally. It would make him loose hope and the determination to keep going to find destination. He did not think he would get that after seeing a deserted town. After all, he did say, ìIt didnít really matter. I was going to die Ö ì(Kurmaskie). The harsh environment, devoid of human contact, clearly contributed to his despair and acceptance of what he perceived as his inevitable fate.

The main features of the setting that affected the cyclist are the fact that it was June and the dessert heat. “I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June…” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This helps us realize how bad the heat is in June in the middle of the California desert. This affected the cyclist by his dehydration and the fact that he was in the middle of nowhere with no one to help him. This isolation exacerbated the danger posed by the intense heat. This is how the month of June and the desert heat affected the cyclist.

The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in this story. First, when he got to the road sign that said “Rough Road Ahead” he was already low on water, but that made things much worse. The rough road made it harder for him to pedal; therefore, he was working harder and getting thirsty. Also, when he stopped at the old Welch’s Grape Juice Factory, he noticed some pebbles on the ground and shoved them in his mouth. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing spit you have left to circulate”. Lastly, “GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP”, could possibly have saved the cyclist’s life. He stopped there and finally got a well deserved drink of water to settle his dehydration and fear. The setting and features severely affected the cyclist throughout his journey, impacting his thirst, his coping mechanisms, and ultimately, his survival.

In ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, the features of the setting affect how the author feels. In the beginning of the essay, the author is confident and happy, and the setting is, ìa reservoir camp ground outside at Lodi, Californiaî (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This sounds like a good place to be refreshed and to feel confident, suggesting a positive influence from the environment. Later into the bike ride, the author is affected negatively by the barren area he comes to when he says, ìThis sight was troubling" (Kurmaskie @NUM1), showing how the harsh landscape impacted his mood. Finally when he reaches a modern store, he is relieved due to the modern facility when he states, ìThen, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind meî (Kurmaskie @NUM3). The area the author goes through has an effect, as seen by the shift from confidence, to trouble, and finally to relief, proving the setting's powerful influence on his emotional state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they don’t ride as much anymore and don’t know the best routes to take. So, they just take their old routes, thinking they are still the better way, but when they use them they realize how tiring and bad they are. The increased traffic and new construction have rendered those once-ideal paths unpleasant and inefficient, proving that familiar routes are not always the best choice in a changing landscape, and their ride becomes more of a struggle.

ìAt some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path..î being out in the desert with limited or no water can make one feel like life is very cruel. The sun was beating down and no water or shade is seen when he reaches a point. The sign that said ìRough roads ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.î had to be intimidating. Considering he was on a bike he could only move so fast. Those old men probably were never off their front porch since Carter was in office. Yes, like the writer said, ìthe world is a fluid place. Things change.î The old men probably had close to no idea what they were talking about considering things have changed since the 70s (when Carter was in office). The snake that he came upon, must have been rather intimidating. Knowing there is a creature like that, there is bound to be more. In essence, I think the setting was a major part of why the cyclist felt that way.

From what there is in this picture the cyclist is riding a dry area which could mean that it is very hot and the cyclist looks to be going downhill; there looks to be a lot of turns. From the body position of the cyclist he seems to be trying at his best and hardest to make it to his destination. All of this could be a big stress on the cyclist; he maybe sweating really hard and maybe tired; the wind might not be helping him at all. The challenging terrain and apparent heat suggest the cyclist is facing a tough ride overall.

In the short story ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limitî by Joshua Chaplinsky, a cyclist travels through an extreme climate and tough terrain that nearly end his life to get to his destination. After getting outdated directions from some elderly locals, the protagonist sets off on his journey to Yosemite National Park. Soon thereafter, the cyclist notices something is amiss. The first ìtownî the locals said heíd find is deserted. And now, twenty miles into his journey, the cyclist needs to refill some of his water supply. The water pump there has ìthe flavor of battery acid.î With the next town 30 miles away, the cyclist struggles to conserve his water to make it there. Even then, things get worse. As he is, ìtraveling through the high deserts of California in Juneî, ìflat road was replaced by short rolling hills.î Chaplinsky tell him not to exceed the speed limit of 25 as he does a ìwater-depleting 35 mph.î eventually, even on his few sips of water, the cyclist finds a spot to fill up on water, knowing now to strike out on better days and better directions, a lesson learned from a near-fatal misadventure.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. When she was riding it was very hot; this caused the cyclist to lose energy and dehydrate, impacting her performance. Also when the cyclist went through a terrain change, the road changed into rolling hills. This caused the cyclist to become tired because after riding up and down your body gets tired from the constant exertion. Also, being as the weather was so hot, this caused the cyclist to drink a lot of water to try and stay cool and hydrated. Eventually, she ran out and then got dehydrated, further hindering her progress. This whole situation implied to stick to your original plan, including accounting for supplies and environmental factors. If the cyclist would have done that, she wouldn’t have had to go through the hardships of fatigue and dehydration, thus highlighting the importance of preparation.

Each new feature of the setting in the essay entitled, “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, affects the cyclist in some way. For example, in the text, when the narrator stated that he had to avoid a “ridiculously large snake” crossing the road, he became more aware of his surroundings and almost seemed to forget how thirsty he was until he finally abided the large reptile. The snake, a sudden and imposing obstacle, forced him to focus sharply on the immediate present. Also in the text, when, “over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view,” hope was replenished into the cyclist. This hope allowed the narrator to become more tenacious about his journey in order to arrive at the old building, the sight of civilization acting as a powerful motivator. Whether for better or worse, a few features of the setting arrive and affect the cyclist every step of his journey, influencing his focus, motivation, and overall experience.

Many features of the setting of the cyclistís excruciating trip affect him mentally and physically. When he first sets out, the pine trees and rivers kept him cheerfully riding through the landscape. When he sees the corral and the rusty pumps, he becomes discouraged and begins to notice his tiredness and thirst. When the cyclist encounters a rough terrain with tumble weeds and snakes, he is both mentally and physically exhausted. He begins to doubt his consciousness and worries that he will not complete the journey. The abandoned grape juice factory is also a let down for the cyclistís mental state. When all hope is seemingly lost, he finally comes across water, and his unique (but very important) lesson is learned, showing how environmental factors impact not only physical endurance but also mental fortitude during challenging journeys.

The features of the setting had an affect on the cyclist. I know this because in the story the cyclist said that he was "going to drop from heat exhaustion," he is riding through the desert in August, and he took directions from three old "gentlemen" sitting on a porch. This harsh environment clearly impacted his physical state, and the presence of the porch suggests a rare, perhaps isolated, outpost of civilization. Thus, the setting's challenging conditions and hints of human presence influenced the cyclist's experience.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, since he was in a desert, the heat of the desert greatly dehydrated him on his journey to find spare parts. Also, the bumpy roads and rolling hills slowed the bike down to 12 mph since it was too extreme for him to handle at high speeds. When he sees the first building, he is relieved, but soon after, he loses all his hope because it is deserted. Even the old men living in the area have an effect on the cyclist because they give him out-dated directions that almost strand him. Because of this, he will probably rest first in one of the old men’s short tents again. This is how the harsh features of the setting severely tested the cyclist's resolve and impacted his journey.

Well first off its very hot and dry witch can dry a person out easily. And the hills are hard to get up so it would be a challange to get to the top. All I know is the lack of water can kill you if you get heatstroaks easily. The sun's intensity combined with the dryness accelerates dehydration. Those steep hills demand significant physical exertion, making the climb even more difficult. Consequently, the risk of heatstroke is greatly increased without proper hydration, potentially leading to dire consequences.

In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. At first the cyclist thought that the journey he was about to go on was going to be a good one, but that soon changes as the challenging terrain and misleading advice take their toll. For example, ìNever accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who havenít left the confines of their porched since Carter was in office.î This quote tells how at first the cyclist thought his journey was going to be a good one, but getting information from two old men soon changed that when their directions led him astray and into difficult conditions. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the essay ìRough Road ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î highlighting how external elements can drastically alter one's expectations and experience.

The features of setting affect the cyclist in that a desert-like temperature and the terrain on which he must bike make him more prone to thirst and exhausting. The heat during July will cause the cyclist to dehydrate faster than normal. This is especially true in this case because of his lack of water. The cyclist might pass out or suffer a heat stroke. The terrain of rolling hills will tire out the cyclist quicker than if he were still on the flat road. His muscles will start to ache and his body will need water and rest. The story would totally change if the setting were different. If the cyclist were biking in the winter on a cold day in the mid 30s he would not have a chance of suffering a heatstroke. There would be a significantly less chance of him becoming dehydrated. The setting is very important in every story and can change everything.

In Joe Kurmaskie’s essay “Rough Road Ahead,” the speaker is biking through rough terrain in blistering heat, not to mention long distances. He has to ride up and down small and large hills through what he believes is a shortcut to his destination. He has a limited water supply, and he keeps coming across ghost towns, where the only water is boiling, brackish water that is unfit for human consumption. Probably the worst setting feature for this guy was the Welch’s Grape Juice Factory (abandoned of course). Adding salt to the wound was “A sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen” (Kurmaskie). To the narrator with his dwindling water supply, this billboard was especially daunting to him on his journey, serving as a cruel reminder of what he lacked and the harshness of his present situation. The image, in its faded glory, mocks his thirst and emphasizes the desolate nature of his surroundings, ultimately highlighting the physical and psychological challenges of his arduous ride.

Desert, hills, road condition, and lack of water all affected the cyclist's journey. First, the cyclist reveals he is in the desert when he exclaims, "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." This means it was hot, adding to the physical strain. Second, the hills and road conditions were horrible. The cyclist reveals this when he describes, "flat road was replaced by short rolling hills," and again, "Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit." This made the ride more physically demanding and slower. Lastly, he had thought that he would have stops on the way to get water from, so he drank all the water he wanted. He then figured out he needed to conserve it, but by then it was too late. These examples show that the cyclist's conditions were harder than he expected them to be, turning what he thought would be a simple ride into a grueling challenge.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. The winding road could affect his turns because he could turn too far one way and fall off his bike and get hurt real bad. The road’s condition, whether smooth or bumpy, also plays a role in maintaining balance. Another feature that could affect the cyclist is grass on both sides of the road. If he tries to take a short-cut and goes into the grass he could hit a rock and flip off his bike and get hurt. Therefore, the cyclist's safety and performance are significantly influenced by the surrounding environment. That is what the feature of the setting could affect the cyclist.

The cyclist was in a California desert in the middle of June. He thinks he's going to die towards the end because of the directions he got. "Never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." This means to never take directions from people who haven't been to the place for a while, especially when your life depends on accurate information in the unforgiving heat.

The setting was a hot desert in California that a biker got stuck in going to Yosemite National Park. These settings were hard on the cyclist. For example, he listened to some old people who led him the wrong way and could have had him killed. He was running out of water and his legs felt like they were going to break off from the constant pedaling under the scorching sun. All of these troubles did affect his trust in old locals though. He learn that just because they are old and looks wise they don't necessarily have accurate information, probably older than the artifacts at a museum. Besides he has a trust map now, understanding who to rely on and who to question. He got a lot from this trip, especially the hard-earned lesson that wisdom isn't always tied to age and appearances, shaping a more discerning approach to advice in the future.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, in "ghost towns," there is no one to ask directions from or to just talk to, creating a sense of isolation. Also, some pumped water from water pumps tastes like "battery acid" and could most likely make someone sick, posing a threat to their health and hydration. Furthermore, there are poisonous snakes and other dangerous animals that could attack the cyclist, so the cyclist needs to be alert. Thus, the environmental aspects of the setting create significant challenges for the cyclist.

There are many features in the story that affect the roles, like being out of water and receiving bad directions. The narrator, whose name we don't know, says, "the water bottles container a few tantalizing sips..." implying there is hardly any water left. He still has to keep going on, until he can find some. In the story, water is something he has to overcome because he is out of it by the time he gets to the fish store, creating a significant obstacle in his journey. This lack of water highlights the desperation and perseverance he must exhibit.

In this analysis I will explain how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. In the short story ìRough Road A Head Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î The whole ordeal occurs in the ìhigh deserts of california.î Prior to this, according to the text the cyclist had taken ìout of dateî directions from elderly people who thought they knew the way. The cyclist encountered a snake, ghost town, and shutdown factory, further highlighting the desolation. Most of the time the cyclist was going over rough terrain, adding to the challenge and isolation. This combination of outdated information and harsh, desolate environments significantly contributed to the cyclist's struggles and feeling of being lost and alone.

The setting in ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî adds drama into the story by how it affects the cyclist. He was tacking through the ìhigh desert of California in Juneî. June is a hot part of the year and since he was in the hottest desert part the heat was multiplied. The terrain changing into ìshort rolling hillsî didnít help the cyclist. The hills would make any riding more difficult. Anyone who rides a bicycle knows it takes more effort to go up a hill than on flat pavement, draining the cyclist's energy. With the person's lack of water, anyone would be struggling to keep riding. Most people didnít have that hints to keep moving. He didnít set a very goal he just went to the ìnext Horizonî. Shouldnít he just wanted to keep going. Another problem with the physical environment was the road conditions. When the ìRough Road Affectî sign appeared the travel then became more difficult. A bike tire takes more effort to go over uneven pavement, which is why the cyclist had so much trouble, further escalating the challenges and heightening the story's tension.

In the story "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist in a hard way. With only a few sips of water left, he noticed an abandoned building: "abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it, it had been a Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sand-blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. I hung my head." Having so little water, seeing that image would have only increased his thirst. Another way the setting affected the cyclist negatively was: "The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so cruel." This reminded him that he was not in a car, and that he wasn't even going half the speed limit. The setting, therefore, affects the cyclist by constantly reminding him of the length of his journey, and at this point, he is clearly suffering from the harsh environment.

In the essay, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting the cyclist is in effects him greatly. One evening when he was resting he got into a deep conversation with a couple of elders. Eventually they got to talking about his journey, and the two men gave him direction for a shortcut. “But on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” When he arrives at the first town, he finds it deserted, this effects the cyclist because he is eventually going to need more water. As he continues, he comes to a steep incline in the road. “After I had arrested the first few of these a large highway sign jumped out at most read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT” This sign was indicating that the road was going to be bumpy, which makes it even more challenging for the cyclist. So, the setting is very important in this essay because it has a lot to do with how the cyclist feels. When the abandoned towns come into play, he begins to feel hopeless. When the road gets bumpy, he gets tired. When he gets to an actual running store, he’s relieved, showcasing how the environment directly shapes his emotional and physical state throughout his journey.

The feature of the setting affects the cyclist because the feature is just a brief preview of what the text is going to be about or who is involved in it. The cyclist gives you what you want and need to know, so the affect would be about the time the feature is finished playing, and no one would want to see the cyclist. Essentially, the setting preview can overshadow the actual cyclist, leading to disinterest.

In the story, "Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The setting of a story is the background, place, and time the story took place. In the story, a cyclist needs to get to @CAPS1 Park. He stops and gets direction from a group of old men, who arenít up with the times, and the cyclist gets lost. He faces drought, a snake, and being lost in the desert, the cyclist says, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake ñ it really did look like a diamond back ñ blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, to avoid any confrontation." The desert environment, with its lack of water and dangerous wildlife, directly impacts his journey and creates obstacles for him. The challenging desert setting significantly shapes the cyclist's experience and the difficulties he encounters.

The cyclist chose the worst time to ride; it was an early summer evening in California. At this time, the sun is hot, and with little water and also lost, it was not the best choice that he made. A cyclist before doing a trip should be prepared for weather conditions and also check a map of the place before going anywhere. This simple preparation could have prevented his predicament, highlighting the importance of planning before embarking on a cycling journey.

The features of this particular setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. Upon arriving at the ìghost townî early in his journey, he felt slight amusement at the situation. But he soon became very troubled when he became aware of the several rusty pumps and a weak corral, next to a ramshackle shed, hinting at a desolate past. The cyclist additionally experienced a bit of irony as he approached the 55 mph speed limit sign complete with a warning to strictly obey it. On his bicycle, at a pace of 12 mph, he could not even reach the 55 mph speed if he had wanted to, highlighting the absurdity of the warning in his context. Before he reached what appeared to be an abandoned Welchís Grape Juice factory, the cyclist felt this twisted amusement yet again, as he laughed. The text states, ìIt was a sad hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.î Finally, his suffering was through when he discovered a ìfish camp,î with a modern bathroom and working sinks, signifying a return to civilization. The cyclistís relief was so immense that he had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber (the owners), and kiss them, demonstrating the profound impact of simple comforts after such hardship.

The setting of this story takes place with a man biking and then taking advice from old timers to a faster route. The biker knew from the start that he should have not given his map away. But thinking the old folks knew the route he took their advice. What the biker should have done was look for someone to ask and make sure the route would work with his journey. But jumping to where he wanted to go led him to dehydration and much more struggle than needed on the unexplored path. You should always think things out before you take action, just to be safe and prevent unnecessary complications.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he initially didn’t know where he was going and took directions from people he wasn’t really sure about. It was hot, and he was running out of water. He had no idea where he was, and there were snakes along the path, adding to his anxiety. His water was running out, and there were no signs to guide him. He kept thinking that he would never take directions from old guys again and that he would stick to future, more reliable methods of navigation, highlighting his frustration with the unfamiliar and challenging environment.

At first when he gets the directions from the old men, he thinks he will be fine. When he gets to the first town he's tired and almost out of water, but still thinks he will be in Yosemite soon. When he gets to the water pump in the middle of the desert, he's tired and thirsty and he realizes that the directions the old men gave him were out of date. He's really not happy about listening to them and not following his map. When he gets to the fishing place he is grateful for the water in the sink and for the rest, and when the old man offers to give directions to Yosemite he thinks he will just use his map. Throughout the story the cyclist's needs change from feeling confident to feeling depressed to feeling relieved, showing his evolving understanding of the journey and the importance of relying on his own resources.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting seemed to affect the main character (the cyclist) very much during his pedal, for example, the dry desert setting made him think that he could survive without water, he became dehydrated. The first town, with @NUM1 degree water, could not satisfy his standards. The old Velches June factory was all run down and is no longer in business, much like the desert, just old, barren, unused land. This sense of decay and abandonment mirrored his own dwindling resources and perhaps his fading hope. While yes, the cyclist survived the pedal, the desert setting posed a great challenge for him, shaping his choices and pushing him to his physical limits.

There are many features of the setting that effect the cyclist. One feature is that it is getting hotter and it will eventually effect him. The line ìI wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasnít a mirge.î shows that the heat might be starting to effect him, impacting his vision and causing him discomfort. Another feature is that he is in the desert and running low on water. The line ìI had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularlyî shows that he is drinking a lot of water and is running low, which is dangerous in such an arid environment. Another feature is that he is riding in the high deserts of California in June. The setting affects the cyclist because it creates that deserted atmosphere and helps set the mood of the essay. Author Joe Kurmaskie learns the dangers of a lifeless wilderness during his experience described in ìdo not exceed posted speed limit.î As a cyclist riding in one of the most undeveloped areas in California, the lack of water found in this setting proves crippling to his survival. The trails he was directed to had no towns or sources of fresh, drinkable water for days, a critical oversight given the physical demands of his journey. The combination of constant exercise riding through the terrain, lack of water and resources, California summer weather, and lack of civilization drained the author’s energy and caused him to suffer from dehydration, a condition exacerbated by the relentless sun. Too much exposure to these conditions could have killed him. The modern time period and year also caused the directions the author was given to be inaccurate, and, thus, causing the cyclist to find himself in such a dangerous and isolated area of the country. The setting of ìdo not exceed posted speed limitî, therefore, places the cyclist in a life-threatening situation due to environmental challenges and inaccurate guidance.

The features of a setting could be a number of different things. It could be snowing and cold, raining and of course wet, hot and dry, breezy and humid. The features could be a busy tough or a solitere country road, there could be rough terrain or straight aways. The setting of a place puts pressure of the reality of what will happen on a cyclist. In the essay a young cyclist takes advice from some elderly man and ends up riding through hot sun and ghost towns not knowing if he would survive. The heat had him feeling as though death were coming on him and the thirst had him becoming more determined to get to the next town so he could survive. If the features of the setting had been different, say he was riding on a flat road in a busy town with a breeze and places to stop for water everywhere he would not have feared for his life. The features of the setting affect how the cyclist feels and thinks. He can feel angry, happy, sad or scared and he can start to think about his own death. These have been what I believe some of the effects settings have on cyclist, influencing their emotions and shaping their mental state as they navigate the world.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. Finally when the author says “no one in sight, no building, car, or structure,” he is affected because he can’t ask questions since he's lost and he's thirsty, heightening his feelings of isolation and vulnerability. The setting makes it hard for the author to maneuver and get to where he wants to go, presenting obstacles that challenge his physical endurance and navigational skills.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î because it goes to many different terrains. In the story, the setting greatly affects the attitude of the cyclist. When he starts out, it is an early summer evening, he is serene while he is talking to the old men. The features of the setting have a great affect on the desperate travels of the weary cyclist. The features of the setting affect the cyclist more than anything in the reading of “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speeding Limit.” In the beginining when the cyclists had just begun his cycling cause he uses a positive tone to describe the setting. The settings of your environment always seem to affect your mood. Take for instance the cyclist. In the beginning he had a positive attitude but once he arrived at the first town his attitude started to go down from there. Many of the setting's features affect the cyclist. One of the features of the desert-like setting is the dry air and hot temperatures. Joe Kurmaskieís ìRough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî tells how a cyclist takes directions from older men who donít tell him correctly the way to get to Yosemite, so the cyclist ends up lost with hardly any water. The features of the setting taunt the cyclist with cruel irony. As the cyclist continues down his path he passes through a ghost town, the silence amplifying his solitude, then twenty miles up the road he sees a ramshackle shed and some rusty water pumps. He attempts to get water out because he was running out, his hopes rising momentarily, but all he could get was muck, then what he described as “water feeling two-hundred degrees; it had the flavor of battery acid.” Further down the road was a sign that said rough road ahead, adhere to the posted speed limit of 55; he was going 12 mph, each rotation of the pedals a struggle. Even worse, he found an abandoned juice factory on the way, the faded signs a cruel reminder of refreshment he couldn't have; at that point, he was completely out of water, his thirst a constant, gnawing companion. The landscape seemed to mock his efforts, presenting the illusion of aid while offering only further hardship, highlighting the futility of his journey.

Do not exceed the posted speed limit, and never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in the office. After reading “Do Not Exceed Posted Limit” I have seen how the scene of an area can affect your mood and attitude around things. The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making him hot and thirsty most of his way. As he rode, he started to get tired slowly, and he got worn and more thirsty. He drank his water at first without thinking too much of it, but as he went on, he slowly found himself trying to conserve it. By the time he got to the second wild town, he was so thirsty and tired that he thought it might have been a "death." So he wiped the sweat from his eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage, a vision often caused by extreme heat and dehydration. The only time people see mirages is when they are hot, tired, and about to kill for some water. This is what the cyclist was like after his long journey to Yosemite National Park with the directions given by old men, highlighting just how challenging the environment had become for him.

The features of the setting include there being no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind which describes the trail the cyclist was taking. These features of the setting describe how the cyclist is affected because it elaborates on his doubting whether he will survive or not, amplifying his feelings of isolation and vulnerability as he faces the daunting prospect of being utterly alone should something go wrong.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. The speed limit sign makes him feel like life is cruel. His first glimpse of the Welch's Juice factory makes him feel excited. Meeting the deserted fork in the road makes him feel troubled. When he finally gets there, he feels relieved. These are all examples showing that features of the setting affected the cyclist, demonstrating how external environments can significantly influence inner emotions.

The many features of the setting greatly affect the cyclist & his performance. For example, the cyclist is riding through a very hot area of California. Not something that someone should be cycling on, had the setting, told of the mountianous regions of California, the wither would hot be hot, or tired because the mountians are a cool, although dry place. The features setting in the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” are very important to the cyclist. In this story, the setting really affected the cyclist because it was in California which is a really hot place during the summer. In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting significantly affects the cyclist. The narrative recounts the man pedaling long distances, twenty miles here and forty miles there, under the intense heat with a limited water supply, leading to doubts about reaching his destination. The narrator states, "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June," highlighting the extreme heat. The desert's hot weather limited his water supply, and the desolation of the location, devoid of buildings, diminished his hope. The presence of snakes further endangered him, and the rough road made his journey more challenging. "I began breaking the ride into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself if I could make it to that I'd be fine." This quote illustrates his struggle due to the harsh environment but also his resilience. Ultimately, the features of the setting profoundly impact the cyclist, shaping his experience and testing his endurance in the face of adversity.

Many features of the cyclistís surroundings affect his speed and confidence. He was the only one on the road. There were no other cars, bikes, motorcycles, or even buildings nearby. It's like he's in the countryside. So that makes him want to go faster, because he wonít hit anything. The wide, open road stretches before him, clear and inviting. The fact that he's alone in the wide, open spaces boosts up his energy level and makes him feel more confident, allowing him to push his limits.

To be able to have a good bike ride, you must have a good setting. To me, a good setting would about @NUM1∞ outside and sunny. You can't go bike riding in snow because there is no way that the tires will move in the snow. You can't go in rain or hail because the roads get slippery and you could get in a accident that could injure or kill you. If it is sunny outside you be able to ride freely on dry roads with a little breeze to go through your hair and you could be refreshed. The sun also provides good visibility. That is why I believe it is important for the setting to be just right for a bike ride.

The June sun beat down mercilessly on the cyclist as he navigated the seemingly endless desert. The hotter it got, the more precious water he consumed, a constant worry since he was utterly alone. After what felt like an eternity, "about forty miles in the pedal I arrived as my first 'town'. The place might have been a thriving little oasis at one time." The deserted streets confirmed his isolation; there was nobody to offer water, directions, or any kind of assistance, highlighting the stark reality of his solitary journey. Every mile pedaled was a testament to his determination in the face of such desolation, a fight for survival fueled by the hope of reaching the National Park.

In the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting greatly affected the cyclist. In this story, the cyclist is heading for Yosemite National Park, thinking it wise, he accepts directions from a group of eccentric old men. He begins his journey confidently on flat terrain and with a large supply of water. The first of three promised towns had been resigned to that of a ghost town, a desolate scene that dashed initial hopes. The second offered only water that slightly resembled battery acid, a further blow to his dwindling resources. The cyclist soon becomes exhausted from lack of water and having to cross the now hilly terrain. He barely makes it to the third town to realize that the juice factory was out of business, a final strike against his expectations. The cyclist becomes sure that he is going to die of lack of water when he stumbles across a bait store, his last hope in a desperate situation. If it hadnít been so hot, if the ìtownsî along the way had offered better resources and if the terrain hadnít been so hilly, the cyclist would have had a very enjoyable ride. All of the aforementioned factors of the setting greatly affected the cyclist, shaping his arduous journey and near-death experience.

Hot, terrain, middle of nowhere- all are features of the setting that affected the cyclist. First, the hot weather in California made the cyclist thirsty and almost dehydrated, sapping his energy with each passing mile. There was no place to stop for water and if there was, the water was bad and warm, offering little relief. Second, the different types of terrain made the cyclist really thirsty also and tired; steep inclines tested his strength, while rough patches jarred his body. Lastly, the cyclist was in the middle of nowhere, completely isolated from civilization. He couldnít get water to hydrate himself or a shaded spot to sit down and rest, compounding the challenges he faced. The unforgiving environment, therefore, presented multiple obstacles that tested the cyclist's endurance.

The setting for the cyclist is a hard and dangerous one. He had little water, and his area had tough terrains. ìI was travelling through the high deserts of California in Juneî (@NUM1). The cyclist in ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed @CAPS1î was riding through the California desert in June. This dry, bare setting made it impossible to find any source of water. The only time that this cyclist found water was when it rained @NUM1 and tasted of battery acid. There was nowhere for him to find water for miles. This lack of water and scorching heat made him travel slow and wearily. He even says that he could only go 12 mph in a 55 mph zone. By taking the advice of the old men and taking a ìshort cutî, the cyclist passed through ghost towns with no water. This ìshort cutî prolonged his trip, most likely by hours. If he had gone through populated areas, despite the fact that it is a longer path, there would have been more water to drink, which would allow him to go faster. The dry, hot setting of the old menís ìshort cutî made this cyclistís trip last much longer than necessary, highlighting how the promise of a shortcut can sometimes lead to unexpected and detrimental consequences.

When the man began cycling he thought that this was going to be an easy ride. For example in paragraph @NUM1 he says ìThings began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.î As he got further he realized that he was in the middle of nowhere. The scenery was getting more and more empty and desolate. There was eventually nothing but sand and scrub. The scenery was putting down his hope of ever getting out of the desert. For example: In paragraph @NUM2 it states, ìa large highway sign jumped out of me. It read: Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.î He realized this was going to be hard. He had to travel on bumpy roads and pass snakes without getting bit, and the sun beat down relentlessly. The scenery created a sense of hopelessness because it was abandoned and unforgiving. When he saw the bait shop, his spirits lifted and he was now hopeful and relieved, seeing a sign of civilization after such a trying journey.

When the cyclist began his journey he was confident in succeeding. Throughout the story however, the cyclist endures many conflicts to his success in his journey. On top of his water problem the heat was unbelievable, and he felt the sun beating down relentlessly. He was losing hydration from all the sweat, and he was losing it quickly. The cyclist was also dealing with the difficult roads, full of uneven terrain that made each mile a struggle. There were many things this cyclist endured throughout his journey, but he was determined to finish his trip and was filled with satisfaction once he overcame these hardships.

The setting in the essay "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" has a major effect on the cyclist. The setting is the high deserts of California where it is June and very hot. The path of the cyclist suggested by some old men makes the heat even worse because there are no people or water in sight. In the essay, the cyclist starts out the day confident and excited for his ride to Yosemite National Park. His mood changes throughout the day as after 60 miles he arrives in a "ghost town" the old men led him to believe would be a settled town where he could get more supplies and cool off. Soon as the temperature rises to what feels like "two hundred degrees" the cyclist begins to run low on water and feels "sometimes life can feel so cruel." The heat and lack of people and water lead the cyclist to desperation and make him feel like as he says "i was going to die." The setting of the cyclists journey provides the mood of hopelessness and amplifies the feeling of determination felt by the cyclist to keep going at all costs because he was going to die if he stopped. The author, Steinbeck uses the setting of the essay to help bring across his message that by blindly trusting people instead of trusting yourself things could end up being hard for you to overcome. Ultimately, the harsh environment emphasizes the importance of self-reliance and critical thinking.

In the story ìDo not Exceed Posted Speed limitî the cyclist sees many different settings when he left it was early summer and it was pretty hot outside. The cyclist should have never taken the advice from the older men. The map would have been a lot safer and easier. People seem to always look for a shortcut, including myself. He could have died from heat stroke and lack of water in that barren landscape. He did have perseverance though; he never gave up, and that is what saved him from a potentially fatal situation. Being in that situation and setting, I would have given up, succumbing to the harsh conditions, but his resilience ultimately saw him through.

When cycling it's important to make yourself aware of the type of terrain it is, including hills, trails, or roads; make sure of the weather, checking for rain, wind, or extreme temperatures; make sure of the environment, being mindful of traffic and potential hazards; and most importantly make sure of your resources, such as water, food, and repair tools. These things are key before taking any cycling trip. They are very important in determining the type of trip you will have and ensure the difference between an enjoyable and relaxing trip, or a long and miserable trip, thus warranting careful consideration.

In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the setting affected the cyclist. It was a hot June day and the water supplies he had was running out. In the short story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting greatly affects the cyclist. For example, in the beginning of the story, the cyclist is eager to get to Yosemite National Park. He listens to the advice of “old-timers who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office,” and quickly realized that he shouldn’t have. The author describes the setting of the first “town” as “the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This didn’t bother the cyclist as much as his next sight. “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the largest mule” was what met him there. The cyclist said that “this sight was troubling,” as the desolation began to weigh on him. It is obvious that the cyclist has given up hope when he says, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This short story shows how anything can get even the best of travellers worried about their survival, as the harsh and unforgiving landscape chips away at their resolve.

I think the features of the settings affect the cyclist because the knowledge of the cyclist is limited; for example, "old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office" suggests that their understanding of the current cycling environment and road conditions is outdated. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because where he is riding it is very dry and hot. I hang my head.î This quote shows that the cyclist is in complete despair as he looks at the photo and hangs his head. The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affected the cyclist in the story. “Not two miles into this next reaction of ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie). The cyclist is travelling through hot, dry California in the middle of June without much water left. The fact that he now has to travel up and down short hills is going to make him even more tired, because going over hills requires more energy than flat riding. This energy loss, coupled with the cyclist's lack of water, causes him to become even more miserable. The heat intensifies his thirst as he exerts himself. The setting of this story greatly affected the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist's mood and behavior. First, believing the shortcut will help him arrive at Yosemite faster, the cyclist is optimistic; then, he realizes it won't. The setting affected the cyclist in a harsh way. At first, the cyclist was fine and going strong, but soon after the first ghost town he was getting weak. The conditions of the environment as well as the road can majorly affect the cyclist. In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the cyclist, on his way to Yosemite National Park, is forced to face the rough deserts of California. In the story ìRough Road ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî a cyclist is faced with many problems. Itís really hot out, practically a desert and its in June. At first, the narrator in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was energetic and enthusiastic about their journey to Yosemite National Park. After getting some helpful advice about a few shortcuts, the cyclist sets out for adventure. The first thing they encounter is a ghost town. The gentleman they had taken advice from had assured them it was a booming, prosperous town. This set the first wave of doubt through the cyclist's mind. Then, a lack of water began to take its toll. They were travelling through the high deserts of California in June and slowly running out of water. Flat road was soon replaced by short, rolling hills which only increased the cyclist's state of deliriousness. After a few more disappointments, including misleading signs and mirages that taunted with false hope, the cyclist decides there is no hope and they are going to die. The reader is partly drawn in, believing that this is the end for the cyclist. All of the disappointments set the stage for the end of the cyclist, and you can't stop reading because you have to find out what happens. If it weren't for the hopelessness of the setting, you wouldn't care, making the despair a crucial element that drives the narrative and keeps the reader invested in the cyclist's fate.

When the cyclist is going on his trip, he is riding through a desert. All he sees the entire journey is a flat road and dirt. He is riding on the road, hopelessly hoping for some form of life. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. The author is trying to be positive but it's hard, because all this scenery is doing is bringing his hopes down. How would you like it if you were riding a bike and had no water in the middle of a desert? Now, if the setting had been a nice, green forest, he wouldn't be that worried, there's water and shade. He has none of that in the desert, only the scorching sun and endless expanse. This whole journey was all mental; the physical hardship was immense, but the real battle was within. He always kept in his mind that everything would be ok, repeating mantras of hope and resilience. That is what helped him survive, pushing him forward when his body screamed for rest. This is an inspiring story, to anyone who needs a push to stay optimistic, a testament to the power of a positive mindset in overcoming adversity.

Poor directions, heat, and lack of water affect the cyclist in the story. At the beginning of the story, the cyclist is confident in the directions which would, ìslice away hours from my ride to Yosemite National Park.î As the story progresses, the cyclist is no longer so confident, realizing the map's promises were empty. The ìheat of the California, June day causes him to be fluent in drinking water.î "I had been hitting my water bottle pretty regularly, and I was travelling through the high deserts of California in June," he recalls, emphasizing the increasing desperation. This lack of water is a big problem for the cyclist, so big that he was near heat stroke, each pedal stroke a monumental effort. ìI eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.î He braved the elements and forced himself on, with hopes that any source of water would reveal itself to him, his vision blurring with exhaustion. His perseverance paid off, rewarding his resolve. ìThen, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me." The cyclist had found a barber shop and received water, a simple act of kindness that rejuvenated him, highlighting how crucial hydration is to endurance.

îDo not Exceed the posted speed limitî tells a story of learning and determination, as one cyclist bikes through the deserts of California, encountering obstacles such as snakes and a lack of water along the way. The descriptive features of the setting greatly affect the protagonist along his journey. The essay takes place in the early summer. As the cyclist prepares to retire for the day, he takes particular note of ìthe serenity of an early summer evening,î and ends the day feeling calm and at peace with his surroundings, ready for a good night's rest. The next morning he is excited and rejuvenated, ready to bike again, feeling the cool morning breeze on his face. The heat rises as the day goes on, and by mid-day the cyclist begins to worry about his water supply, carefully rationing what little he has left. He boldly continues forth reaching new terrain, rolling hills that seem to stretch endlessly before him. Here he begins to lose hope, and is disappointed when he sees the ìtownî he hoped to find is just an abandoned juice factory, a monument to broken dreams. The cyclist thinks he is going to die due to the heat and lack of hydration, his body screaming in protest, but gathers his strength to turn the final bend, and reaches a bait shop where he can stop and get water, finally finding relief and a renewed sense of hope. In conclusion, as the cyclist continues his journey through the California desert, the change in both weather and terrain coincide and affect the cyclistís change in physical and mental strength to continue traveling, highlighting the profound impact of the environment on the human spirit.

The setting in the essay “Rough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed the Speed Limit” affected the narrator in many ways. The first thing that affected his ride was the heat. At first he didn’t really notice, but then it began to slow him down. Then the ways of the roads began to affect his ride; the roads went from flat sheet to short, rolling hills.
