The complex features of the setting affect the cyclist negatively throughout this story. His trip goes from bad to worse as he progresses to Yosemite. After taking directions from the ìold codgers,î the author attempts the shortcut, but is dissapointed to find it far more challenging than anticipated. He arrives at the first town but it is completely deserted and eerily silent. He rubbed it off though, and kept ìthe cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,î as his motivation, visualizing the reward that awaited him. He pedaled on, but began to run out of water and his desperation increased; when he arrived at a well, he found the water to be inedible, further diminishing his morale, and continued onward. Just as if things couldnít get any worse his trail was getting rougher, becoming increasingly difficult to navigate, and his water supply was low, heightening his physical discomfort. The cyclist was becoming dehydrated, and began to lose hope that he'd ever reach his destination. He became even more of a pessimist when ìa ridiculously large snake- blocked the majority of the pavementÖî, symbolizing another seemingly insurmountable barrier. He kept going, and excitedly pedaled toward a building in the distance, but found it to be abandoned, dashing his hopes once more. He even put rocks in his mouth to help his dehydration, a testament to his dire situation. When he finally found the fish camp, he was relieved, feeling an overwhelming sense of accomplishment. All the obstacles he prospered through were worth it in the end, as the beauty of Yosemite finally became his reward.

The journey of a solo cyclist is a lonely one. The cyclist in ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî had a particularly hard journey, as made even worse by the setting. His main opponent in the battle of staying alive was the heat. In the California deserts on a day in June, it was no surprise that the sun would be beating down particularly harder than it would at another place anytime. Also, as the terrain became hillier, his journey became even harder. There is nothing hard about biking in a flat straight line. But constantly pedaling yourself up steep hills and around winding roads is no picnic. Just like the buildings around him, the cyclist’s water deteriorated, as did his state of mind, as his trip, which started out very joyful, became increasingly more morbid. ìIt didnít really matter, I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.î This cyclist was fighting against strong forces of nature, pushing his physical and mental limits to the brink. Ultimately, the cyclist's struggle highlights the immense challenges faced when battling both internal despair and the harshness of the natural world.

In the short story, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting plays an extremely important role. The story takes place in sunny California, where the cyclist was pedaling around 12 mph. The heat made his dehydration situation much worse. ìI was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.î The cyclist was losing hope, yet he was still determined to find water. This setting was very important to the story, for if it had taken place at @LOCATION1, @LOCATION3, it would not have made sense. The relentless sun beating down on the asphalt road, combined with the dry air, intensified his thirst and exhaustion. The setting contributes to the story by raising the intensity of the situation, making the cyclist's struggle for survival all the more compelling.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they started to mess with her mind. She didn’t know where she was and on top of that got lost. Whether you see nothing around you or a lot around you, you’re going to feel scared. They have the same effect. In the author's case, she was cycling and didn’t have any food or water. This is an overwhelming feeling because you can die from dehydration. She then kept cycling and saw nothing, “no one in sight; not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” That is isolating, no water or people around, as if you are going to be just left to die. These settings would affect anyone who came across them. They definitely affected the cyclist because she was by herself, and on her own. Plus, all she had was a map, her bike and an empty water bottle, making her situation even more precarious and contributing to her mounting fear and disorientation.

The features of this story tend to affect the cyclist very much. Because he took a shortcut he had an even longer journey than before. He was in the middle of nowhere with barely any water left and, on top of all that, he's exhausted from all the hills on the terrain. So because he took a shortcut it ended up costing him in the long run, demonstrating that sometimes the most direct route isn't always the most efficient or beneficial one.

The features of the setting in the essay affected the cyclist because first of all he listened to old folks that hadn’t left their front porch in about ten years. Then, he didn’t ask someone else’s opinion on where to go and how to get there, relying on unreliable advice. His worst mistake, though, was not trusting the map he had with him the whole time. If he would have just trusted his map and not gone with what the old fella said, he wouldn’t have almost died of heat stroke, highlighting the importance of preparation and reliable navigation.

In the essay, ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects him negatively because he was on his bicycle and he was in a hot area and no water whatsoever, like in this quote, ìI got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar like substance ozzed out.î In the quote, the cyclist finally thinks he has found a water pump, a potential source of relief from the oppressive heat, but he really gets nothing but a disappointing, unusable substance. Also, another negative thing is that he thought he was never going to get to where he was going, feeling the miles stretch endlessly before him under the scorching sun, but in the end, he got there and he got some water, a much-needed reward after a grueling journey, proving that even in the face of adversity, perseverance can lead to relief.

The setting in the story affects the main character greatly because of the heat. The main character is biking through a desert in the summer with little water. The heat of the setting provides a problem because the main character is at risk of dehydration and heatstroke. The main character knows that if he passes out in the barren desert he will surely die. The main character says, "The growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke" weighs heavily on his mind. The main character is faced with a problem of man versus nature and the heat is winning. Heat and dehydration sap the main character's energy while he is biking through a desert, desperately trying to make it to the next town for water. In summary, the main character's biggest problem is the heat of the setting.

The setting around the cyclist affected him in one main way. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ìtownî (Kurmaskie). The cyclist put the words towns in to parentasis because it was actually a Ghost town. No one lived there; it was abandoned. Around the cyclist were deserts, and more empty towns loomed in the distance, adding to his sense of isolation. The farther the cyclist got, the more he realized the old men were wrong, as the cyclist was running low on water and there was nowhere to stop for supplies, making him increasingly desperate. He finally found some water after hours of searching and vowed to never listen to old men's directions again, having learned a harsh lesson about trusting unreliable advice in a desolate landscape.

All the feature of the area have a have a big affect on the cyclist. It is a hot June morning, and he is on his bike, pedaling hard, going many miles. He can't find any water, because all the towns along the road are deserted. He is getting dehydrated, and losing strength. It seems like he might have collapsed if he hadn't thought he was going to reach salvation soon@CAPS1, and if he hadn't gotten some water at that store. All in all, the setting seems to have the intention of king him.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road: Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie affects the cyclist in a very negative way. It begins slowly with the “ghost town.” The narrator “chuckled, checked my water supply and moved on,” he wasn’t especially worried, but the fact he checked his water suggests that he’ll need to ration it for a while. The decline continues when he reaches the fork and the “ramshackle shed.” The description of the place shows you he did not like it, and he confirms that with the words, “this sight was troubling.” He wouldn’t be replenishing his water here, and the isolation is starting to weigh on him. Any more of this he’d be dead, either from dehydration or from pessimism. Eventually he reached the road sign which declared that going over 55 mph was a bad idea. This is ironic, he only going 12 mph; to put it in his own words, “sometimes life can be so cruel.” He quite obviously hates the setting, and it’s all the fault of the setting, which relentlessly chips away at his optimism and threatens his survival.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he had limited water, he had to peddle harder to get up over the hills and he was getting dehydrated from the heat. For example, he had limited water because he had taken the directions from the old men and probably didn't bring as much as he would have if he would have taken a longer way. This lack of preparation exacerbated the challenges he faced. Furthermore, to get up the rolling hills he had to peddle faster and harder. That affected him because he would have been more exhausted from peddling. The increased physical exertion further depleted his resources. Moreover, it was a June day and in June the days are hot; with the lack of a good amount of water the cyclist would have started to get dehydrated. The relentless sun intensified his physical strain. This is how the setting affected the cyclist, creating a perfect storm of challenges that made his ride significantly more difficult.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, his body heat raised a good bit. They don’t come out and say it, but they do say, “The sun was beginning to beat down.” We all know that if you're outside when it’s hot, you get hot too. The rising temperature also probably added to his dehydration. As a long distance runner, I know what the sun will do to you during a hot day, causing you to sweat more and lose fluids faster. That is how the setting affects the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way. For one, if the desert was not a deserted mountainous area in California then the cyclist would not have the same problems with heat exhaustion, lack of water, and potential wildlife encounters. By changing any one feature of the setting you would change how the cyclist would behave in the setting, perhaps leading to different choices regarding navigation or resource management. Thus changing the entire plot of the story. If the cyclist was say in the city or a merely developed area then he would not face the same dangers as if he were in a mountainous region, such as getting lost or facing extreme weather conditions. The setting's features have a huge affect on the cyclist, significantly shaping the challenges he faces and ultimately influencing the outcome of his journey.

In Joe Kurmaskie's story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting's features appear negative to the cyclist. The setting starts to worry the cyclist just two miles after he confidently predicted he could easily cover the next @NUM1 miles. For example, the cyclist states, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills,” indicating his concern that the journey wouldn't be as effortless as anticipated. From that point onward, the setting seems to deteriorate further for the cyclist. Later, the cyclist exclaims, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” This was when the cyclist began to truly notice his fear of dehydration, compounding the difficulties presented by the harsh environment. Ultimately, the cyclist perseveres and makes it through, realizing the profound impact nature can exert.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by unexpected things happening. His water supply got drank quickly, and he couldn’t find a town nearby. He was in the desert-like California landscape, and the sun was beating down on him, intensifying the heat. When he did find one town, it was more of a “ghost town,” and had rusted pumps that had battery-oil tasting liquid. Every person he asked told him the next town was near, but from dehydration, it took him longer to reach. The roads got windy, and small hills occurred, further draining his energy. There was a large snack in the middle of the road, as the tumble weed blew by, a testament to the desolation. He finally saw a town that had a bait shop and was able to get water and cool down, finally escaping the harsh environment. Therefore, the unforgiving setting posed numerous challenges to the cyclist, pushing him to his limits until he found respite.

The setting in ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limit definitely affected the author. The cyclist states, "Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The features of the setting affect the cyclist because if the old men didn't give the boy advice then he probably wouldn't have run into all the trouble he ran into. The features of the setting affects the cyclist by the roadís condition being rough as the cyclist rides further along the road, making the journey increasingly challenging and demanding more physical exertion with each passing mile.

The setting of this short story has a big affect on the cyclist. Since the story takes place in the desert, the temperature is very hot. The cyclist only packed enough water for the intended trip. During this essay the author is talking about his journey, a path marked not by grand adventures or exotic locales, but by a series of quiet shifts in perspective. It was a journey inward, a slow and sometimes painful unraveling of long-held beliefs and assumptions. It began, subtly, with a question, a persistent whisper of doubt that refused to be silenced. This initial inquiry then led to further reflection, forcing a confrontation with uncomfortable truths and a gradual reshaping of his understanding of the world and his place within it. The author’s journey, therefore, is one of continuous learning and self-discovery. And while the destination may remain elusive, the value lies in the transformative power of the journey itself, in the willingness to question, to learn, and to grow.

The setting included nice cool pines and then a ghost town, and it being hot out. There were banners of @CAPS1 and poison snacks, and hills that were getting harder to go up. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in several ways. The first was the terrain, which started out flat, then turned to hills. Not to mention the ìsandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth,î which would remind the body of its thirst, intensifying his craving. So the setting most definitely affected the cyclist.

In the story, the cyclist is greatly affected by the features of the setting. For example, the setting has nothing for miles, just ghost towns, making it impossible to find any water. Another example is the stone he put under his tongue, a trick that lets you survive a lot more effectively by stimulating saliva production. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. Three features I found were the lack of the water, the heat and the conditions and limits of the road. I think that the features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. First, I think the weather conditions affect him. I think this because in the passage it says, "I could drop from heatstroke". In ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affects the cyclist. The cyclist takes advice from some old guys and ends up wishing he never did. He is on an empty road, flat and dry. He ends up drinking all of the water he has, and needing to stop for some more. "I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." He stopped to get more water, but once, all that came out was some tar like stuff, and then he couldn’t find another place for quite a white. The flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills and he came to a sign that said ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limitî, and passed tumble weeds and a large snake. All of these things impacted his journey with fear, caution, etc. When he finally reached a place to get a drink, he was finally satisfied. Because it was hot, and empty, he was more thirsty so therefore the setting affected the cyclist. The arid climate, combined with the desolate landscape and the lack of accessible water sources, intensified his thirst and dictated his need for frequent hydration, illustrating how the environment directly influenced his physical state and actions.

He feels alone; there is no one around him to push him, and yet he keeps going, trying to push himself to the end to win. He grits his teeth, focusing on the finish line ahead. The fast roads are rough, and the hills are tall, testing his endurance, but he is determined to finish, fueled by an inner fire that refuses to be extinguished. He will see this through, no matter the obstacles.

Heat, abandoned roads, snakes all are reasons that affected the cyclist. The relentless heat made him get dehydrated faster while he was using energy to pedal. The long abandoned roads, cracked and overgrown, further increased his doubt of surviving the whole bike ride. He used up all of his water quickly. So when he finally got to the old pump, sputtering and groaning, only hot dirty water came out. The snake slithering across his path in the story made the journey for this guy even more perilous and deadly. This all happened because he stubbornly refused to listen to the old guys' advice initially. When the other old guy was about to tell him where to go, offering crucial directions, he confidently said no, sealing his unfortunate fate; this decision ultimately contributed to the cyclist's struggles.

The features and the setting affect the cyclist a lot. One reason was that he was in the desert. Like in the quote “through high deserts of California,” this means that it was hot and he could pass out from a heat stroke. Then he couldn’t even get any water. Like on the quote “of the rusted water pump,” it was describing how old it was; then the cyclist got some out, but it tasted like old battery acid, making it undrinkable and unhelpful. The features of the setting intensely effect the cyclist over period of time. Destined to reach Yosemite National Park from Lodi, California, a determined cyclist rode strongly through the gentle evening. When the setting changed, so did the effect it had on the cyclist. When the man reached the first town, which was deserted, energy began depleting because the sun began to come into the picture, beating down with increasing intensity. Next, he came to a shed desperate for water only to find rusty pumps with tainted, unsafe water, adding to his despair. When the flat terrain turned to rolling hills, the man was entirely exhausted. “With what I believed to be my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill.” That quote directly describes what the man was feeling and how the hills effected him. When the man stumbled across a fish camp with water, he became reloaded and replenished with confidence he had before when he “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile.” Therefore, the cyclist's journey highlights how deeply physical and mental states are intertwined with and shaped by the environment.

The setting affected the cyclist in many ways. For example he was riding in the desert and all the towns he was going to were abandoned, adding to his sense of isolation. And he was cycling with very little water, making the already harsh conditions even more perilous for his journey.

In the essay ìDo Not @CAPS1 Posted Speed Limitî the setting effects the cyclist in many ways. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, he described it as a ghost town. The authorís setting described a difficult terrain and harsh weather for bike riding. The author said that it was early summer which means it could be hot and uncomfortable weather for the cyclist. The author also said that when the cyclist reached the first town, the sun began to beat down. That means the temperature is going to rise since the sun is getting stronger. This gives you a sense of how much hotter it is since heís traveling through deserts during early summer while the sun is high. The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. From the ghost town to the bait shop, it was all a challenge for him. A misleading challenge, but a challenge. In the desert is where water grew short, and he tried everything to push himself. From staring at the horizon to get from one place to another, from sucking on pebble stones to not focus on water. And when he arrived at the bait shop, a sense of relief came to him, like that shop was his safe haven. But yet he would never get directions from any old-timer again. Lack was not a factor in this story; rather, it was drive and the overall climate of the story. When it was two hundred degrees left, and no water left, he pushed himself to the light. And also when he saw a building, he was determined to get to it, proving his resilience in the face of harsh conditions and the deceptive nature of the landscape.

The cyclist was trying to make it to Yosemite National Park. The cyclist was in Lodi, California when he decided to ask for directions from old codgers so that he could take a short cut. The shortcut, a well-intentioned but ultimately misguided piece of advice, had led him to the brink of exhaustion, a stark reminder that sometimes the well-trodden path is the safest one to follow.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in many ways. The scenery makes the cyclist turn worried, unconfident, and in the end an ironic hopeful. He also couldn’t refill water supply, so fear of dehydration also kicked in. Already tired, the cyclist became unconfident when he came upon the sign reading, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit". Knowing that this was going to be a long and slow journey, the cyclist becomes unconfident that he can make it. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed posted speed limit” the cyclist has some very rough obstacles on his way to Yosemite National Park. The features of the setting effect the cyclist on different occasions in different ways. In the short story ìRough road ahead .Do not exceed posted speed limit ,î the cyclist faced many difficulties. These difficulties were the result of the setting. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many different ways. One way is the hilly terrain makes him work harder and wears him out physically. The feature effect the cyclist because he wants to go somewhere spectacular and amazing. The setting can affect a cyclist in many ways; if it were hot out, he would be thirsty and sweaty. If there were hills, the cyclist would be tired as well as thirsty. The cyclist, although thirsty and tired, is determined to get through and find a town. The cyclist said, “I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” By saying this, he knows that he can make it that far and is determined to do so, demonstrating mental fortitude. With the challenging terrain causing even more trouble for him, it would make it more difficult, but he knows that he must overcome his challenging activity, and he still keeps a strong spirit. Ultimately, with that strong spirit, he can do just about anything because he has the encouragement he needs to push through and achieve his goal.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making his mood change. In the shaded woods, where itís nice, shaded, and cool, he feels fairly good. Heís excited and ready to take on the adventure of a new path. Heís still in a good mood when he comes to the first town. As he moves on, and his water supply deplets, his mood sinks lower and he becomes more frustrated with the growing heat and relentless sun. In the ironic twist of fate that he finds a Welchís Grape Juice, Factory, a mirage of refreshment that offers no actual water, he is about to quit. He is dejected and almost ready to admit defeat against the harsh landscape. But he forces himself to go on, driven by some stubborn inner will, and when he finally reaches a place with water, his relief is mixed with wariness of the old man sitting on the porch. He will never take water for granted or advice from old men ever again, his experience forever shaping his perspective.

The features of the setting only drain the cyclist's willpower. The things he sees discourage him, for example one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold the largest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. The desolation begins to wear away his hope of finding a building or town, sometimes the things are psychologically damaging. In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building abandoned years earlier, by the looks of it – had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still be seen. For someone who is quickly running out of water, this irony could make one lose their resolve to continue. The snake and rolling hills slow him down, and make him use more energy, demanding more water. The heat dehydrates the cyclist even faster, baking the cracked earth around him. The environment is a hostile one for a cyclist, relentlessly chipping away at his determination and pushing him closer to his breaking point.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. The setting affected the cyclist because of the bad condition roads. The roads were bumpy and uneven, making it difficult to maintain speed and control. ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kindî. The main features that affected the cyclist were the rough terrain and the hot sun. The features of the setting in the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speed limitî affect the cyclist. As the cyclist rides to his destination, he encounters obstacles and views his surroundings. The author gives the starting setting in the second paragraph as ìa reservoir campground outside of lodi, California an early. Summer evening.î The reader is informed that the temperatures are not in summers in California. This gives the cyclist his main conflict, the lack of water. With temperatures being high, it is easier to become quickly dehydrated, thus adding to the struggle. The author stated, ìThe sun was beginning to beat down and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June. Also, to cyclist encounters a ridiculously largeî snake in the middle of the rode. The reader is aware that there are many conflicts which one can encounter while cycling. There are finally many features of the setting that let the cyclist know where he currently is, and the place where he wants to be most, the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite. The features of the desert changed the way the speaker thought about his journey. When the road began to change, the speaker’s determination did too, ìFlat road were replaced by short hillsî. The terrain began to change and the speaker became doubtful of the old man that directed him towards the shortcut. ìI could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadnít been off their porch in decadesî. The heat in the desert made the speaker thirsty, causing him to drink all his water. There was no source of water therefore he decided to suck on a stone. ìIíd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirstî. But the bumpy terrain didn’t allow him to do that, as the rough path jostled him constantly. He hit a bump and swallowed the stone. The speaker began to panic, ìI was going to die and the birds would pick me cleanî. But luckily the author's thoughts changed after he found a supply of water, proving how much the challenging features of the desert affected the cyclist, influencing both his physical state and mental outlook on the trip.

The setting affects the cyclist in a very negative way due to the lack of buildings, people, and cars on his ìshortcutî he was in great doubt of his survival. The relentless sun beat down, and the cracked asphalt radiated heat, amplifying his distress. ìI was going to die, and the birds would pick me clean.î He thought he wouldnít get any water because there was nothing around him, just endless stretches of desolate landscape, and he thought he would die of dehydration or heatstroke. ìAnd the growing realization that I would die of heatstrokeî further cemented his despair, highlighting the harsh reality of his isolated predicament.

The setting of the story had affected the bike rider in many ways. It was hot when he was riding so he was thirsty. For example, “The sun was beginning to beat down” (pg @NUM1). So the sun is very exhausting and made him start dehydrating. Another example is “traveling through the desert of California in June” (pg @NUM2). California is a relatively hot state and June is one of its warmer months. The terrain didn’t favor the rider either; “Flat road had turned into short, rolling hills” (pg @NUM2). Short, rolling hills are harder on a biker's body than flat terrain. This combination of heat and difficult terrain demonstrates how the setting negatively affected the rider's experience and physical state.

The setting affected the cyclist because it was in June and it was starting to get hot. In the book, it said he was going through the desert. In this paragraph I will explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The setting affect the cyclist in ways such as weather, road structure, & animals. The features of the setting in this story gives the cyclist determination. Since the desert stretched endlessly before him, an ocean of sand and sun, each mile marked only by the dwindling water in his pack, the sheer desolation fueled his resolve. The oppressive heat, shimmering off the dunes, became a challenge to overcome, a tangible enemy against which his will could be tested and ultimately triumph. The silence, broken only by the whirring of his tires and his own ragged breath, allowed him to focus solely on the present moment, on the next rotation of the pedals, solidifying his determination to reach the distant horizon.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it is very hot and it is summertime. The text also states there were rolling hills and tumbleweeds, so it must have been a desert kind of area. The trip was also a very long one, “about forty miles into the pedal,” causing him to be tired and dehydrated. As you can see, the setting, with its intense heat and isolation, significantly contributed to the cyclist's exhaustion on this long desert ride.

The features of the setting are very important for cyclists. If the setting is wrong, they could be in many dangers, such as collisions with vehicles or pedestrians, or hazards due to poor road conditions. It is really important to have a clear setting, encompassing well-maintained roads, adequate lighting, and designated cycling lanes. By ensuring a safe and well-defined environment, we can significantly reduce the risks cyclists face and promote safer cycling practices.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist horribly! For example, he ran into the worse problems and couldnt really do anything about them. Throughout his journey, the protagonist in the story encounters obstacles in the setting. First off, he is cycling in the hot, dry, desert. The features in the setting would affect the cyclist because they would want to have towns with water so they can restock their water. They would also want a place to get something to eat and maybe rest their legs, allowing them to continue their journey refreshed. These features are vital for a cyclist undertaking a long journey.

The feature of the setting affects the cyclist because of the intense heat and lack of water. Also, the rough road ahead was a significant challenge. This confluence of harsh environmental conditions and the cyclist's grim acceptance of his fate demonstrates how powerfully the setting affected the cyclist's physical and mental state.

The hot, dry, desert setting affects the cyclist in many different ways, ìI was traveling through the high deserts of California in Juneî (@NUM1). The cyclist is very hot. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because when he has water and plenty of it, the setting seems to be smooth, easy riding. There are many ways that the features affect the cyclist. One is that he is already scared to go up this really big hill. After reading, “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit,” I noticed that the setting of this adventure affected the narrator. First of all, the heat caused the narrator to be uncomfortable and thirstier, as the sun beat down relentlessly. While on the move, he refers to the trip as a “water-depleting” one; this quote shows that he was lacking water and that this was a major problem, impacting his focus. Also it refers to the road as “rolling hills", and this shows the reader that they seem to go on forever, creating a monotonous landscape. This lowers the narrator’s hope of getting there quickly, making the journey seem even longer. Also the desert gives the author low hope of reaching his destination, with its barrenness suggesting a lack of resources or respite. The setting affects the narrator both physically and mentally, impacting his well-being and outlook.

The setting of the story affected the cyclist because it kept him going because he was all alone and had no help. First, just the fact that he was by himself kept his determination high. The isolation meant he had to rely solely on his own strength and resolve. If he would have had a partner they could have stopped and took a break or shared the water. Next, the fact that there were no buildings, houses or anything in sight affected him. The desolate landscape amplified his sense of isolation and the need to persevere. He got a bolt of strength just from seeing a building ahead. If there had been building he could have stopped and asked for more water and rested. The fact that he was in a desert in California in the middle of June really affected him. The intense heat and arid environment presented a constant physical challenge. He had no determination there because there was nothing he could do to better the situation in his cause. He even at one point felt that he might die. In conclusion the setting really affected the cyclist because it determined his endurance and will power.

Features of the setting affected the cyclist in many different ways. For example, he asked the older guys, "that haven't left their porches since Carter was in the office," where the next place was to get water. Also, he was out in the middle of nowhere. It was also in June where the weather was warm, and he didn't have a lot of water, which made the journey more challenging. The combination of isolation, heat, and limited resources created a difficult situation for the cyclist.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. First, he was in "high desert of California in June." This affected him in many ways. It makes him become very dehydrated due to the intense heat. He had to conserve his water and chew on pebbles to get any spit to collect in his mouth, just to relieve his parched throat. Also, the road became very rough and uneven. The new terrain made him have to push himself harder and lose energy quicker as he struggled against the unyielding ground. The last feature would be the distance he had to travel. He had to travel a lot further than he had planned to. This again affected his energy and spirits with thoughts of possible death and not being able to make it to his destination alive. Those are just some of the ways the features of the setting affected the cyclist, both physically and mentally, testing his limits of endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He tried to recall how far the next town was, but his mind was hazy from the heat and exertion.

The features of setting affect the cyclist. The harsh terrain proved a challenge when his water supply was low and all towns had been abandoned, leaving him no refill. The relentless heat was also a significant factor, quickly creating weariness and fatigue. On the bike ride, he experienced a glimmer of hope at an old water pump but was quickly disappointed when the hot liquid tasted of battery acid. The setting, with its arid landscape and scarcity, set the conflict and helped achieve the tone the author was looking for to affect the cyclist, emphasizing his struggle against a desolate environment.

The settings effect the cyclist by the roughness of the ride. First, they go over a bunch of rocks, and the tire could pop. Next it could be smooth and easy, offering a welcome relief. Also, it could be far away from towns and difficult to get back, leaving the cyclist stranded. There could be a lack of water making you dehydrate, impacting performance and health. That is how the setting around the cyclist could effect him, highlighting the importance of preparation and awareness of the surrounding environment.

The setting presented in the story, "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit," would be a nightmare for any biker. This biker is riding in the middle of a desert on a summer’s day. The sweat dropping down him is just speeding up his dehydration. This is shown when the narration states, "wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that i could drop from heatstroke" (Kurmaskie). This shows how hot the desert was, and how he could drop dead. The desert is also deserted with rolling tumbleweeds and giant snakes, as he passed abandoned towns and factories, adding to the desolate atmosphere. The dangerousness for a biker in this area is very high, considering the environmental factors and isolation. The biker was lucky to have made it out of those surroundings alive.

The desert area of California was making him dehydrated. The long trip required careful water management, and he had enough to reach his destination only if he took the mapped route. The old men, who he thought hadn't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office, told him a shortcut. He followed their advice and ended up almost dying from heat stroke and dehydration. If the cyclist would have followed the map, he could have stopped off at a store for more water, assuming the desert setting was as unforgiving as it proved to be. Ultimately, trusting the locals' ill-conceived shortcut jeopardized his journey and his health.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The setting was a dry California desert, for if it had been a busting city, the events in the story would have not happened. The author asked a group of old men for directions to Yosemite National Park, and, ìlike a foolish youth,î followed their advice. Everything started out fine until he reached the second town. He ran almost dehydrated and ìin an ironic twistî he reached an abandoned grape juice factory. Almost all hope was lost for him until he rounded the bend and came across his new hope: ìGary and Wilberís Fish camp-if you want bait for the big ones, weíre your best bet.î In the end he learned to stick to a map instead of old people who ìhavenít left the confines of their porches, their car, or their office,î showing the importance of reliable navigation in such an unforgiving environment.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because first he realized that getting advise from people that no longer drive or even leave of the porch would be unuseful. When the author say ìold timers who havenít lest the confined of them porches since carter was in officeî that what he is explaining, highlighting the disconnect between their outdated knowledge and his current experience. He then say ìI rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my faceî he was refering back to how hes on the rode alone riding the bike and theres not a car insight any where around, emphasizing the freedom and solitude he found. The curbs of the turns where so sharp that only a bicycle could make them as safe as he did ìHe whipped the sweat from his eyes to make sure it wasnít mirage and tried not get to excitedî This unique situation would have made many people excited about the long lonely cicle by his self. Ultimately, the setting, with its lack of traffic and challenging turns, contributed to the cyclist's excitement and sense of accomplishment.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making his way to the Yosemite National Park a longer, more difficult, and dangerous way to go. He takes the dare of going that way, defying the warnings of some old folks that he says “haven’t gotten off their porches since Carter was in office.” Despite their potential wisdom, there would be a reason to disregard their advice, even though their experience might be valuable; the cyclist’s youthful exuberance and desire for adventure outweigh the perceived risks in his mind. Therefore, he continues undeterred, highlighting a generational difference in risk assessment and the allure of the unknown.

In the setting there are no cars and no buildings meaning no help available. The cyclist, weary and parched, was tired and dehydrated because he ran out of water. The relentless sun beat down as no one was around because it was the desert. The cyclist was dehydrated but kept going, driven by the hope of reaching his destination. The road was straight for a long while, but almost to the end there were many hills, testing his strength. Along with having to bike up the hills, his vision blurred from the heat, he almost ran into a snake, startled by its sudden appearance. The weather was hot and unforgiving; he had no water, he could have died if he didn't push through. Despite the odds, he persevered, his determination ultimately seeing him through the arduous journey.

The features in the setting in the story "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" greatly affect the biker. For example, the heat is constantly drying the biker out, making the ride physically taxing. Also, at the first town, the old water pump proved to be a hopeless cause with water that tasted like "battery acid", offering no respite from the thirst. Even after that, there were more problems. There was a sign that posted a max speed limit, a cruel reminder of how slow he was going. The biker was doing about one-fifth of that speed. This affects his mood, and he realizes that it will be a long ride, both physically and mentally. The pebbles that he found help him out marginally. He remembers reading that sticking pebbles in your mouth calms your thirst, a small comfort in the vast landscape. Finally, the bait store gave him the relief that he needed at the end of his trip, marking the end of his struggle. In conclusion, the setting makes the rider's journey a difficult one, but in the end, the bait store had just what he needed, providing a welcome conclusion to his arduous journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist. For example, there were no towns close nearby. In addition, he could have a heatstroke and there would be no one around to get help from, and he could easily die from the exposure. In my point of view of the reading, I believe where he was located is what affected him mostly, because the scarcity of resources and isolation significantly amplified any potential risks he faced.

The hot weather is dehydrating the cyclist, who can’t find more water. The sun beats down relentlessly. The hills and rough terrain are draining the energy he has. The features of the setting affect the cyclist on how the nature of life he was hydrated or not. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The cyclist from the essay ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit, ìby Joe Kurmaskie had many obstacles to overcome. The setting where the cyclist is at is in a desert, and it can affect him because he could get a heatstroke. The setting of this story is a dry, hot desert in the middle of June. These features of the setting effect the author, because it shows how he starts off strong and determined and is left weak and doubtful. In the beginning of the story, the author says, “Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.” This is showing the reader the confidence he has with himself before starting his trip. Later on in the story, he describes the setting as “the high deserts of California in June.” He is describing the heat and what he is facing. It goes on to tell how he is dehydrated and worn out, highlighting the harsh conditions. But he comes to a town, "cool water dripping from my head as I slumped against the wall." He is relieved, demonstrating the impact of escaping the oppressive environment. As the setting changes, the author's attitude changes as well, illustrating how the environment can dramatically influence one's physical and mental state.

Different features of the setting affect a cyclist; for example, temperature really changes everything. If it’s too hot, you’re going to get tired really easily, due to increased perspiration and dehydration. Then again, if it's too cold, breathing gets really hard and muscles can stiffen. The biker in the story was in a desert area in June, so it was really hot and tiring, making hydration crucial. Also, the terrain affects a cyclist. If the road is filled with hills, getting up those hills is difficult, requiring more energy and strength. If it’s all downhill, it’s really easy, but all uphill is hard; level terrain is fairly easy, allowing for consistent speed. The cyclist in the story was in level terrain, then it turned into a lot of hills, which tired him out considerably, impacting his overall performance and endurance. Therefore, the environmental conditions and the landscape significantly determine the cyclist’s experience.

The setting affects the cyclist because he is faced with roadways he is unsure of, making navigation difficult. The weather is hot and dry, which can lead to dehydration and exhaustion during his ride. Furthermore, the presence of wild animals poses a potential safety risk, adding to the challenges he must overcome. These environmental factors collectively impact his journey and well-being.

The setting has a great impact on the condition of the cyclist. First, it is a very hot dry in June, with the sun beating down mercilessly. The cyclist is maneuvering his way through high deserts in @LOCATION1, where the arid landscape stretches out before him. He comes across many steep hills that he must climb over, straining his muscles, and then carefully maneuver his way down the other side, testing his brakes and control. With all of these obstacles and the heat slowing him down considerably, sapping his energy, he will need water but is already low on his supply, making his situation increasingly precarious.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” the narrator is faced with the challenging and perilous desert he must cross. He wasn't traveling in a car, he was riding a bike, and crossing a desert on foot is tiring enough, let alone on a bike. "The speed limit was 25. I was doing a water depleting 5. Sometimes life can be so cruel." In the horrible 110 degree heat the narrator gulps down his water bottles at such a rate that he’s at risk of running out. Not only that, but he’s been pedaling for such a long time that he could pass out from exhaustion or, "I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades." So I would say the narrator was pretty hassled by his surroundings, and his journey was fraught with danger and discomfort.

The setting affected the character in ways that would usually affect people. When he got into the first town he had ran out of water to drink but the town’s water he was in now tasted like battery acid so that’s not safe to drink. As he started to head out the scenery changed. “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This is hinting at the fact that maybe this town he is going to be abandoned or not used. He saw a huge rattle snake and tumbleweed, which are usual signs of a desert, further isolating him. It was hard for him to keep his balance as he says, “trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” He ended up getting to the point where he had to put rocks in his mouth to trick his mind that he wasn’t thirsty anymore, a desperate measure highlighting the severity of his situation and the unforgiving nature of the environment.

The feature of the setting affected the cyclist because at first he had to watch out for the snakes that usually crossed the roads, then the streets were crooked and bumpy, so the road structure throw him off a bit, and he was riding his bike in June and it was very hot, and he had lack of water so he thought he was going to have a heatstroke. These environmental factors significantly impacted the cyclist's energy and concentration. These things affected how the cyclist performed on his bike, ultimately hindering his speed and overall enjoyment of the ride.

The cyclist is riding through the high deserts in California. In this environment everything looks the same for miles. The cyclist is dehydrated and is getting worse because he has no protection from the sun. It is hard for the cyclist to keep in good spirits because he is not even coming across any towns or sources of water. The cyclist says “About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ‘town.’" This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time- say before the last world war- but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.” This made the cyclist doubt the old timers directions. In the wide open desert, the cyclist was only coming across something after at least twenty miles. The heat, lack of water, and lack of civilization made the cyclist think he was “going to die and the birds would pick [him] clean." When the cyclist spots the abandoned Welch’s factory, the cyclist says they used what seemed to be their last bit of energy. The conditions affected the cyclist, and the cyclist found it hard to remain positive given the circumstances of the challenging desert terrain.

The setting affects the cyclist by showing that he is a little angry. He states that “I don’t remember the saying ‘don’t take candy from strangers.’” So we know he is upset about something. He is mad about the fact that this one older man tells him directions on how to get somewhere, and it’s wrong, and the man figures that out halfway through the story. He also said that “the old man hasn’t been off his porch since Carter was in office,” so he needs to get his directions up to date. It is clear that the cyclist's frustration is fueled by the outdated advice, leading to a negative attitude at the beginning of his journey.

In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the settings affected the character because he thought he wouldnít make it to the park because of the way things looked around him. The desolate landscape, with its implication of danger, heightened his anxiety about time. Because of the rolling hills and snakes he didnít think he would make it any where and thought he was going to die. Thatís how the setting affected the character, creating a sense of foreboding that significantly influenced his perception and actions.

While the cyclist was trying to get to Yosemite National Park he listened to some old men who gave him directions for a shortcut. When he began his trip everything was fine. But then he found that along the "shortcut" there was no building. By the time he figured out that the old men were mistaken, he had almost run out of water. There was nothing around that he could drink, not even a puddle. He was getting very thirsty. The fact that he was in the deserts of California in June didn't make his task any easier, as the sun beat down relentlessly. About halfway through his ride he ran into rolling hills, which made his trip even harder, forcing him to dismount and push his bike. Towards the end he found a building and he used all of his strength to get to it, just to find that it was an abandoned juice factory. This made going without water much harder, as well as he gazed at the picture of the boy who was drinking juice on a faded billboard. In the end he finally made it to a paint shop where he guzzled all the water he possibly could, finally quenching his desperate thirst.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist greatly. For example when he was riding on the road he would pick a destination and ride to it. Then he would take a break. If this destination was a building he would be strong willed and determined, pushing himself to reach the solid structure. If it looked like their was nothing ahead but hills, he would just ride and wait to fall over dead without a care in the world, the endless slopes sapping his motivation. Ultimately, the landscape dictated not just his route, but his very spirit.

One ramsackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubled and forlorn. There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind to break the desolate landscape. With any luck, Iíd hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. Rough road ahead if he didnít take the old mans advice; he would have enjoyed his bike ride if he had heeded the warning, and he needed a new map to navigate this forsaken place.

The features in the story affect the cyclist by not having anything to drink. The person was going to a place far away without any food or water for miles, and this lack of sustenance could have been deadly. There is another feature that affects the cyclist, and that is the isolation, with no one around for miles. If he collapsed out there, no one would know for days, delaying any potential rescue. I know this because in the story he said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car or structure of any kind.” That says it all about the desolation of the location. The last feature is that it was hot. I know this because it says, “I was traveling through high deserts of California in June.” It is hot in June, and it is even hotter in California, and the heat makes the journey significantly more dangerous due to the risk of dehydration and heatstroke, compounding the lack of available water. These environmental factors create a precarious situation for the cyclist.

People who travel will almost always encounter difficulties. For the main character in this story, this is very true. He said, "what I shouldn't have done was to let them see my map". Another problem he faced was when he began to run out of water. This caused a problem for him because of dehydration. In the story he said, "The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips." Also, another problem he encountered was the desert area that he was riding through. This caused a problem for him because there wasn't anybody around to help him if he needed it. In the story he says, "There was no one in sight, not a building, cars, or structure of any kind." By reading this story, we’ve realized that people encounter problems everywhere; however, any problem, no matter what size, can be overcome, as the main character's resilience shows us the possibility of triumphing over the challenges that arise during travel.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because on page @NUM1 it talks about how the cyclist had to go down a hill then find a factory for juice. The setting in the story reflects upon the cyclist. In the story a cyclist is riding his bike and takes directions from some old men sitting on a porch. The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him dehydrated and hot. The features of the setting affect the cyclistís mood throughout the essay. Joe @CAPS1 starts with being happy and confident to determined yet helpless and then to relief. The features of the setting affects the cyclist because when all the cyclist is worried about is finding a place with water all he's doing is getting scared and panicking. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in different ways. The woman who had listened to the older men to get where she was going had made her run out of water and almost died of thirst. He was affected by lack of water, the hills, a snake in the way, and the condition of the road. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, explaining how the lack of water was a problem. The hills affected him, as they were "crippling." The snake was a long ways on the road, and he didn’t know how to get past it. Finally, the roads were rough, and you shouldn’t go over the speed limit of 55 mph. So, he was affected in a lot of different ways, highlighting the multiple challenges he faced.

The features of the barren desert path make the cyclist quite nervous, but they also make him determined to escape them. He passes ìghost towns,î ìabandoned buildings,î and diamondback snakes. These are images traditionally associated with being lost in the deserts, and would be enough to instill fear in most anyone travelling alone. The author even remarks that sadists are probably finding his story pleasing. He often mentions fears of ìdroppingî dead, being eaten by vultures, and, at one point, even wishing death upon himself via choking albeit jokingly. And yet he was determined to live. In spite of the odds stacked against him, he moved on, even after losing ìwhat (he) believed to be (his) lost burst energy." He even maintains a sense of humor throughout, writing of a diary entry that would be left behind that remarks on the wisdom of old men. In the end, when he finds a place to rest, he turns it all into a lesson heíll surely abide by: follow the map! This journey, though fraught with peril and existential dread, ultimately reinforces his will to survive and learn from his mistakes.

The cyclist is affected by the heat, the hills, and the lack of people. For example, the cyclist was growing short on water and had "wide rings of dried sweat on his shirt," and he could "drop from heatstroke." The hills must have forced him to use more energy, draining him further. Lastly, the lack of people exacerbated his situation. If the towns still had people, the cyclist wouldn't have been as affected by the setting, as he could have potentially resupplied or sought assistance.

Features of any setting affect what you do and how you do it. Features affect the cyclist by water, help, and safety. The cyclist's desperate need for water is highlighted when he sucks on a rock to circulate his saliva, attempting to alleviate his thirst. The rough terrain and the outdated, abandoned road, recommended by the old men, leave him isolated, unable to find directions or confirm his route. Encountering a snake along this desolate path underscores the danger; a bite, far from civilization, could prove fatal due to the lack of immediate medical help. Similarly, the risk of heatstroke is magnified by the absence of water and assistance. Safety, help, and water are critical factors, and these environmental features significantly impact the cyclist's journey and well-being.

The features of the setting make the ride for the cyclist very hard. It has a lot of hills, which would make him use more energy. Also, it is a desert, so it is very hot and dry. This makes the author need more water than he normally would. The cyclist’s features around him affected him negatively. He was cycling through “the high deserts of California in June” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). He lost hope after that landscape, and he pretty much gave up, as the mirage of refreshment only deepened his despair. The setting affects the cyclist because there were lots of hills, making the ride physically demanding, and very little water, leading to dehydration and fatigue. The cyclist in the story “Rough Road Ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, is heavily affected by the features of the setting in the story. Many features of the setting affected the cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie. One feature that affected the character was the heat of the sun. The features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist in the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî. In the story it says, "I was traveling through the high desert of California in June." In the essay "Rough Road Ahead; Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting is integral to how the cyclist feels and behaves. The cyclist feels a growing desperation as the setting around him gets progressively more bleak. In the beginning of the trip, the cyclist encounters a ghost town. "I chuckled, checked my water supply, and moved on." The cyclist is still thinking positively at this point in the essay, demonstrating a resilience fueled by the initial novelty of the journey. A while later, the cyclist comes across another abandoned set of buildings. He feels that this sight is "troubling." The cyclist is worried, he is not yet depressive and pessimistic, but the increasing desolation is clearly starting to wear on his spirits. Farther down the road, the terrain of the road changes, and he sees the sign that gives the essay its name." The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water depleting 8. Sometimes life’s can feel so cruel." The cyclist’s surroundings get progressively worse as he rides on, but eventually he finds a place with working water. He is so overjoyed by this building that he wants to find the owners, and kiss them. This profound shift in emotion, from despair to elation, underscores how deeply the environment shapes his internal state, proving the setting's crucial role in dictating the cyclist's feelings and actions throughout his arduous journey.

The setting of the essay ìDo not exceed posted speed limit," is very dry, sandy, hot, and deserted. On his way to Yosemite he takes a ìshort cut" so he goes through the desert.
