He can keep his hopes for himself and follow a true set of directions, maintaining control over his journey despite the harsh environment.

Anyone who has ever rode a bike knows how relaxing it can truly be, but when you are forced to ride miles and miles on unforgiving terrain without any water, relaxation feels like an oasis, especially going through beat-up roads with dryness all around you really puts a damper on your experience, as it extends your need for thirst by enhancing the amount of dryness in the air and the amount of energy you are having. The ability to block all of that out and trying to focus on something easier to handle is exactly what you want to do in these situations, that unforgiving terrain can really build character into a cyclist, but adding the fact the amount of water he had was none, and the dryness around him, it sounds like torture. I can only hope that if I ever become a cyclist, I never have to endure this kind of situation.

The cyclist, Joe Kurmaskie, had a rough time traveling to Yosemite National Park. Granted he was misled, but if the conditions of the terrain and if the climate were working for him it would've made life a whole lot easier. Not only was it hot, being in a desert in California in June, but he only had one water bottle. One water bottle wouldn’t have lasted a little longer if it was a straight shot through, but it wasn’t. The roads went up, down, there were hills, there were towns-ghost towns at that. The only water he could pump from the pump was scalding hot and tasted acidic. Also, he wouldn’t have lost as much energy if it was a straight shot. It’s easy to say that he literally roughed it, having to resort to putting rocks in his mouth to circulate saliva. All in all, he was very determined to work through the very unfortunate conditions he had working against him, and very lucky to survive it.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the fact that he is pedaling a bike through the high deserts of California in June makes the intensity level of the story very high. The scorching sun beating down and the dry air make each pedal stroke a monumental effort. If it would have been springtime and there was a nice breeze, it would be different; the ride would be more pleasant, and the physical challenge diminished significantly, altering the narrative's tone. Therefore, the harshness of the environment directly shapes the cyclist's experience and the overall story's tension.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by lack of water, a poisonous snake, and the condition of the road. For example, the lack of water affected the cyclist because he couldn't make it without water; he could have passed out if he didn't have water, especially under the hot sun. Another example of how the setting affected the cyclist would be the poisonous snake; if he had gotten bitten, he could have died because there would be nobody to help him in the remote location, and antivenom might not be readily available. And the last example of how the setting affected him would be the condition of the road because it made it tougher for the cyclist to get to his destination with hills and windy rounds, slowing his progress and increasing his exertion. This is how I think the setting affected the cyclist and presented significant challenges to his journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that if it's hot and you're riding a long way you need a lot of water so you don't get dehydrated, potentially impacting performance. Also, it can affect your vision because you're looking at the sun, possibly causing glare and impacting visibility. Another way cyclists can get affected by the setting is because what if the road is all bumpy and just not in good shape; it can affect the way they ride their bike, leading to discomfort or even accidents. The environment clearly plays a crucial role in a cyclist's experience and safety.

The story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by @PERSON1 had some statements that were kind of pointless to put in. One sentence in the essay had a couple of words that don’t need to be used. In the sentence, "about forty miles into the pedal, I arrive at the first 'town,'" I don’t think "into the pedal" needs to be in there because it’s not describing anything relevant to the arrival at the town. Removing it would make the sentence more concise and direct, focusing on the distance and the destination.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is, the setting. The cyclist is out in the dessert, in two-hundred degree weather, with very little water. Also, the cyclist didn`t have a map and he asked someone that hasn`t left their porch since Carter was in office. ''Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn`t been off their porch in decades.'' This quote talks about how the setting can affect him. The extreme heat and lack of resources, exacerbated by poor directions, created a dangerous situation. Also, he listened to someone that didn't know what they were talking about. In conclusion that is how the features of setting affected the cyclist.

The story unfolds in a harsh, desert-like setting, a sweltering expanse where the protagonist pushes his physical limits to survive. The road is unforgiving, a gauntlet of rough terrain and sharp turns that demand constant vigilance. At one point, a surge of adrenaline fuels him; he pedals with fierce determination down a steep hill, then savors a moment of respite. This desert environment with its challenging road conditions forms the backdrop for his struggle, highlighting both his resilience and the brief moments of relief he finds.

The setting affected the cyclist because the condition of his surroundings was hot, so he got dehydrated more quickly and needed more water to compensate. There were a lot of hills, meaning he had to pedal harder and use more energy to get up the inclines, testing his endurance. Because there were no cars, buildings, or smog, just nature surrounding him, it was a peaceful and relaxing ride on the bike; that's how the setting affects the cyclist, both physically and mentally, creating a challenging yet serene experience.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist in a great way. His journey would not be as difficult if these factors had not crossed his path. Climate, location, and population all have an effect on the cyclist. In the story, it is told that the cyclist is in the dry climate in California, in the heat of June. There is also a lack of water, so he must pace his sips carefully. Therefore, there are also few towns, making it hard to get good advice and supplies. The cyclist also comes across a snake, making him affected by native wild life. The dry climate and lack of water affect him by causing doubt. The cyclist is constantly worried about passing out and dying of dehydration. The cyclist also gets doubts when he sees the road signs reminding him how slow he is going. The snake also has a depressing effect about his dangers on his journey. All of these things in the setting affected the cyclist and his mental resolve. His journey does teach you though, that through determination you will be rewarded. You have to want things bad enough and put the effort into it. The author also teaches you to always have a positive attitude to get success, showcasing how internal strength can overcome external challenges.

The features and settings affected the cyclist because of all the dangers of doing it, like sunstroke and dehydration. He took advice from old people to do it, hoping their experience would guide him. But even though it started out good with clear skies and a manageable pace, almost nothing last forever. He's riding a bike in the middle of summer with little water and in the desert, the heat radiating intensely. He runs into towns that are abandon and the next town is only @NUM1 miles are litheraly going to be rough roads ahead, filled with rocks and sand. But when he did get to the town that was abandon to, despair threatened to consume him, until he found hope and seeing a man in a chair, a sign of possible help. The cyclist's journey is a testament to the fleeting nature of initial advantages, and the challenges that arise when venturing into harsh and unforgiving environments, yet hope persists.

The features of the setting affects the cyclist by not being in town. I say this because the cyclist talks about "old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." This suggests isolation and a rural environment, so that means he doesn't know where he's at, emphasizing his unfamiliarity with this particular, out-of-the-way place.

In the cyclist's journey to Yosemite, several factors hinder him from reaching it. The first is obviously the false information given to him by the elders regarding the correct path. The second is that because the information wasn't true, the cyclist had an insufficient amount of water for the actual, longer journey. This made him dehydrated and weakened. The last is the fact that the route given to him included obstacles such as snakes slithering across the path, dangerously rocky roads that threatened his tires, and unsettling old ghost towns and abandoned buildings which made the cyclist less confident and more fearful. Those are the features of the setting which significantly affected the cyclist's progress and overall well-being, ultimately contributing to his struggle.

The setting affects the cyclist because he should have stuck to his own map, considering the terrain. He should have also packed an extra bottle of water, given the potential for heat and exertion. He should not take any advice from people that haven't left the porch in years, as their knowledge of current conditions is likely outdated. Therefore, adapting to the setting requires preparation and reliable information.

The setting affects the cyclist's mood in the story. The cyclist takes a shortcut with many abandoned towns and buildings, as well as a bumpy terrain. When he came to a fork in his path that had a water pump, he immediately began to pump it; the water was not good for drinking. He was determined to make it to the next town. "I could make that," he said. Because of the ghost town and the old pump, he had to continue on. When the cyclist came to a sign in the road warning him about the road ahead, he began to get depressed, "I was sad." Finally, when he reached Miller's and Johnson's Fish Camp, he was thankful and wanted to show his gratitude. The setting can affect a cyclist by his mood; at first, the cyclist is determined, but as the setting gets worse, his mood and hopes go down the drain. At the end, when the setting is bright, so is his mood, demonstrating how powerfully environment influences emotional state.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was thirsty and it was hot, the sun beating down relentlessly, and he was almost out of water. He almost died because when he was drinking the last of his water, desperately gulping it down, he hit a bump and spit got lodged in his throat, causing him to choke. Adding to his misery were the tiring hills; it seemed to never end, each incline sapping more of his dwindling strength. Thus, the harsh environment pushed the cyclist to his physical limit.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he wasn't prepared in the beginning; the cyclist got directions from an old man who hadn't left his porch in years, so he wouldn't know what had changed. Then the cyclist starts his journey with not a lot of water. When he got to the second town, "I notice the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills." This quote means that he wasn't expecting hills; he thought it was going to be a flat way. Also in the @NUM1 degree weather with a limited water supply, he couldn't ride up and down hills easily, making the journey more difficult. Going down the hills gave him a break, a brief respite from the arduous climb. That's how the cyclist was affected by the setting's features, highlighting the impact of the unexpected terrain and harsh conditions on his unprepared journey.

A lot of factors affected the cyclist. Temperature, terrain, and directions all gave the cyclist doubt. The temperature through the high deserts of California left the cyclist feeling hot, parched, and irritable. Through the story, he had all but a few sips of water left. Knowing you're running low on water "to feel sorry for himself." The cyclist had biked so far the terrain started to change from flat to "rolling hills." This could impact someone greatly who has never biked on different levels before. Lastly, the feeling of hope could have affected him the most. Not believing in yourself is the hardest thing to overcome. Having just leisurely taken instructions by an old man cost the cyclist hours of torture. The author did a great job using hyperbole to exaggerate the cyclist's feeling of lost hope. He also used very detailed text to paint the reader a picture. These literary elements made it easier for me to understand the effect the temperature, terrain, and hope had on the cyclist, showcasing the author's skill in conveying the cyclist's internal struggles.

The features of the setting really affect the cyclist. He is led into false pretenses by the immediate surroundings. Little does he know that it would bring him into danger? When he comes to a rock in the road and finds that the water pumps are not good he is in serious danger. In the reading it says ìThe sun was beginning to heat down, but it hardly noticed. The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them.î The setting let the cyclists mind wonder so much that he didnít even realize the heat. This shows how the beautiful environment masked the potential threats, ultimately contributing to the perilous situation he encountered later on the trail, highlighting the deceptive nature of his surroundings.

In the short story, ìDo Not Exceed Posted speed limit,î by Joe Kurmaskie, expresses the features of the setting like the lack of water, and can not find help to the end affects the cyclist in the story. The barren landscape and absence of assistance amplify his desperation. During his time of need the cyclist says, ìIt didnít really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise old men their wisdom.î The cyclist has a lack of necessities in the features around him and is letting his pride fall down; giving up on hope. This quote showcases his acceptance of fate, highlighting the psychological impact of the harsh environment. When the cyclist finds hope, ìAnd drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait.î The cyclist was astonished of what he had stumbled onto and appreciated that he was still alive. The cyclist should not have taken the old peoples advice for granted, but will now look onto peopleís sense of directions, showing a newfound respect for the wisdom he initially dismissed, demonstrating how near-death experiences can alter one's perspective.

Setting affects many things in stories. The setting in this story affected the cyclist. The setting was very hot and it slowed him down a lot. For example he said he was doing 55 miles an hour, but with the heat, he could only manage 40. The extreme weather clearly had a negative impact on his speed and performance. The story highlights how much the environment can impact a character's capabilities.

The setting in the story was the high deserts of California in June. At first, the cyclist had seemed really confident and excited about his journey. It was during it that he had changed his mind. The cyclist was running low on his water supplies, so he stops and pumps water from this water pump, but all he gets is this acid taste. So he is on his way to the nearest town which is @NUM1 miles away, and he thinks he can make it. So he is heading towards the nearest town when the terrain starts changing. It changes from flat road to short rolling hills. During this time, the cyclist starts losing hope. He thinks that he is going to die of dehydration and the birds are going to pick him apart. Then, when he thought he couldn’t make it, he saw a sign that said ìGary and @CAPS1 fish camp.î He ran into the shop and took long drinks from the sink in the bathroom, and when he went out of the store an older gentleman asked him if he needed help, and he said no, I have a really good map. The hot temperature and rolling hills have a negative effect on the cyclist; he goes from being confident to thinking he is seeing mirages and dying. It states in the story ìI wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasnít a mirageî and ìI was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.î So this brought self-doubting behavior, as the harsh environment and physical challenges eroded his initial optimism and replaced it with fear and desperation.

The features of the setting where the cyclist are affect them very drastically. They need a water supply, and if they don’t have one, they might dehydrate or even die from heatstroke. They need shade trees because it keeps the sun from beaming down on them so hard, reducing the risk of sunburn and heat exhaustion. They also need to cycle when it's not as hot outside, like early morning or late evening, so that just in case their water gets low, there is a better chance of survival. It would be great if there was someone with you to help if you get hurt in a fall or have a mechanical issue with your bike. There should be buildings nearby just in case of an emergency requiring assistance or shelter. It might even be good to carry a cell phone to call for help if needed. These environmental and logistical considerations are crucial for cyclist safety and well-being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in more than one way. The first features were a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lamest mule. These items gave the cyclist a feeling of doubt. They made him begin to think he had taken the wrong route when he saw these things were outdated. Then, he couldnít get any cold, clean water out of the pumps to save his life. This lack of refreshment was the first obstacle which affected him. The next features of the setting which caused a problem were the tumbleweeds and "a ridiculously large snake." They made the cyclist scared and caused him to go around these things, wasting energy. You can tell he was scared because he quoted "I eased past." When the flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills, the cyclistís journey became exhausting, never ending, and difficult, further draining his strength. Two more things affected the cyclist. These two things consist of the signs. One of which read "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" and the other "GARY AND WILBER'S FISH-IF you want bait for the big ones, weíre your BEST BET." The first sign affected him in a negative way and caused him to become a little angry and frustrated because he was tired and dehydrated, and the rough road ahead gave him no hope. The second sign led him to water, which was the one thing that would make things better, so it had a positive affect, providing much-needed relief. Therefore, the cyclist's experience was significantly shaped by the environment, both negatively and positively, throughout his journey.

The setting affected the cyclist: due to the changes in terrain. A rough spot for the cyclist was when the terrain changed from a flat stretch to rolling hills. The author wrote, ìI tolld on"(Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was pushing through the rough and it was not an easy stretch to get through. Another place in the cyclist's trip that was difficult was when he saw the abandoned juice factory. The narration states, ìover one long, crippling hill, a building came into view"(Kurmaskie @NUM1). The context clues that provide information that it wasn't easy are the words "long" and "crippling." The impact of those words provide feelings of being drug on through the rough setting of the cyclist's trip. These specific word choices effectively highlight the challenging environment and the cyclist's struggle to overcome it, emphasizing the difficulties presented by the terrain.

The cyclist had experienced some hard obstacles on his ride to Yosemite. He had gotten directions from a group of old men who hadenít gone the places they told him about in a long time. Where they said there would be a town it was more like a ghost town. The day that the cyclist was riding was very hot and he was riding through the desert, which made it worse. Because of the heat he was drinking his water regularly to stay hydrated. This meant he was running out of it fast, and since the old men had given him directions through places that were no longer open, he couldnít get more water. The cyclist also had to go over roads that were in bad condition, which slowed him down even more. All of those environmental features at the setting affected the cyclist a lot on his trip.

Many features of the setting affect the cyclist. In the beginning, he cannot get water and becomes dehydrated, which saps his strength as he pedals under the relentless sun. Then, he goes on a rough ride and loses more energy as the jarring terrain forces him to work harder to maintain his balance and speed. Then he finds the bait and gratefully drinks the water, replenishing his depleted reserves. All of these greatly affect the cyclist's condition, demonstrating the significant impact the environment has on his physical state and ability to continue.

The setting of the cyclist’s journey affected him because he was in a hot desert in California. This affected him because he had to ride a bike through it, and the heat took a lot out of him, making each mile a struggle. He didn’t have a lot of water because there were no rivers or water supply due to the desert surrounding him, adding dehydration to his difficulties. At the end, he finds a store, which affects him greatly because he gets a cool drink and some supplies, which helped him recover his strength. So, in the end, his surroundings both destroyed him and then relieved him, demonstrating the desert's power to both harm and, unexpectedly, provide.

The bicyclist was riding to Yosemite National Park and on the way ran out of water. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Then, hills came into play which makes you more tired and thirsty. Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills. The rider didn’t think he would live; he felt the sun beating down, and his throat was parched. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” he thought, imagining the vultures circling. But finally, he spotted a small ranger station, a beacon of hope in the arid landscape. He rushed inside and drank deeply from the sink, gulping down the cool liquid. Refreshed and revitalized, he continued his ride, the fear of dehydration now replaced with a renewed sense of determination, and he finished his ride.

In the story “Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting affected the cyclist a lot. At first, when the cyclist set off in the morning, the conditions were great. It was breezy with shade from trees and rivers. Then, after a few hours, the cyclist was in the desert with bumpy hills. In the story, the speaker states, “Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” The condition of the roads and not having water really affected the cyclist. It took more energy to get up and down the hills without any shade, which meant that he needed more water, which he didn’t have any. This change in the landscape, from flat, shaded paths to a hilly, exposed desert, significantly drained his energy and resources. The demanding terrain, coupled with the lack of readily available water, exacerbated his dehydration. The condition of the setting really affected the cyclist, and if it was easier to bike, they might have not been so dehydrated, highlighting how crucial environmental factors were to the cyclist's physical state and overall experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by disturbing them to ride on the road, limiting their speed, and making their distance longer than the original travel plan. For example, the features at the setting disturb the cyclist’s road travel because signs dictate permissible routes, such as "no entering" or "one way" signs. Second, speed is limited because posted speed limits, such as @NUM1, restrict cyclists, increasing travel time. Third, distance increases, impacting travel plans and speed. A "Rough road ahead, do not exceed posted speed limit" sign exemplifies this. Therefore, setting features significantly affect cyclists during their journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because they doubt or lessen his chances for survival, but the cyclist is determined so he survives. The harsh, unforgiving terrain, with its steep inclines and treacherous descents, constantly threatens to throw him off balance. The scorching sun relentlessly beats down, dehydrating him and sapping his strength. Yet, despite these formidable obstacles that diminish his prospects, the cyclist presses on, fueled by an unwavering resolve to overcome the challenges and reach his destination, ultimately proving that determination can triumph over adversity.

In the essay, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. One feature that affects him is his lack of water: "The water bottles contained only a few tantallizing sips." The lack of water made him very desperate, especially when he came to the Welch's grape juice factory. The building—abandoned years earlier—had been a Welch's grape juice factory and bottling plant. This desperation, after he had come to the abandoned factory, was followed by disappointment and a vague sense of hopelessness expressed by the phrase, "I hung my head" after he had found the abandoned factory. This broken promise of potential refreshment, offered by the sight of the factory yet ultimately unattainable, further emphasizes how the setting actively contributes to the cyclist's emotional and physical state. These are some of the features of the setting that affect the cyclist.

No water, rough terrain, bad info—all are reasons why the boy isn't doing so well. I said no water because he is dehydrated but needs to conserve his water. Also, he could die from heat exhaustion, a serious risk in this environment. I also said rough terrain because he could fall and get hurt, with no one around to help him if he twists an ankle or worse. And to top it off, he took info from old people that didn’t know what they were talking about, leading him astray with outdated or inaccurate advice. These all contribute to his predicament.

In the story by Joe Kurmaskie it tells about a cyclists challenge through the heated deserts of California in June. The cyclist had started out with confidence, followed by determination, then relief. The setting affected the cyclist physically and mentally. First, listening to the old men was stupid, then taking the trip not certain if you would have enough water, and lastly traveling through the desert in June. He started getting a little doubtful with himself as well, that won’t help much with bringing success of the trip. Once he had made it to a fish camp an old man even older then the men who gave him the false information told him he knew how to get to Yosemite, but the young man did the best thing and told him he already knew how to get there, resisting more bad advice. He didn’t need to be traveling out in the desert heat for hours that’s just unhealthy, and by trusting his own instincts, the cyclist ensured his safe passage and the ultimate completion of his challenging journey.

A cyclist is affected by many things when riding, most being features of the setting. One feature of the setting that can have an affect is the terrain. If the terrain is rough then the cyclist could have a more difficult time maintaining control of the bike, especially if he is not a professional rider. For example, the author of the essay on page @NUM1 titled: Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit, had a hard times on the rougher roads partly due to his level of experience. Another aspect of the environment that can have an affect on a cyclist is the climate. Most people who go cycling and know anything about the sport know how to dress for it to keep their body at a comfortable temperature but sometimes the weather plays tricks on us. The cyclist could get caught in a sudden heat wave or a sudden drop in temperature, ultimately affecting the cyclist's overall performance and safety.

The features of the setting enhance the cyclist’s desperate spirit. Throughout the whole journey the cyclist is by himself and there are no people, cars, or buildings around. This isolation intensified his desperation, as a fall or dehydration would leave him helpless and alone. Also, he came upon things such as “Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant” which initially raised his hopes for respite, but would soon crush his spirits upon realizing they offered no aid. These events fueled his growing desperation because he had no external support and nothing to fall back on in a life or death situation, ultimately underscoring the harsh reality of his solitary struggle.

In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the features of the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. First of all as he was riding about @NUM1 miles up the road, he saw that the terrain was changing and that scared him; he says ìThis sight was troubling. I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly ì(kurmaskie @NUM2). He is saying that as the things around him began to change, the more his anxiety rose. And he kept drinking a lot of water just to try and calm his nerves. Another example is after he had left the sign that told him not to pass. He says ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills" (kurmaskie @NUM3). This is also an example of fear that started over coming him, when he saw even more changes in the landscape. He wasnít going to stop because of the road changes and the fact that his water was almost gone; he still had the courage to go further. The setting brought him fear, yet despite this mounting apprehension, he persevered and made it through.

The cyclist had run out of water. He had mentioned it tasted like battery acid, a final, bitter dreg. The surroundings affected him, looking around and not seeing anybody for miles. That brings despair. Also, a desert with the hot sun beating down on him, with just sand and cactus all around added to his feeling of hopelessness. Now, if you saw that, you would think of no water or shade because the desert is put to image when you hear those descriptions, amplifying the sense of isolation and desperate need. The combination of the harsh environment and lack of resources would naturally lead to feelings of despair and a heightened awareness of his precarious situation.

The features of the setting in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” affect the cyclist both physically and mentally. In the story, the arid landscape offers no water for the cyclist, contributing to his physical weakness. Mentally, he is greatly affected by the harsh environment. For instance, seeing the abandoned Welch's factory and the image of a boy "pour a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth" deeply impacts him. This vision of refreshment only serves to intensify his thirst, causing him to hang his head as he rode on. Overwhelmed by the desolate surroundings, he even contemplates the possibility of dying there. I believe the first photograph closely relates to the story "As Worry" because the author's son suffers a lot. It shows what he and his friends look like @MONTH1. When the bicyclist was trying to find Yosemite he stumbled into a million settings. One in the beginning was when he was talking to the old men on the porch, and they sent him off into the distance of nothing but desert. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted him. It was desolate and only him. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed his path, a sure sign he was off course, and a ridiculously large snake – it really did look like a diamondback – blocked the majority of the pavement in front of him. Tumbleweeds usually mean desert. He also saw the @CAPS1 grape juice factory and the bait store where he finally found someone else to give him directions, showing the unexpected turns in his journey. The variety of these disparate locations highlights the bicyclist's misadventures while trying to reach his destination.

In the story rough road ahead the cyclist is affected by the setting in many ways. Because he was in a desert in June it was very hot, so he got thirsty and had to ration his water carefully. Also because of the heat he could have dehydration or heat stroke, making the ride even more dangerous. Lastly because it was a desert the wild animals like the snakes and lizards could hurt or poison him, and he could die; this constant threat added to the cyclist's challenges, showing how the setting of the story affected the cyclist.

The cyclist in ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by @PERSON1 suffers from hardship while riding through the desert. The features of the setting affected the cyclist by having no water to drink because it was a desert; there was no vegetation, meaning no water, so he was becoming dehydrated. Also, the setting of the towns he went to had no living organisms or people, so he couldnít quench his thirst there. In one town there was a spigot, but the water was gross and hadnít been pumped in a while, making it undrinkable. Then he comes to the Welchís juice factory, which was abandoned, and from there he thought he was done for, but then he finally came to a shop where there are bathrooms where he drinks water from the sink and he is relieved. Also, the rocky roads affected him because he barely had any water left, and rocky terrain tends to take more strength and endurance, further depleting his limited resources. Ultimately, the harsh desert environment and its lack of resources pushed the cyclist to his physical and mental limits, highlighting the critical role of the setting in shaping his arduous journey.

In the passage DO Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit the desert’s features did not have any positive affects on the cyclist. The desert contained "rolling hills." When a cyclist goes over hills it takes more energy due to the laws of gravity. Because the cyclist used more energy to go over the hills, he only had enough energy to "feel sorry" for himself. The more hills, the more energy lost, the more tired he became. The desert was also hot, and dry. Obviously, since he was in the "deserts of California in June," the weather would make him become thirsty. He did stop for water, but a "tarlike substance" came out instead, further adding to his discomfort. When he again stopped later for water, it was "cool" and most likely refreshing, providing much-needed relief. Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.î It talks about a gentlemen who is riding a bike to ìYosemiteî and he does not know exactly how to get there. In the essay ìRough Road Ahead; Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the features of the setting had an affect on the cyclist. The setting and the features affected him not only physically, but mentally as well. The setting caused him to doubt himself and the men and also it kept him from having the energy needed to get to where he was going. Where the cyclist was riding, in California, affected him physically. It was hot, and he had no water. This caused him to become tired and frustrated, sapping his physical strength. The setting affected him emotionally as well. He started off fine, but as he went on, and as the road slowly changed to hills, he began to get frustrated and angered that he listened to the men. As he saw no buildings in sight for many miles, he began to lose his determination as well as hope. Lastly, when he saw the sign ìGary and @CAPS1 Fish Campî he started to regain hope and become less frustrated. The setting and features of the essay affected the cyclist not only physically, but mentally as well. He started off determined, then as the setting changed he became doubtful and frustrated. In the end, he turned out satisfied as the setting seemed more hopeful, demonstrating the powerful influence of environment on both body and mind.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. The text first mentions that, ìthere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or a structure of any kind.î This shows that the cyclist felt insecure and the isolation was starting to upset him. Another example from the text that describes the cyclist is, ìOne ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lamest mule greeted me.î You can see through the cyclist's description that he was frustrated with the dilapidated state of everything, including the useless water from the pumps. In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î many of the features of the setting affect the cyclist on his journey. The rusty water pump, highway sign and abandoned juice factory all seemed to make his trip more difficult than it already was. First of all, when the author stumbles along a ìramshackle shedî surrounded by ìseveral rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold in the lames muleî, he is anxious to check the pump for well-needed water. When he finds that he is out of luck and cannot drink the bitter tasting water, his hope droops a little. It is as if the sun were taunting him, telling him that he canít make it. Secondly, he passes a large road sign reading ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî. Once again he begins to feel hopeless, but then turns his angst into determination to finish his journey. He says ìsometimes life can be so cruelî as he notices the speed limit to be 25, but he continues on, pedaling hard. Lastly, the author sees a lone building in the distance and almost doesnít believe his eyes. It turns out to be not only his last hope for water, but an abandoned grape juice factory. He reflects on the irony of his position by saying that his situation ìshould please all sadistsî reading about it. Therefore, the features of the setting affected the reader by highlighting the negativity of his situation, which in turn drives him to continue pedaling.

In the essay ìDo Not Exceed Speed Limit,î the features of the setting affected the cyclist in a few ways. One way it affected him was that the temperature was very hot, and by it being hot outside his water wouldnít stay cool. This is a problem because you need nice, cool, refreshing water to stay hydrated, especially during strenuous physical activity like cycling. Another way was when he hit a fork in the road; he didnít know which way to go. All he saw was one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold the lamest mule greeted me. The sight was troubling, leaving him uncertain and adding to his physical discomfort. Last but not least, this water pump wasnít working very well, so he got down on his hands and knees and started pumping. The water wouldnít cool down. He tried a drop or two, and the water tasted like battery acid, making it undrinkable and further jeopardizing his hydration. Those are some features of the setting that affected the cyclist on his journey, highlighting how the environment presented challenges to his physical well-being and navigation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because it makes it hard for him to get to ì@CAPS1 National Parkî. He took advice from some old men to take a shortcut to get him where he wanted to be. There are several features of the setting that greatly affect the cyclist. One feature is the desert he is biking through. The heat of a desert in June can easily dehydrate someone. When exposed for a long time, exercising, and running out of water, the effect is even greater, potentially leading to heatstroke. In addition, the change in terrain and road surface would have an effect on the cyclist. Traveling on a flat road requires much less effort then climbing hills. If the road is also rough, the biker has to work even harder to push up the hill, expending precious energy. There is also the mental effort of not tipping the bike on the uneven surface, requiring constant focus. Finally, there are not any buildings in sight. When someone is dehydrated but has no water, they are desperate to find some. However, if there is nothing they know of nearby, they will start to lose hope. Once they lose hope they won’t try as hard to keep going and they will lose some of their strength, making the physical challenges even more difficult to overcome. The setting in the short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie is troubling to the cyclist. “One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the tamest mule greeted me,” made him troubled that he was in the middle of nowhere, a place that seemed desolate and uncared for. In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the cyclist is affected by his surrounding. At first the man starts out at a reservoir camp ground. He realized that his trip was going to be rough, far more challenging than initially anticipated. The environment and risk of death gave him the determination he needed to push forward. If he had not been so aware of his surroundings he might have given up, but not making it out of the desert to ìthe cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemiteî would be too devastating; therefore, his acute awareness and the stark reality of his environment were crucial to his perseverance and eventual success.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the rougher the terrain got the more the cyclist had to strain to make it. For example, when the terrain turned to hills, the cyclist had to struggle to climb the hills which caused him to use more of his energy and deplete his resources faster. Also, if the terrain was flat and smooth, the cyclist had less problems making the long journey and could maintain a steady pace. For instance, if the cyclist had less strain on him then he would not be as tired and would not drink as much water, allowing him to conserve his supplies for longer stretches. In conclusion, that is how the features of the setting affect the cyclist.

The setting affects the cyclist by the need and comfort of riding down with no infrastructure around or people. In the adventures of the cyclist the setting is not only what develops the character but, that what affects how he pushes himself to not give up, even when he feels helpless. The features of the setting affected the cyclist. The relentless headwind slowed his pace considerably, while the rough asphalt vibrated through his handlebars, numbing his hands.

In ''Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted speed Limit'' by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting most of the time disappoint him. The features of the setting affect the cyclist b/c the route that the cyclist was taking there was a rough road him to travel. When the cyclist first set off, he was doing fine, he had plenty of water. As he kept going, and sort of got of cause, he began to come into the desert region. There are many ways that a cyclist will be affected, and one of these is the setting. The setting affects them because if it is a short, smooth setting, the ride will be easy. But if it is long, bumpy, rough roads, it will be harder to control the bike, which means that the cyclist’s job will be harder; for example, a cyclist riding on a flat, paved bike path will have a much easier time than one traversing a rocky mountain trail. This is how a cyclist is affected by his or her settings, ultimately influencing their experience and performance.

The cyclist ran into rough settings on the way to @ORGANIZATION1 park. The first is the town he came to was a ghost town, deserted and unnerving. The features of the setting have a very negative effect on the cyclist. According to the old men the cyclist would pass by a few towns if he took the route they told him. But he didnít because he thought he would choke on them. The setting around him also made him have negative thoughts. ìIt didnít really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.î Because the setting was a hot, deserted, desert it had a very negative effect on the cyclist. But because he did run out of water it made the effects much worse, amplifying his feelings of despair and hopelessness in the face of such desolation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist. One reason I say this is because he ran out of water, a scarcity likely caused by the arid environment, and he could dehydrate. It is said that, "experience is a good substitute for INSTINCT." This means if someone knows how to deal with the environment they're in they can survive even if they weren't born with the animal instinct that come with the territory. However, even the most experienced person can be overcome by the extreme weather conditions they live in. In the essay, "Rough Road Ahead," by Joe Kurmaskie, the experienced cyclist decides to take a long, difficult, and dangerous trip. His ride will take him a long the long desert paths of California with a limited water supply. This is the major element that challenges him in the story. Because he listened to some old men he went without water for most of his trip. Between his constant exercise, extreme heat, and lack of water, dehydration hit him fast. A common side effect of dehydration is hallucination, which the cyclist knew. It says in the essay, "I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn`t mirage." This represents his knowledge and experience in the matter, and showed that he was adapt to his environment through experience. A similar story to this is Jack LONDON's, "To Build a Fire" where the man is also pitted against extremes of nature through the Yukon, but the elements still overtook him. Both stories represents man's quest for adventure, and also the constant struggle for survival that people face.
The feature of a setting can affect a cyclist’s energy. In a setting with turns, hills, and headwinds, it can easily tire this cyclist out.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist most on the fact that it strained him out the hydrated state. The arid climate and relentless sun made it difficult to retain fluids, and the lack of readily available water sources exacerbated the problem. It made him unable to operate at his full power/efficiency. Depleted of essential electrolytes, his muscles weakened, and his cardiovascular system struggled to keep up. It deprived him of the little energy he had in him to begin with. Facing headwinds and the constant uphill climb further compounded the energy drain. That is how the setting affected him, ultimately hindering his performance and pushing him to his physical limits.

The setting affects the cyclist very strongly. The desert and heat with no water cause him to get dehydrated. The rolling hills and rough terrain tire him out, making each mile a struggle. The cyclist’s condition was greatly influenced by his setting because he was lost in the high deserts of California in June. The heat crippled him as he traveled in search of Yosemite. How the features of the setting affected the cyclist in the story, "Do Not Exceed Posted Limit," were very dangerous to his life. The cyclist traveled miles after miles on his bike only to pass by deserted towns, "This place might have been a thriving little spot...a ghost town." The terrain was threatening because after twenty-two miles or so, the cyclist had to overcome, "short rolling hills," which would use more energy and make his thirst for water even stronger. The cyclist was out of water and the hot day, with the sun beating down, was not helping. After a grueling journey, the cyclist used all the strength he had to go to a local bait shop and drank from the sink after the treacherous environment he was exposed to. During the cyclist journey in “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie he experiences setting changes such as the road being flat then going to short rolling hills. When he's riding, he says the road is flat. “Flat road was replaced.” This tells us the road he was on was nice and flat, offering a relatively easy ride. Then as he's riding he notices the land change. “Flat road was replaced by, short rolling hills.” This tells us that the cyclist will have more trouble since the terrain changed, introducing an element of challenge that demands more physical exertion. The shift from flat to rolling hills foreshadows the increasing difficulty of his journey.

The features affect the cyclist. The setting affects the cyclist because it's real hot. So he takes a couple tips on some short cuts by some old men. Then come to find out these tips weren't really short cuts. So now he's riding and angry that he took their tips. Also he's running out of water and becoming dehydrated. He sees an abandoned place with water, but in order to get it you need to pump it. So he starts pumping and sees black gunk. He pumps for about 20 minutes to cool the water, but it doesn't cool off. Come to find out the water tastes like battery acid. So he starts riding again, but encounters a snake. Luckily he gets away, but he feels that he's about to die and regrets listening to men who haven't got off their porch since Eisenhower was president. What makes him more angry is that they seemed so sure. As he's riding he sees a juice factory and goes there. Now it's a fishing store and drinks lots and lots of water. He also says he's never listening to old men and he'll always use the map, deciding that trusting his own navigation is the only way to avoid such mishaps in the future.

As the author of the story goes on her bike trip, the landscape around her becomes less and less welcoming. The first thing the cyclist encounters is a rusty pump and old shed. When the cyclist tries to get water from the pump, she describes the water as very hot and not cooling down at all. When the cyclist continues, tumbleweeds that look like “diamond head snakes” cross her path. She encounters no buildings for a long time; when she does encounter a building, it is abandoned and suggests that people left because of the landscape. The paint is peeling, the windows are boarded, and a sense of desolation hangs heavy in the air, reinforcing the idea of nature’s dominance. The cyclist encounters another elderly man in her journey but decides not to take his advice because of the path the last set of elderly men set her down. Distrust now colors her interactions, a direct consequence of the harsh environment and the misleading guidance she previously received, leading her to rely solely on her own instincts despite the inherent challenges.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways; they face heat, lack of water, and hills. In the story ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist has a very long journey that itís affected by a variety of things, and problems. In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î a cyclist is confronted with a troubling setting on his journey to Yosemite. He is led away from the steady road as a result of taking mislead advice from an old group of individuals. In this essay the setting plays a crucial impact on the cyclist. In the essay, the author sets up the story describing the day as, ìtraveling through the high deserts of California in June.î Because of the amount of heat the cyclist was enduring, he became weary and dehydrated, impacting his physical and mental state. Alone with this, the cyclist had to work much harder because the man noticed, ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.î This setting is a major setback to the cyclistís journey, and required him to persevere through the difficult terrain and weather conditions. In my life there have been numerous obstacles which I have had to persevere through. One of which had been when I was out camping, and suddenly, as in the essay, the setting changed, and a storm came, bringing heavy rain and strong winds. Though the other campers and I did what we needed to to make the best out of it, securing our tents and finding shelter. In the essay, the cyclist is affected greatly by the setting. This was the same in my experience as the setting affected myself. In both situations, perseverance led to a final satisfaction of the journey, allowing us to overcome adversity and appreciate the rewards that followed.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist because the roads are bumpy, making for an uncomfortable ride. In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The setting is described as a rough terrain, which makes it harder for the cyclist to travel. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the surrounding is perceived negatively. Everything around the cyclist is perceived negatively, so naturally the cyclist feels like the task is harder and more challenging than it really is. For example, nothing is surrounding the cyclist but sand and the hot temperature since the setting is so empty and no one is around, then everything seems harder than it really is. The sun beats down mercilessly, the sand offers no respite, and the vast emptiness amplifies the feeling of isolation. Also the cyclist feels like he can't go on and is weak because there is no life around him. The absence of visual stimulation and encouragement further depletes his motivation. Furthermore, if the cyclist was in the park with the sun shining and people around and in sight, his attitude would change and everything would seem easier. The lush greenery, the cheerful faces, and the sounds of laughter would create a positive feedback loop, making the ride feel less strenuous and more enjoyable, demonstrating how crucial setting is to perceived effort.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist by making it hard for him to control his bike down the rough road, the incline and uneven terrain adding to the difficulty. The setting affects the cyclist in many grueling and harsh ways. First, the lack of civilization contributes to an uneasy feeling and an inability to refill his water bottle. Second, the heat and uphill climbs are taking their toll on both the cyclist's physical and mental strength. Third, his water bottle is emptying at an alarming rate due to his thirst and relentless heat. In paragraph four the exhausted cyclist reaches the first ''town.'' This place *may* have been a striving spot, but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. *As* he came to a house with a rusty water pump, which spewed out brackish, near-boiling water, which did not support the parched cyclist, physically or mentally, thus adding to his distress.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because ìnever accept travel advice from someone who hasn't actually cycled the route themselves." The setting of the story affects the cyclist in a negative way. He entrusted that these men he had asked directions from knew what they were talking about. Only to find deserted towns, disowned factories, and unrelenting hills stretching before him. In the story ìDo not exceed posted speed limit" The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. One way is that the harsh conditions of the desert make him need alot of water resources. While trying to reach Yosemite by a shortcut, the cyclist faced many challenges and emotions. The cyclist started out his journey cheerfully with thoughts of the cool pines of Yosemite. "The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it." The cyclist continued on, his spirits as well as his water supply going down. The cyclist encouraged himself to keep going, just to find an open building, telling himself that if he could make it that far, he'd be fine. Passing many abandoned factories, the cyclist tried many methods to decrease his thirst, including sucking on stones, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope. After passing the abandoned factories, the cyclist found a deserted building, and he lost more and more hope. When the cyclist found an open store with modern bathrooms, he had "an overwhelming urge to seek out anyone, kiss them, and buy some bait." At the end, the cyclist promised himself to always use his map, having learned a hard lesson about the importance of planning and preparation.

In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Kurmaskie, the cyclist went through hard times, trying to get to Yosemite National Park. Well some features might have more prominence than others, and the cyclist might face more challenges than the author in certain aspects of the journey. Also the author faced a lot of problems like the scarcity of water, the presence of poisonous snakes, and the poor condition of the road. So there were many things that affected both the author and the cyclist, significantly impacting their experience as they were on their arduous journey. These factors highlight the demanding nature of the trip and the various obstacles that had to be overcome.

In the passage ìDo not exceed posted speed limit,î there are many features from the setting that affected the cyclist. One feature that affected the cyclist was the snake he encountered on his way, for example in the text it says ìAt some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snakeî, ìI cased post, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated stateî This proves that the snake was a feature that affected the cyclist by requiring him to maintain composure. Even in a dehydrated state, the cyclist had to focus and react to the unexpected obstacle. This demonstrates how the environment introduced challenges that impacted his physical and mental state, influencing his journey.

There are many things that could have made his bicycle ride much more enjoyable, one thing is if he wasn't in the middle of nowhere and if he actually knew where he was. For example, "There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind." Therefore, he had almost no water to get him through the day. For instance, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." Moreover, he did not know where he was going so it was harder for him, because he was lost and disoriented. In conclusion these are some things that made his trip hard.

The features of the setting do affect the cyclist in such ways, making him illusionistic and dehydrated. He saw the illusion that a juice factory was working, when it was abandoned. He saw rusty pipes; this made him dehydrated because he knew those pipes could never produce water, further contributing to his disorientation and physical distress, thus highlighting the powerful influence of the desolate environment.

In the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the settings of the story affect the cyclist, making him think he will die and overall making him worried. In the story, the cyclist takes two old men’s advice on the best way to get to Yosemite mountain and gets himself in the middle of nowhere. He finds himself in the California desert without water, and he lets this go to his head. “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean,” that line was from the last page of the story. The biker was taking an unfamiliar route, and he let himself believe he would die. He knew he was in the desert without water; the setting makes him nervous because he was in a desert. He wouldn’t have been nearly as nervous if he was in a forest where there are streams. He lets the desert and the heat convince him that he is going to die. By coming across ghost towns, he believes he will never see another person again; he gets older because of where he is. He thinks the heat will kill him. The setting affects him and tricks him into believing he is going to die, showcasing how the environment can significantly impact one's mental state and perception of danger.

The feature of the setting including the conditions, weather, and amount of water can possibly decide the life or death of the cyclist. The conditions such as hills, and rocky roads can decide a future for a cyclist because if the rocky roads turn you off balance you could fall down a hill and give yourself an injury or possibly die. For example, in the short story it says, “over one long crippling hill, a building came into view” This shows the conditions in which the cyclist had to deal with. In addition, the weather and amount of water can also decide the future. “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.” This shows us that if the cyclist gets dehydrated enough he could pass out and no one would find him in the desert. The scorching heat further exacerbates the situation, as it accelerates dehydration and exhaustion, potentially leading to a fatal outcome in such an isolated environment. In addition, the heat isn’t helping him out any once he could die without anyone knowing. These reasons show us a cyclist needs to make sure they have enough water and the conditions and weather is right so they don’t make a life-threatening choice.

When the cyclist is at his low point, he is an abandoned ghost town, looking for water that tastes like battery acid. The cyclist feels hopeless in the abandoned town. When he first reaches the water pump and the abandoned juice building he has a little hope, a flicker of possibility in the desolate landscape, only to be let down, because the building has no juice and the water pumpís water is too hot and the water is not any good. The setting is the reason his mood changes throughout the story, dictating his emotional state with its promise and subsequent disappointment. The environment actively shapes his hope and despair, revealing the profound impact of surroundings on one's emotional well-being.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist, influencing their ride and requiring adjustments. Different elements, such as snow or rocks, directly impact a cyclist's ability to maintain balance and control. For instance, patches of ice can cause a cyclist to lose traction, leading to a fall. Similarly, a road filled with rocks demands careful navigation and slower speeds to avoid accidents or damage to the bicycle. Ultimately, the cyclist's experience is shaped by the setting, necessitating adaptability and awareness to overcome environmental challenges.

In the beginning of the story, a young cyclist sets out on a long journey to Yosemite National Park. Along his ride he meets some old but confident men who suggest a new route, which they claim "was to slice away hours" from his ride. The setting was exceedingly hot that July. He was supposed to encounter a few thriving towns along the way, but the first was a "barren ghost town," the next had water "the flavor of battery acid," then he came to an abandoned Welch's grape juice factory. The author navigated through a very trying setting until he reached a bait shop. The advice that he gives to his readers is to stick to your guns & don't let old timers try and change your mind, because sometimes the well-intentioned shortcut leads to a far more difficult path.

In the essay ìRough Road aheadî by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist had many challenges due to the harsh desert setting. The cyclist was lost, and this affected him a lot because the desert is very hot, with temperatures capable of causing heatstroke. He could have died from either dehydration or exhaustion while trying to find his way back. Also, in the desert some animals can be very dangerous on the cyclist journey; he saw a poisonous snake slithering across his path. It was a good thing that he was cautious around the snake because if he hadnít been, he might have gotten bitten, and there would be no one around to help him administer aid. The desert that he was in also happened to be deserted, and there was no one around to help him with directions, compounding his sense of isolation. The worst thing would have to be that he ran out of water, his most vital resource. Without the water, he could become very weak and dehydrated and could have even died from the exposure. The setting of where the cyclist was affected him greatly, posing significant threats to his survival.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him thirsty and him thinking he is lost and going to die. The cyclist, parched and sun-beaten, got information from an old guy that has not been off his porch for years. Just when the cyclist thought he was lost he saw ìGary and Wilberís fish camp-if you want bait for the big ones, were your best bet!î The cyclist went in and got water, and the old man asked him if he wanted to know where to go, but this time he said no, confident he could find his own way.

In the short story "Do not exceed the speed limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting has a great impact on the cyclist. In the beginning of the story he describes the scenery as "rolling golden hills." As he continued following the old men's outdated advice, it led him through more barren lands. When he came to the first "town" he described it as a ghost town. The second setting he arrived at was "one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn't hold in the lamest mule." He continued moving to the next town, which was 40 miles away; he came to what he thought was a Welch's Grape juice factory and bottling plant. This took a toll on his confidence because he said "I hung my head." He moved on and had finally arrived at an abandoned building called "Ernie and Wilbur's Fish Camp." This is where he drank water and became replenished. The setting had a great effect on the cyclist, because, depending on the location, it decided whether he would live or die in the hot deserts of California, showcasing how the environment dictated his survival.

One of the main things that affect the cyclist is the heat, causing dehydration. Due to the heat he drinks all of his water, leaving him vulnerable to its effects. Another feature of the setting that affects the cyclist is the rough road; since he is so tired, he has a difficult time riding on the hills and other hard road conditions, further depleting his energy. These environmental challenges clearly impede the cyclist's progress.

In the story, "I Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," written by @CAPS1, the setting reflects how the cyclist is feeling. For example, "Flat roads was replaced by short, riding hills" @CAPS2 as the terrain was changing, so was his attitude. When he first started the journey, he was happy and care free and the land had no hills and was flat. However, once he noticed that everything is not as the men said, he seems to grow a little angry and upset, @CAPS2 like the land seemed to reflect this; soon he found himself on a bumpy and unpleasant road. The setting also seemed to give the man more obstacles to overcome on his adventure; "tumbleweeds crossed my path; a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the movement in front as me." It appeared the land was actively working against him. The land seemed to be teasing and tormenting him, when he started to figure out that listening to the old men was a mistake, showcasing how the environment mirrors his internal struggles and the increasing difficulty of his journey. Ultimately, the setting serves as a powerful symbol of the cyclist's emotional state and the challenges he faces.

In the story ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the features of the setting affects the cyclist by draining him of energy, he is sweating so much, he keeps on drinking his water and slowly finishes it and still has a long ride ahead of him. ìThe water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.î(Kurmaskieís) since is was so hot the cyclist was thirsty and drank all of his water. It was a warm day and he needed to stay hydrated; the sun beat down relentlessly on the black asphalt, radiating heat that intensified the physical strain, and the relentless warmth contributes to the cyclist's growing desperation, making the remaining journey seem even more daunting. The cyclist’s struggle highlights the setting's impact.
In the book ëDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the setting was in Codi, California. The author went on a journey

Throughout the rider's long journey, the setting greatly affected him. For example, the hot weather caused him to drink the majority of the water supply, making him dehydrated and tired; consequently, his pace slowed considerably. If the weather was cool, he would have lasted much longer and likely arrived at his destination with more energy, demonstrating the profound impact of environmental conditions on his endurance.

In this story, the cyclist was affected physically and emotionally in many ways, one such way being through the setting around him. For example, when he rode into the first town, he gained a boost of confidence because he believed he was on the right track to Yosemite. Then, when the cyclist rode upon that old shed and the rusty water pumps, he began to feel a little worried because he was running out of water, and The Old Timers never mentioned the shed. When the cyclist encountered the rolling hills with tumbleweeds and snakes, I believe he began to feel dismayed because he was lost, and the harsh environment was taking its toll. I believe this because, in the text, he says, "I was going to die, and the birds would pick me dead," which shows how hopeless the man felt in the face of the unforgiving landscape. When he reached "Gary and @CAPS1 fish camp," he was relieved and thankful because he no longer had death blazing towards him in the form of a yellow sun, empty spaces, and an empty water bottle. This illustrates how the features and setting affected him in many ways, influencing his emotional state as he navigated the challenging terrain.

Riding through beastly mountains and hot, burning deserts with no water, a cyclist was riding through a town and asked for directions. The two old men gave him the wrong directions, sending him on a trip through hell that only a determined person could get through. First, he had to go miles without water, which resulted in him losing faith, becoming dehydrated, and almost giving up on continuing with his plans. The terrain he had to go through was unbearable and could almost kill him without water. Luckily, he had faith and determination, so he got through it and learned a lesson: maps are made for people to use, so if you have a map, you should trust it. In the ending, it shows that the cyclist learned that because he said, “And I promised myself right then that I’d always stick to it in the future,” proving the importance of trusting reliable sources like maps.

In the short story “Rough Road Ahead Do not exceed posted speed limit,” a lot of things affected the cyclist. Such as the rocky road and the lack of water, for example, where the author says, “when I tried a drop or two, It had the flavor of battery acid.” This shows how he is losing hope, and he seems a little scared. The cyclist’s dwindling water supply and its putrid taste significantly impacted his morale, adding to his mounting anxieties, also, the abandoned towns didn’t help. The desolate landscape and decaying infrastructure amplified his sense of isolation and vulnerability, making his journey even more psychologically taxing. Thus, the combined effects of physical hardship and unsettling surroundings contributed to the cyclist’s growing despair.

All the features of the environment through which the cyclist is riding affect him greatly. The sun was also beginning to beat down on him which means that he was going to have a hot ride to the town and which later caused his struggle for water. In the story it says, ìThe water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sipsî and that he could drop from a heatstroke on a beautiful day in June.î This is basically showing that the hot environment caused him to drink a lot of water, and now he has run low which could cause him to have a heat stroke, highlighting the perilous impact of the harsh desert environment on his well-being.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by depleting his water supply and almost giving him heat exhaustion. The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. The features of the setting affect the cyclist because depending on how the setting is, is how much skill they need. Like if they're going downhill then they really only need to know how to control the bike. If they're going up a mountain with lots of bumps they need to have some skill, and the right gear. Usually if they're riding in a shady area then they wear clothes to keep them cool, and protect them from any potential moisture. But if they're going to be in the sun then they need to wear light clothes, and apply sunscreen. The setting affects the rider very much, influencing their clothing, gear, and the level of skill required for a safe and successful ride.

The setting in "Do not exceed posted speed limit" affects the cyclist in many ways. The old men told the cyclist there were flat roads on the path he was to take, when the cyclist got there, there were hills not flat roads. The features of the setting affect the cyclist for many readers after another. @CAPS1 are some examples why the cyclist was bike riding down a windy road. Another thing that affected him because of the setting was that the desert had rocky roads and windy paths because he followed the old mans direction. "Rough Road Ahead" A final example is that he was in the desert so he saw a snake come out of the tumbleweeds, "A large snake it really did look like a diamond back." @CAPS1 are three examples how the cyclist had been affected due to the setting of the story; these examples illustrate how the desert environment significantly impacts the cyclist's journey, presenting challenges related to heat, terrain, and wildlife.

The features in the settings, like hills, make the cyclist use more energy; the more energy that he uses, the more water he will want to drink. In the story the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example he is in the desert and it is very hot outside. Also he is running out of water. This is bad because he could become dehydrated, impairing his judgment and physical strength. The features of the setting affect the cyclist’s mood towards the journey. At first, he is confident that the old men’s knowledge of the land is accurate and he is excited about what lies ahead for him. However, his excitement soon turned into dismay and slight doubt as his journey drags on and the landscape offers no respite. The heat of the weather and lack of water makes the cyclist develop an uncaring matter. “I’d read once that sucking on stones helps…with any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat.” The verbal irony in this passage delivers a negative feeling to the reader and it is here that it is clear that the cyclist doesn’t care what happens to him. When he finally reaches a sign of civilization, a gas station, the cyclist becomes himself again and decides that his knowledge is best, suggesting the harsh environment had temporarily broken his spirit, but his self-assurance returns with comfort.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” while riding his bike the author Joe Kurmaskie has a long ride. Where he is riding there are up and down hills also the road is very rough. He was running out of water in the desert. “I stopped at a rusted water pump to get water and a tar-like substance oozed out.” Once he is off his bike, he least worries about the poisonous snakes of the desert. He found a Welch’s grape juice factory but it was abandoned. The author found a bait shop and got water, showing his resourcefulness in a challenging environment.

In the short story "Do not @CAPS1 the Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the setting of the story affects the cyclist in many ways. This ever-shifting environment, with its demanding terrain and fluctuating weather, is why the setting @MONTH1 affects the cyclist so profoundly.

The hot sun and the desert features in the setting are affect the cyclist in ways that could potentially stop him from making it to his destination. The sun is beating down on him and is making it harder for him to reach his destination. ìThe sun was begining to beat down...wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt.î By him being so hot and tired from the sun, he thought that he would die from dehydration. This would very likely stop him from making it to his destination, Yosemite. His lack of water supply didnít help the situation either because he could only go "a mile or two," was "water depleting fast."
