The features of the setting does affect the cyclist. For example, if it is hot outside then he would need more water than normal to avoid dehydration. Also if it was raining he would have to drive more careful to prevent accidents due to slippery roads. That is why the setting would affect the cyclist, influencing their hydration needs and driving precautions.

The environment around people in certain situations can affect them in many ways. For instance if you are hot, a tree could provide shade, or if thirsty, a river nearby could quench your thirst. If you were hungry and hot, but nothing was near you, this could exacerbate the heat. In this cyclist's case, the environment affected him in many ways, from bumpy roads and ghost towns to trees. For example he said, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed,” this is because of the "cool pines" around him as he explains in the next paragraph. It also says in the text that the terrain changed and he even came upon a snake, which added to his thirst, consequently making it harder for him to continue. Therefore, from reading the text one can see how environmental features can indeed have significant effects on a person.

The features of the setting strongly affect the cyclist's journey to Yosemite. The features of the land, including inclines and hills, the fact that it is desert, and the setting in the middle of June also affect this story. The dry and hilly land is a huge factor for the main character, because if it is hilly, he has to work twice as hard. The land is dry, so he is thirsty and has nowhere to get anything to drink. The land is also desert, so there is nowhere he can go for help or to get food, water, or civilization. He believes that he is not going to make it. The text explains in paragraph 11, "the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh." The setting plays a huge role in the story, influencing the cyclist's struggles and doubts. It is hot, dry, and deserted; this drastically affects the main character and his journey, shaping his experience and challenging his resolve.

The cyclist in the essay Rough Road Ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit feels discouraged and dehydrated because of the setting. Near the beginning, after viewing the first stop which consisted of a few broke buildings and some rusted pumps he states ìThis sight was troubleing,î He also feels dehydration when he reaches the pumps and finds the produce ìA tar like substance oozed out, followed by blackish waterî. Also as he is pedaling he sees a sign that says do not exceed 55 miles per hour. He notices the sign is faded and bullet riddled, further adding to his unease and sense of isolation. In this quick passage by Joe Kurmaskie, the many conditions of the road and the area around it determine how he acts and what he feels, ì The sun was beginning to beat down , ì (Kurmaskie). He is starting to get tired because it is becoming hot and sunny, so he is feeling less confident. He was traveling through the high deserts of California in June ì. (Kurmaskie). The setting significantly affects the cyclist. The essay "The Cyclist" demonstrates this impact, focusing primarily on how the environment influences the cyclist's experience. The scenery makes the cyclist happy. He's sooooooooooooo happy! Woohoo! Happy, indeed, as the rolling hills and clear blue sky stretch out before him.

In this story the setting has a affect to the cyclist trip and to him self. It being hot and over 100 degrees and going down hill with a lot of turns. The setting significantly influences the cyclist's mood, mirroring his emotional state. Initially, he exudes strength and optimism, evident in his smile. Heat, dessert, humidity all are things that affect the cyclist as on his journey. First, heat because the heat is making him thirsty for water @CAPS1 he is running low on. The features of the setting greatly affect this cyclist. At first he is fine riding along the old-timers’ ìshortcutî as he states that ìthings began well enough. I rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on my face.î But what he didnít know was this was the beginning of a very rough day. He arrived at the first ìtownî which was a ghost town, its buildings silent and empty under the scorching sun. He wasnít overly worried yet but at about sixty miles in on his journey he came to a ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a broken down corral. The cyclist explains how he had drank a lot of his water and was in need of some. He tried the pumps but he explains how ìa far like substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.î A couple miles later he came to a highway sign that read ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. The cyclist continued on desperate for water, the rough road jarring his bones. He even came across a snake, a rattlesnake coiled and ready to strike. He was now fearing a heat stroke, his vision blurring in the heat. He came to an abandoned grape juice factory and hung his head, the boarded-up windows offering no relief. The cyclist then was almost completely dehydrated from the long, tiring bike rid. The cyclist was sure he was going to die from dehydration or a heatstroke that this terrible ride had caused. He finally came to a shop a drank from the sink. So this ride was torturous due to the setting, its desolation and harsh conditions pushing him to his physical and mental limits.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in positive and negative ways. At first, there were the two old men who gave the cyclist the out-of-date information. They affected him negatively because if it wasn’t for them, the cyclist would have never gotten lost. The cyclist relied on their directions, only to find himself further off course. When the cyclist arrived at the first town, the water pump affected him; the cyclist was running out of water and the water from the water pump tasted like battery acid and was about @NUM1∞. The cyclist was becoming more and more dehydrated and the small, rolling hills didn’t help his dehydration, he also used a lot of energy in order to go over the hills. The sun beat down relentlessly, exacerbating his thirst and fatigue. Finally, he found Gary and Wilber’s fish camp where he was able to get water. This whole experience in a way, affected the cyclist positively even though, at the time, he was affected negatively. The cyclist learned to not take advice from really old people who “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” He gained a valuable lesson about trusting his instincts and verifying information. The cyclist was affected positively and negatively by the features of the setting.

In the essay ìRough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limitî the cyclist is on a journey to Yosemite National Park and stops for advice on a quicker route. When he asks the old men he says, ìNever accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who havenít left the confines of their porches since carter was in office.î Along with using their advice he faces abandoned ghost towns that they said were thriving spots. The cyclist overcomes the rolling hills of terrain and mirages and the heat of a day in June in the California deserts. Finally he sees a bait and tack shop, and when he sees that the men who own the place are older than the other guys he just stares at them in all. Based on his earlier conviction about advice from the elderly, it's likely the cyclist will disregard their claim of possessing the best map, choosing instead to rely on his own instincts or perhaps a more modern navigational tool. His previous experience with outdated information has made him wary.

The features in the setting affect cyclists in many ways. One of which is being only able to carry so much equipment which might be needed. For example, you can only take so much water with you and once you run out of water, and there are no buildings or anything around, you are out of luck. Also, you can only take so much food with you on your ride. Finally, when you are ready to go to sleep you can’t just pull over; you have to ride until you find a hotel or get home. I know that I would not make it. So those are just a few reasons why the setting affects cyclists and their ability to complete their journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by making him dehydrated, troubled, and relieved. The cyclist is dehydrated because of the horrible heat. He says ìthe growing realie at von that l would drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.î This means that the heat is a threat to him and would cause him to become dehydrated and have heatstroke. The cyclist is troubled by the scarce surroundings, seeing "a corral that couldnít hold the lamest mule.î He is getting worried because there is no one around and his directions are starting to sound wrong, leaving him feeling isolated. The cyclist is relieved by the water from the sink. He had the ìoverwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them.î This means that he is so relieved that he has finally found water, ending his thirst, and he wants to thank the owners of the bait shop for providing it. Therefore, the setting's harshness and eventual provision of relief significantly impact the cyclist's physical and emotional state.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the story "Rough Road Ahead" by Joe Kurmaskie. The downhill land format helped him because he wouldn’t have to exert as much strength to pedal, a definite advantage considering his dwindling water supply. However, when he came to a pump, its condition was far from ideal; it was rusty with tar oozing out and dispensed hot, brackish water that tasted like battery acid. The dryness of the desert negatively impacted the cyclist, as he was unable to replenish his fluids until reaching the longed-for Yosemite water. Conversely, the breeze provided a welcome cooling effect, offering some respite from the oppressive heat. Clearly, the features of the setting in the story "Rough Road Ahead" by Joe Kurmaskie significantly affect the cyclist's journey, presenting both challenges and minor reliefs.

One of the biggest problems that the author faced in his essay was his surroundings. The setting of the story in Yosemite provided many obstacles such as the vastness of the park, the summer heat, and the fact that many places had been abandoned. An example of the vastness of the park was when he quote, ìAbout forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first ëtown.í This place might have been a thriving spot at one time-say, before the last world war-but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town.î This quote shows that even after many miles, he hadn't seen a sign of anyone living, which would have increased his desperation to keep looking for civilization. The combination of heat, distance, and desolation created a truly compelling narrative, showcasing the author's resilience against the harsh realities of his chosen environment, and ultimately shaping the central conflict of his experience.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in this story greatly. Another feature was it was hot, which means he was losing water because it either evaporated or he was drinking it. I know this because it said “The water bottles contained water, a few tantalizing sips,” which means there was little left, making him dehydrated and weakening him. The settings affect the cyclist in many ways on the way to Yosemite. For one, when he took the shortcut, it was June, and he was out in the desert, which made it difficult. Also, he went to a couple of deserted towns, so there was no way to replenish his water. It says, “I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn’t cool down. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” Another thing about his setting that changed was the hills, making the cycling more physically demanding. But once he came to a bait shop, the old man asks him if he knows the best way to get to Yosemite, and he responds, “yes- sir: I own a very good map.” Through this experience, he understood that the best way to travel anywhere is the path or road he knows because he’ll know what to expect regarding terrain, resources, and potential hazards, thus changing his perspective on the importance of familiar routes.

In the essay the features of the setting affected the cyclist. In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, depending on how the main character feels, that’s what the setting is like. Some things that affected the cyclist was the terrain changing into a flat road that was replaced by short, rolling hills. Then he came to a rough road, jarring his hands. Everytime he pumped it wouldnít cool down, and the water tasted like battery acid, a truly awful sensation. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in the short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The setting of the story is “a reservoir campground outside of CAPSLOCK, California” during the early summer. Being early summer in Southern California, the temperatures are going to be hot. And the main character, who is a cyclist and is doing a lot of physical activity, is going to sweat a lot. The temperature and excessive sweating cause the cyclist to drink a lot of water, quickly depleting his supply. The water runs out, and we are now at our conflict. The setting also leads the main character to his resolution of the conflict. Being by a reservoir, fishing is going to be a popular activity, meaning a bait and tackle shop would be the perfect business to have nearby. At the bait and tackle shop, the cyclist could go inside and quench his thirst. Therefore, the setting of the story affects both the conflict and the solution.

The cyclist decided to ride to Yosemite National Park during a hot summer day in California. His first instincts was to use a perfectly good map that was up to date. Then he started having a conversation with some old men who decided that they would tell him a short cut they took back in the day. The cyclist decided to take the old men's short cut through the desert with one measly bottle of water. It was really hot outside and the sun was scorching down on his back while he was riding his bike. This made him hotter than he anticipated, and there was no shade or place for him to stop and get some water. This made the trip harder for him because now he was focused on finding water and not on his ride. The settings of the cause affected the cyclist in many ways; he was not prepared for the route, and the route he took was not biker friendly. If he would have took the route that was on the map then he would have known where he was and his ride would not have been affected by thoughts of slowing down to put rocks in the mouth to conserve water or thoughts of finding water he would have been able to focus on enjoying the scenery and the physical challenge of the ride, ultimately making for a much more pleasant and safer journey.

The cyclist had a rough time. The elements were against him. It was dry and hot and he had no water. In the text it says, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." The wether can change the corse of action a cyclist will take. If it is cold out side then the cyclist will bring beveyer cloths, such as a jacket and gloves. In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed limit” by Joe Kurmaskie the different aspects of the setting affect the cyclist in several ways. When he first begins he doesn’t even notice how hot it is and he says, “the rain was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” His mood starts to change very quickly as the harshness of the environment begins to take its toll. Soon he drinks most of his water and becomes increasingly tired from battling the elements. He finds a water pump which irritates him when he realizes the water tastes like “battery acid.” As he continues, pushing through the challenging terrain, he sees a snake which he could swear was a diamondback so he slowly goes by it out of caution. When he notices a factory he uses his last bit of energy to reach it only to be discouraged when he finds it abandoned and devoid of any help. His spirits finally rise when he finds a store and drinks a good amount of water, revitalizing him after his difficult journey. Ultimately, the cyclist's experience is shaped by the setting's challenges, creating a narrative of resilience and the impact of environment.

Multiple parts of the setting effect the cyclist. The cyclist in this short story was greatly affected by the setting. He was riding in a desert which is very hot, with little civilization to help him. The cyclist was exhausted as he was going uphill. The setting of story affects the cyclist alot. This is because in California it is really good to be cycling. The setting of the essay greatly affected the cyclist. These settings discourage him, although he tries to keep hope. Being a cyclist is not as easy as it sounds. Sure riding a bike might be easy, but being a cyclist is so much more difficult. Cyclists have many obstacles to overcome while riding. One obstacle would be a rough terrain. Cyclists are used to riding on smooth, paved roads. Going off road or riding on a dirt road might be a challenge, requiring more focus and energy. In the short story “Do Exceed posted Speed Limit,” by Joe Kurmaskie, also has another example for an obstacle cyclists have to be careful of, and that is running out of water, “I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state” (@CAPS1 @NUM1). The cyclist went on in telling how he needed to try to keep his balance but it was hard because he was dehydrated, and balancing is important when riding a bike, especially when fatigued. In conclusion when it comes to as easy as riding a bike, you need to take precaution in what might lie ahead.

The setting affects the cyclist in many ways. It makes him feel hopeful, determined, alone, and completely exhausted. The desert-like terrain leaves him feeling very tired and thirsty. The bumpy road is hard to pedal over, and the endless stretches of land make him feel as if the next town is years away. While travelling, the cyclist recalls ìAt some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake blocked the majority of the pavement in front of meî (Kurmaskie, @NUM1). The tumbleweeds are a symbol of dry desert death. They remind the cyclist he is completely alone in a vast stretch of sand and rocks. Were the snake in the path to poison him heíd be under the beating sun until some other unfortunate cyclist found him. The heat adds to the danger, making the potential consequences of a snakebite even more dire. However, later on when he sees the sign for Gary and Wilberís fish camp, the hope is restored back to him. He is yet again determined because waiting somewhere near is the water he needs to keep him alive. In the end, the setting helped him to safely feel the hope deep inside of him.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, "not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." This affected the cyclist because he had to pedal harder to go up the hills, requiring more exertion, and he got short of breath due to this increased physical demand. Another example is, "At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me." This affected the cyclist because he had to wait for the snake to move, adding an unexpected delay, so it wouldn't bite him while he crossed it, presenting a potential danger. One last example is, "As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out @PERSON1 and Wilber." This had an effect on the cyclist because he was now happy to have water and to have reached his destination, providing a sense of relief and accomplishment after a challenging ride. These examples clearly demonstrate how the environmental conditions and unexpected obstacles directly impacted the cyclist's physical state, safety, and emotional well-being throughout his journey.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he saw “short, rolling hills,” “tumbleweeds” blowing across the road, and “a ridiculously large shake” advertised at a roadside diner, and he thought that he was not getting anywhere, as the unchanging landscape and tempting distractions made his journey seem endless.

Each area the author entered changed what he felt and experienced. At first, he is lent courage by his surroundings. When he passes through the first town, abandoned and empty, he is still confidant he can go on sparred by the lush green trees and the cool rivers around him that belied the hot sun overhead. They are basically the reason he continued to go on. Later on during his trek through the desolated empty desert, his bleak surroundings make him feel hopelessness as well as despair. Even in the small details, such as the ghost town or the pump, this is proven, as the ghost town brings him the first vestige of despair, and the useless pump only amplifies it. The setting's ability to influence his mental state highlights the powerful connection between environment and emotion, underscoring how much our surroundings can impact our inner selves and perception of the journey ahead. The scenario and scenery reflect and alter the author's mood throughout the story.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in many ways. They affected his confidence, his energy, and his determination. In the beginning of the essay the cyclist is very confident. Many things that the author talks about in the story affect him: One example is the old men that give him advice. They tell him that they know a great shortcut, which turns into the author's hardest ride ever, filled with unexpected hills and rough terrain. In the story “Rough Road Ahead Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is affected by features of the setting. The features the cyclist experienced during his ride affect his body and mind. At first the cyclist was on flat ground, drinking plenty of water and without fear. The conditions in the California desert were horrible for a cyclist. The temperature was extremely high and the humidity was very dry. There were also no stops to refill his water along the way, which is bad because the heat, lack of water, and all of his energy exertion leads to major dehydration and potential heatstroke. The conditions along this trip are not good for a cyclist and can be very dangerous, posing significant health risks.

In “Rough Road Ahead” by Joe Kurmaskie the main character faces a lot of trouble. First people give him the wrong directions, sending him off course. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" greatly. He started off happy because he was going to Yosemite National Park and had gotten shortcut advice that would make his trip shorter. "He rode into the morning with strong legs." Then he got to the first stop, which looked like a buzzing town at one time, but was now a ghost town. So he kept on with plenty of water, thinking he could make it to the next stop. The next stop was an old abandoned gas station where the only water was rusty and unpalatable. He was hitting the water pretty regularly, and the hot sun was beating down on him. The terrain changed, and he thought he would die and have the vultures pick his bones because he took advice from old timers, then came to his next stop, which seemed to be an old Welch's grape juice factory, deserted and baking in the sun. He thought he would die of thirst but he kept on with little water and a hot sun. Next the hills came, and he paced himself for a little time. Then he finally came to a modern-looking place with cool running water and an old man who gave him directions that he gladly took. After assuring himself he would die, he was relieved to see the old man's place; he would forever on listen to their advice because he made it, understanding that local knowledge was valuable.

The features of the setting affecting the cyclist was like saying you are old and that you know nothing at all. But it is not true. The first town the cyclist came to was like a ghost town because nobody was there. The next town wasnít any better because it was 25 miles down the road. The features of the setting in "DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT" affect the cyclist in a negative way. The terrain, initially mild, becomes rough and rolling, and since the author doesn't know the layout well, he struggles. The dwindling water supply adds immense stress, fueling worries about dehydration and the possibility of not reaching Yosemite National Park. However, with strength and determination, he finally arrives at Fish Camp, where he replenishes his water and regains his strength before continuing onward, ultimately demonstrating his resilience against the harsh environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is in a hot, dry place and has no water. He is pedaling up hills, and that makes him even more tired. The sun beats down relentlessly, baking the asphalt and radiating heat back up at him. His throat is parched, and his lips are cracked. The dude is probably dehydrated, and his conditions are getting worse! The combination of the harsh environment and physical exertion is clearly taking a toll, pushing him closer to exhaustion.

The features of the settings affects the cyclist a lot in the passage called ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî. Cyclist are in very good physical shape. They can cycle for along time; however, weather can affect the cyclist. This happened in the passage. The cyclist was determined and confident he could make this journey. ìI would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so- a test of my inner spirit. Even though he had confidence the features of the setting affected the cyclist. ìTumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snakeÖ.î. ìThe water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sipsî. The cyclist was tired and exhausted; the relentless sun beat down, and the rough terrain made each pedal stroke a struggle. The weather and terrain had worn him down. During this biker's adventure, heat and lack of water affect him. In this short story, when the cyclist feels lost he says, "I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." This suggests that the rider was faced with the extreme heat of the desert during his ride, a common challenge for anyone undertaking such a journey. He also says, "The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips." This quote shows that not only was he faced with the heat, but also with lack of water, further compounding the difficulty of his situation. These facts and quotes show the clear threats this biker faced on his long bike ride, highlighting the physical and mental challenges inherent in such an endeavor.

The settings affect the cyclist in more than one way. These ways are that he is running out of water, he might become dehydrated and he is unsure of the path he is on. With him running out of water, he is in real trouble. Because of the lack of water, not only might he die but he begins to see mirages, further disorienting him. His lack of water eventually leads to dehydration and he become uneasy about things. For example; in the text it says that he staggered into the store, a clear sign of his weakened condition. Because he is unsure of the path he is on, he begins to panic a little. Panicing isnít good especially considering that he is running low on water and is becoming dehydrated. Panic canít help to solve anything. The setting is in a dessert so he needs lets of water, which he runs low on. Desserts are extremly hot which causes a person to become dehydrated or die. Desserts have little shade, if any; and they have rough weather as well as rough landscape. For example, theyíre landscape is mostly all hot sand. Therefore, the setting does affect the cyclist, exacerbating his already precarious situation and contributing to his physical and mental distress.

The setting which is a desert in the summer affects the cyclist. For example, she couldn’t go as fast, “The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph,” so that affected his ability to find water. The setting was also really hot, so the cyclist had a hard time getting the water he needed to keep going. For example, “I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water wouldn’t cool down.” This reveals how the setting has got on to him, and he needs water badly. The desert setting also affects the cyclist's mind, causing him to hallucinate. He believed he was seeing mirages and he was afraid he was going to swallow a stone because he might hit a bump, further demonstrating the psychological toll. The desert setting affects the cyclist's ability to function, highlighting the overall detrimental impact of the harsh environment.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead” the features of the setting affect the cyclist. At points the setting made the author feel depressed and sad and at other times, happy and joyful. For example, the cyclist was pedaling and pedaling with nothing in sight. In twenty miles he saw camp, a sign that he was thirsty and had hope. When he pumped the water, no water came out. These parts of the setting gave the cyclist a bad effect. The cyclist even states "life can be so cruel." He obviously had a bad effect if he thought life was being cruel. At some point in the story the setting had a good affect on the reader. He is about to die of thirst when he sees a bait shop. This puts the cyclist in a good mood because he said “my troubles, thirst and fatigue, are all behind me.” Therefore, different settings in the story gave the author different effects.

The setting affected the cyclist because the terrain you ride on can determine how you ride. For instance when you have hills and dry weather like they did when it said “flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” the one easy terrain was now made more difficult and only added to his frustration and his dehydration from having no water. The change in terrain forced him to expend more energy. Also the heat contributed plenty and it was there the whole time. Sometimes he didn’t seem to notice or feel it but it was there and it was taking energy from him: Like when it said, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it.” He didn’t know it but that took from him so he drank more water and that affected his ability to take enough to complete the ride. Therefore, the environmental factors, both acknowledged and unnoticed, played a significant role in hindering the cyclist's performance.

The cyclist was riding in the hot, desert. This made him thirstier and less active. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, a testament to the relentless sun and draining ride, further diminishing his energy.

From my perspective, recycling impacts cyclists because improperly discarded trash, like soda cans, litters the environment. Cyclists often encounter this waste. The cyclist listens to the geogers, absorbing their local knowledge. After a while, he starts to get tired from the relentless pedaling. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He always kept his head up and was determined to make it to his destination. The first problem was when he came to the "fork of sorts" as he put it. He needed more water, but the pumps were rusty and all he could get out of them was a tarlike substance followed by blackish water. He tested it, hoping it was better than it looked, but it wasn’t. It tasted like battery acid. He was very thirsty, but had to move on, looking for another water supply. Another problem that occured was, while he was becoming dehydrated more & more by the minute and unsteady on his bike, a huge snake lay across the road. He had to slowly maneuver around it, though it was hard, he was successful and continued down the road. The third "obstacle" he ran into was he was so thirsty and finally had a chance for a drink, when to his dissappointment, he found an old abandoned welches grape juice factory. As nervie and upsetting as it was, he continued to move on, still determined to make it to his destination. He finally came up to a fishing supply store where he was able to take a break and get a nice drink! Even though the setting was tough, teasing, and ironic, the man made it through and still with a smile on his face.

Features of the setting affect the cyclist because of his endurance. The terrain dictates the amount of time he can ride without stopping, while the steepness impacts how long he can ride uphill, and the road surface affects how many bumps he rides over. Finally, the climate influences how long he can ride without a drink of water. Therefore, the cyclist's endurance is constantly tested and shaped by the surrounding environment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by the changes that occur while riding his bike. The features of the setting affected the cyclist by for the roads and heat has. The setting of the cyclist clearly influences his mood. From the beginning to end, the outside world reflects the tormils in his head. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. He is riding his bike along the road and encounters a dilemma. The feature of the setting affect the cyclist by giving him hope that the finishing line is not far, and there was nothing in sight – no cars, buildings, or structure of any kind. The author was affected in many ways by the conclusion. He was tired from the blazing heat, didn't have much water, and got lost. Water simply was limiting, and as he went farther and farther, it seemed like things would get worse and worse for him. A man had given him the wrong directions, and he probably hadn't been off his porch in decades, the author says, making the situation even more frustrating.

The cyclist explained how the road conditions changed as one progressed. An example was the sign: “Rough road ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed limit.” Also, the road was dry. The cyclist pointed out that initially, the asphalt was smooth and well-maintained, allowing for comfortable riding. However, further along, the surface began to show signs of wear and tear, with cracks appearing and the occasional pothole marring the path. The texture changed, becoming coarser, and one could feel the vibrations through the handlebars. Consequently, reducing speed became a necessity for safety and comfort as the initial smooth road degraded considerably, requiring greater caution and awareness.

In the story, there are many elements that affected the cyclist in his journey. The first feature of the setting that affects him is the old water pump, which did not work, and when it did, the water from it tasted horrible. The next obstacle on his journey was the rough terrain. "Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills," was how he described it. This change in elevation made the cycling significantly more difficult. When the narrator finally finds a building, it turns out to be abandoned and offered no help. Eventually he finds a town and rest after his long journey, and learns his lesson from before not to take advice from people he doesn’t know, showcasing the importance of self-reliance.

Well the features were rough desert like features. For a cyclist this terrain is difficult. For example the lack of water, and the battery acid flavor of what little they found, affected the cyclist in a major way. This made hydration a constant struggle, impacting performance and overall well-being on the arduous journey, severely hindering progress.

'Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills'' (Kurmaskie @NUM1). When the cyclist realized the terrain was becoming difficult, he became more frustrated and felt a sense of hopelessness. ''Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt; and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn't been off their porch in decades caused me to laugh. It was a sad, hopeless laugh'' (@NUM1). He wasn't going to die, but even though he was struggling, he felt the situation was overly dramatic. Fortunately, the man survived. He would live on, telling people not to blindly trust the advice of those detached from reality. ''Never accept travel advice from a collection of old timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office'' (@NUM3). He was on a long, hot road, and he started taking sarcastic jabs at the old men; he even planned to revise his writing about them. ''I made a mental note to change that paragraph'' (@NUM4). The man was not obligated to follow their directions. Ultimately, his decision to shorten his trip, coupled with the challenges of rough terrain, heat, and dehydration, led to feelings of hopelessness, anger, and self-pity, highlighting his somewhat self-centered reaction to the adversity he faced.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way is that the cyclist is traveling through the high deserts of California in June, meaning the heat is intense and relentless. Another affect said in the story was that the cyclist made it to a town where the water pump was all rusted and with all his strength, he worked the handle and got a tarlike substance followed by brackish water which he couldn’t drink, leaving him desperate and dehydrated. Also, the cyclist had been hitting his water bottles regularly, indicating a growing concern about his dwindling water supply. Lastly, the old-timers said the towns would be close when really they were far apart, adding to his frustration and misguiding his expectations. These harsh conditions of heat, lack of water, and misinformation greatly impacted the cyclist’s physical and mental endurance.

There are many things that can affect a cyclist's journey. This cyclist seemed to have bad wick. He starts off mentioning that he is planning a trip to Yosemite and the men that hear this give him a tip about a shortcut. The cyclist is pretty confident in what they tell him, so he follows their suggestions, trusting their supposed wisdom. He ends up getting lost due to the shortcut being outdated. The cyclist is also travelling in the high deserts of California in June. That means that he is travelling in summer with dry air, exacerbating dehydration. When he gets to the first "town" he sees, he can't get the water he needs to rehydrate his body, finding the place deserted. He also runs into a snake while travelling through the desert, which startles him and slows him down. Because it's hot, and he's tired and dehydrated, he begins to see mirages that affect him mentally, adding to his distress. All of these features cause the cyclist to take one long, tiring journey through the desert. Well the setting was the lil boy was on the bike and he meets this old man and the man toke him a short cut. So he took dis road and I guess something went wrong. The shortcut looked harmless enough, but soon the path narrowed and grew dark, the trees closing in around him.

In “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the main character, the cyclist. After he first journeyed from the house where he met the old men, he rode over much flat desert terrain, where the sun beat down and dehydrated him. Soon, though the terrain changed. “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.” This tests his endurance even more as he has to maneuver down the hills while dehydrated and ready to collapse from exhaustion. The relentless landscape, first flat and then hilly, thus becomes a powerful antagonist, pushing the cyclist to his physical limits.

Hot, @CAPS1, @CAPS2-all are the features of the setting that affect the cyclist. First, the hot days with not a lot of water to drink will cause him to get dehydrated, impacting his performance. Also, there is no one around to help him if he gets lost or encounters trouble. Joe Kurmaskie explains ìthere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structur of any kind,î emphasizing the isolation. Finally the creature was a large snake that came along on the road, creating an unexpected obstacle. So he had to move around it, adding a moment of tension and potential danger to his ride, highlighting the challenges posed by the natural environment.

Setting is one of the most important needs for a cyclist if the terrain or weather are bad; the hotter it is for a cyclist, its necessary to supplement fluids and electrolytes to maintain performance and prevent dehydration.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because the cyclist faces challenging problems. For example, the terrain changes. A flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills, and then a large highway. This shows that when he arrived, the road was not in good condition and required him to navigate a significant jump. The changing landscape clearly presents difficulties for the cyclist.

The oppressive heat of the setting threatened the cyclist, raising the risk of heatstroke and even death. A snake unexpectedly crossed his path, startling him, but he managed to get past it. He then spotted an abandoned Welch factory, a building that offered potential shelter but was ultimately unusable. Further down the road, he found a fish restaurant and gratefully used the bathroom to get some water. Inside, someone inquired about his destination and tried to mislead him, but thankfully he still had his map, so he decided to trust it and navigate his own way. Despite the challenges of the environment and the unsolicited advice, he remained focused on his map and relied on his own navigation.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead,” a cyclist relies on outdated information from some older men, and their directions lead him astray, even proving dangerous. The setting exacerbates his predicament; he is in a desolate desert landscape dotted with ghost towns, and the intense heat diminishes his hope of survival. For example, at a fork in the road, he finds “several rusty pumps” and “one ramshackle shed.” Finding these decrepit structures, instead of a functioning water source, is demoralizing, especially with his dwindling water supply and the oppressive heat. The lack of usable resources further erodes his confidence. Later, the story emphasizes the desolation: “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This isolation significantly affects him because he has been cycling for a long time, is out of water, and is nearly exhausted. The absence of any sign of civilization diminishes his hope; he feels trapped in an empty desert with little chance of escape. In conclusion, in “Rough Road Ahead,” the setting plays a crucial role in undermining the cyclist's hope and confidence, because the abandoned and scorching desert environment amplifies his sense of despair and reduces his belief in his ability to survive the ordeal.

Well since the cyclist is in a desert and out of water, he is probably not going to be happy. The "ghost towns" aren't really a boost of confidence either, adding to his feelings of isolation. The rugged hills made him angry too, forcing him to dismount and push his bike. The heat affected him the most, sapping his strength and making the journey even more arduous.

The features of the land affect the cyclist in many ways. For example, the first two buildings that he came to were abandoned, so he could not get any food or water to replenish his energy. Also, he noticed that the terrain was changing from flat to rolling hills, and this change will certainly put more strain on his legs as he pedals uphill. Finally, the land was hot and dry, which was making him dehydrated and impacting his performance. This is how the features of the land affected the cyclist and his journey.

In this story the setting affects the cyclist in many ways. He tries to get directions but the people he asked really didn't know what they were talking about, offering vague gestures and uncertain nods. That's why you have to be careful about who you ask for help. Then he needs a drink, hoping for some refreshment, but that doesn't work out too well because the water from the old pump ends up tasting like battery acid, leaving a metallic tang in his mouth. Then the cyclist begins to be on his way again and finds the same difficulty in the road. The road is in bad condition, riddled with potholes and loose gravel, and he must go slower than the speed limit. At this point, with the sun beating down and his throat parched, it felt like he was going to die. Luckily, he found a dilapidated gas station with a working bathroom and gratefully drank from the sink, the cool water a welcome relief. The setting's challenges truly tested his endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a few ways. Early in the essay, the cyclist states he “enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers.” The cyclist was enjoying himself and the atmosphere, but then the mood changed quickly to doubt when he didn't listen to the “collection of old-timers who havent left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office” and his depleting water source quickly became a cause for concern. Doubt was soon followed by relief when he saw the sign for Gary and Wilber’s Fish camp and was able to get a drink from the bathroom faucets. Relief was then followed by satisfaction when he “promised himself right then that he'd always stick to [the very good map] in the future,” demonstrating how the challenges presented by the unfamiliar setting ultimately led to a valuable lesson learned.

The setting had a bad affect on the author in many ways. One reason is that the heat of the setting caused the author to become dehydrated. Dehydration is when your body begins to shut down due to lack of water, and this sapped his strength. The setting also affected him by draining his confidence and making him seek out water. Finding none, ìI hung my head,î which suggests that he was depressed and discouraged by the harsh conditions. This proves that no matter who or what you follow there is always a possibility of death from any circumstances. Therefore this is how the author was affected by the setting he was biking.

I think the settings made it a little more challenging, preventing one from giving up easily. This also shows that you often do better in life when challenged and pushed beyond your comfort zone, ultimately leading to growth.

The setting affects the cyclist because it is in a warm, dry climate, causing him to sweat profusely and requiring him to drink more water. When no one else was around, it was more difficult for him to continue, especially if there was a chance that he was on the wrong path, with nobody available to tell him otherwise. With only abandoned buildings, if any, water was unavailable, which made the journey more tiring and physically straining. If the setting were different, with cooler temperatures and populated areas, this story would not have been as traumatic, emphasizing the critical role of environment in shaping experience.

The features of the setting really affected the cyclist. The author wrote of rough terrain and isolation. "Flat roads was replaced by short, rolling hills tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake." After reading this information and the descriptions, I inferred that the author was alone in the desert with awful conditions. I also infer a tone of resentment. He seemed to wish he hadn't taken the "shortcut" that landed him in the desert. The hot weather was another factor that affected the author, "trying to keep my balance in a dehydrated state." The features of the setting that most affected the cyclist were the water pump, the Welchís Factory, and the fish camp. The pump affected him because he was very thirsty, and at first he thought he would have a chance to get water, he was excited and he pumped the water out, as he wrote, ìwith all my strength.î But he had to go on thirsty, (a very risky thing to do while cycling) because ìit had the flavor of battery acid.î Next, the Welchís Factory affected him by killing his spirits. He was already feeling bad from the lack of water, but seeing the mocking, ironic image of ìa sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juiceî, made him feel worse. It reflected his own desperate situation, all refreshments in the past, there was nothing left. I had a similar experience once. I am alergic to peanuts. One time, on a long car trip, I had slept through lunch, so I was starving, and we were on a long stretch of highway with no buildings to be seen. After two hours, we finally saw a sign for a nearby restaurant: @CAPS2ís peanut shack. I nearly cried. The last thing that affected the cyclist was the fish camp. It saved his life. He arrived and "drank deeply from the sink." He was so happy that he wanted to kiss the owners of the camp. This also relates to the car trip I mentioned, because after hours of hunger, we found a very good sushi bar, and sushi is my favorite food, thus illustrating how the environment can profoundly impact one's physical and emotional state.
