The features of the setting affect the cyclist because sometimes, it made him lose some courage and optimism. "and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke on a gorgeous day" is an example of how he lost courage. He wanted to be brave and be strong, but the hot day and all the sweat made the author feel weak. "I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear" is an example of how the author lost some optimism. He didn’t want to die, but he kept telling himself that he was going to; he should have thought to himself that he was going it make it, but the setting was just to rough. The harshness of the environment, coupled with the cyclist's physical discomfort, stripped away his positive outlook. There were bumps along his ride, and the sun beating down his thirst, he became less courageous and less optimistic, demonstrating the powerful influence of the setting on his mental state, diminishing his initial resolve.

The features of his journey are cruel. "Rolling hills" make him work harder to get over them. The more he works, the more he sweats, and therefore he needs fluids to do so. The lack of water he has does not help his dehydration. Poisonous plants don't really bother him if he leaves them alone. The condition of the roads adds onto the hills. Rough roads make him work harder to get through and then over the hills, increasing his exhaustion. So this guy is getting it pretty rough on his arduous journey.

Some of the features of the setting that affected the cyclist were the rough terrain and the hills. It says in the reading "a flat road was replaced by short rolling hills," this would wear a person out without a good supply of water and make him unsure in what direction he is traveling. And another thing that affects him is the hot June weather in California, which would certainly increase the risk of dehydration and exhaustion on such a physically demanding ride. Thus, these environmental factors combined to create a challenging and potentially dangerous situation for the cyclist.

Throughout ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the features of the setting affect the cyclist. The cyclist was traveling through a very dry area, where it was very hot, dry and dangerous. There was no water to be found and the terrain is were rough and bumpy. The speaker stated, ìAt some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously lareg snake...î (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist faced land blockings and dangerous animals, forcing him to navigate carefully. This caused him to slow down a little bit. It was extremely hot out in the setting he was in. The cyclist was in the deserts of California in June. The speaker stated, ì@CAPS1 rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on gorgeous day in June...î (Kurmaskie @NUM1). The cyclist was experiencing the high temperatures of the setting, battling dehydration. The cyclist witnessed the intense features of the setting, impacting his journey and highlighting the harsh realities of the environment.

The features of the setting effect the cyclist in many ways. The relentless heat and barren landscape contribute to his mental state; he becomes delusional when he said that if he were lucky one of the stones would be lodged in his throat, illustrating the desperation induced by the harsh environment. Also, he is dehydrated because he uses all of his water and is having to push hard to make it to the next town, further demonstrating how the demanding setting takes a toll on his physical and psychological well-being. The challenging environment, therefore, profoundly impacts the cyclist, pushing him to his limits.

The features of the setting started out easy like a road that's flat, cool lines to keep him cool and not hot. Then it got harder, lack of water, road is not flat anymore, snakes, the cool pines are gone. The sun beat down relentlessly, and the cracked earth offered little respite, showing the shift from a welcoming path to an unforgiving trial.

In the story "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit," the features of the setting greatly affected the cyclist. As he was riding, he was passing through desert during June, a very hot month. There is not much water present in a desert (that would be part of the definition of a desert) and so, particularly in the even-hotter-than-normal June sun, he was at risk of running out of water. Had he been driving through, say, a forest or perhaps rolling grasslands, he might not have been in such danger, and could have merely looked for a river or creek for water if he was desperate. Another thing that might have affected the cyclist would have been the effect of the desert on his mind. When people think of deserts they often think of dry, barren wastelands, complete with buzzards and maybe a dead cow skull, as in movies. Deserts are intimidating; they have a bad reputation and so, as he was riding through and was low on water, the thought of death, how he was, "going to die and the birds would pick (him) clean," was running through his now-terrified head. Had he been in a city or in rolling farmland, he might not have been as terrified; those places offer perceived safety. There are people in those places, and places to be safe there, but, in his desert, he had neither, allowing him to give way to despair and make rash decisions. Setting does a lot to influence stories, so it is important to keep that in mind when reading.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist because he was out of water in a desert-like environment, and there was no firm ground for most of it, so he was on his own. The cyclist was affected in the story when he says, "I got down on my hands and knees, working the water handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tar-like substance oozed out followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees." That affected him because he was drinking a lot of water before he got to that point in his trip, and he was almost out, so he desperately needed to replenish his supply. The harsh, desolate setting, devoid of reliable resources, left him with no readily available place to get more water. This lack of access to potable water, a direct consequence of the environment, significantly impacted his situation.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by getting dehydrated, getting tired, and by getting lost. After the cyclist was on the road for a while he had drank almost all of his water, but he still had a while to go before he got to his destination. He was going to try to find somewhere to stop so he could pick up more water but there was nothing around, just the seemingly endless road stretching before him. He also got tired because he was out in the sun, had barely any water, and he didn’t know where he was going, making the journey physically and mentally draining. One last example was that he was lost. There were no cars, buildings, or people to ask for directions or offer assistance. So if he were to get hurt or sick no one would have been able to help him, leaving him vulnerable and isolated. In conclusion, being dehydrated, tired and getting lost were the ways the features of the setting affected the cyclist, highlighting the harsh and unforgiving nature of his surroundings.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he runs out of water because he is trying to traverse the terrain. In the setting there is a desert in California that he is riding through on a bike, "I was travelling through the high deserts of California." The word "high" means that there were hills which would make the journey even more difficult, requiring more exertion and thus more water. The hills appeared later in the story as the cyclist said "flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills." When the speaker says "replaced" he is trying to show a change of terrain, indicating a shift from easier to more challenging riding. Another feature of the setting is the tumbleweed that he crosses after the hills, "tumbleweeds crossed in path." The tumbleweeds made him remember he was in the desert because tumbleweeds are associated with the desert which brought up the thought of dying and being picked apart by birds. The harsh desert environment, with its hills and sparse vegetation, clearly contributes to the cyclist's struggle and eventual dehydration.

Well if the setting relates to the theme then the story will make sense, like if it’s a sad story and it’s a ugly rainy day then it will match very nicely. That’s how the setting makes it better, enhancing the overall impact and emotional resonance of the narrative through its descriptive elements.

If it is hot out you can dehydrate quickly. Also, if it is off road and hilly you use a lot of energy. It can be rough on equipment, body, and mind. Make sure you dress appropriately and carry lots of water. Next, make sure your tires are inflated and all equipment is working properly. Then, plan a good route that you can stop at places and catch a breath or some water. Also, make sure you eat well, food provides a lot of energy. These preparations will help ensure a safer and more enjoyable experience.

In the setting of the essay; "Rough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit." had a great affect on the cyclist. It made him even more determined to finish because the terrain was so hard to ride through. For example, "At some point, tumber weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake-it really did look like a diamond back-back the majority of the pavement in front of me, I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state." The author fully explains how no matter how bad the obstacles are he comes across he keeps trying to easy on by. The terrain affect the character by keeping him determined. This happens to many people in their sports, pushing through adversity to reach their goals. For example in football they take any problems and use them as reasons to push themselves harder to finish the game. Therefore, the challenging terrain in the essay serves as a catalyst for the cyclist's determination, mirroring how athletes in various sports harness obstacles to fuel their drive and persevere.

In the story the cyclist was affected. The cyclist was affected by the directions of the old man. It says that they gave it to him to help him out. That it was a shortcut. I think the cyclist thinks the directions are out of date. The reason I think this is that in the second sentence of the story it says, "never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." The feature of the setting also affected him because he had to ride up and down through what he thought of as rough terrain. These outdated directions and the challenging landscape, therefore, contributed to the cyclist's difficulties on his journey.

In Joe Kurmaskieís ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the features of the setting affect the cyclist alot. The terrain has a great deal to do with it. Also, the heat: First, the terrain affects the cyclist. It affects the cyclist because there is alot of hills. The text says, "With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill.î In order to go down a hill, you had to have gone up a hill. So, having to use the energy to pedal up hills affected the cyclist alot. Also, constantly changing gears for the inclines and declines would add to the physical strain. Next, the heat affected the cyclist. I know this because the text says ìand the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke.î This proves it is extremely hot outside. Heat would affect the cyclist because heat prevents you from functioning at your greatest ability. The cyclist is clearly pushing his limits in these conditions. That is how the features of the setting in ëDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî affect the cyclist. The terrain affects the cyclist because of the hills. The heat because it drains your energy quick.

In ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not exceed posted speed limit,î the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. One way it affected him is the towns were old and deserted. In the story he said ìThis place might have been a thriving little spot but it was a ghost town.î He could not get any water or any directions, leaving him stranded and unsure of his path. The features of the setting affected the cyclist because the roads were bumby and there were many hills. ìFlat road was replaced by short, rolling hills.î Consequently, the cyclist had to use all his power to manuever over the hills, draining his energy. The third reason why the setting affected the cyclist was the weather and that it was a desert. ìI was traveling through the deserts of California in June.î He was hot, sweaty and thirsty, struggling against the harsh conditions. He was also tired and desperate to find water and a town that was not deserted, highlighting the severity of his situation. The features of the setting affected the cyclist in ìRough Road Ahead: Do not exceed Posted Speed Limit,î by the roads, deserted towns and the lack of water, all contributing to his increasingly difficult journey.

ìRough road ahead do not exceed posted speed limits.î The setting is a long road with no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. The cyclist could be affected by the rough road that he has to ride down; the jarring bumps threaten to throw him off balance. The sign serves as a stark reminder of the challenges ahead, urging caution and awareness, as the cyclist must heed the warning to safely navigate the rough terrain.

In the essay by Joe Kurmaskie, he describes his experience of bike riding in the desert. The setting affects the cyclist in many ways throughout the writing. At first, Kurmaskie is confident as he listens to a group of old codgers giving him advice. The setting is calm and happy and Kurmaskie writes that he ìenjoyed the serenity of an eary-summer eveningî. The word ìserenityî gives the affect of calm and peace, reflecting his initial optimism. However, as Kurmaskie proceeds into his journey, the setting changes. He is troubled by the ìramshackle shed, several rutsy pumps, and a corral that couldnít hold the lamest muleî in a ghost town that he meets in the desert, suggesting a loss of hope. Even later, the terrain changes and he sees a sign stating ìRough Road Aheadî, further diminishing his spirits. Kurmaskieís confidence turns into even deeper doubt and worry as his water supply runs low, amplifying the harshness of the environment. Finally, Kurmaskie sees a sign for a fish camp. Here, his hope returns as he finds a ìrather modern bathroomî where he can stop to get a drink, signaling a shift back to optimism. As the setting changes, Kurmaskieís confidence is followed by determination and then relief, demonstrating the powerful influence of the environment on his emotional state and journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is in a desert-like place with only a mirage of a water surface, and he could get tired quickly. I would never have asked old people for help; he should have asked someone who was in charge of a store, because those people likely get asked for directions many times. Also, he could have died if that snake had bitten him, or from what he said, "heatstroke." Thus, the harsh environment posed significant dangers, and seeking informed help was crucial for survival.

Having diligently collected directions from a series of venerable old men, the cyclist confidently embarked on his journey to Yosemite National Park. The initial amusement at discovering the first town to be a complete ghost town didn't shake his conviction. However, arriving at a desolate spot marked by "one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule" began to erode his certainty, especially as his water supply dwindled alarmingly. The landscape unfolded with rolling hills, the occasional snake slithering across the path, and the relentless tumbleweeds, each element chipping away at his initial enthusiasm. The abandoned juice factory proved to be a particularly devastating blow, the sight of it a cruel reminder of his parched throat and fading hope. Finally, reaching Gary Wilber's fish camp and replenishing his water supply was a turning point, revitalizing not only his body but also his dwindling spirits. With each discouraging landmark passed, the author's confidence waned, highlighting how the absence of hope can be as debilitating as physical hardship when pursuing even the sunniest and breeziest of vacations, ultimately draining one's inner reserves.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist negatively because he was in the desert in the summer with little water and no stores to get a drink at. For example, he says, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This explains how his setting affected him because he had nowhere to go or get a drink, emphasizing his isolation. This harsh environment, devoid of resources and human contact, clearly presented a significant challenge to his survival and well-being. That is my reason why the cyclist's settings were negative.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in bad ways. The rocky road and steep hills made him peddle harder, straining his muscles with each rotation. The old people made him go through the rocky way when they pointed him in the wrong direction. The temperature from the desert made him thirsty so he ran out of water fast, He said ìWhen I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.î The heat could have killed him anytime. For example ìWide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from the heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June.î This ride this man took to Yosemite was a very dangerous ride, and the harsh environmental factors contributed significantly to the peril he faced.

The setting can greatly affect the cyclist. The place can change what happens and how it happens. For example, if the story had taken place in Alaska, the cyclist would not have had, "Wide rings of sweat circling my shirt," and instead have been fighting off hypothermia. The setting is very important because it affects all of the details in the writing, influencing everything from the cyclist's clothing to the challenges they face, ultimately shaping the narrative.

At first the terrain was fine and he confident. But when he reached the first town it looked like one of those ghost towns in the movies. The next town didn't come up when he was told it would. The terrain was that of a desert, no water for miles. His throat felt like sandpaper, but he stayed determined. And he made it to some water though, a small spring bubbling weakly from the parched earth, just enough to quench his thirst and renew his resolve.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” For example, he finds a “ramshackle shed” and tries to find water. It affected him, because it says, “I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two hundred degrees.” The quote meaning that he was determined to find water and perhaps anything. The desolate and unforgiving environment, characterized by the shed's disrepair and the pump's rusted state, directly contributes to his desperation and willingness to endure discomfort in his search. This illustrates how the harsh setting shapes his actions and highlights the challenges he faces.

The setting affected the cyclist by depriving him of hydration and weakening him. The demanding environment, with its lack of water sources, took a toll. The large hills and rough roads ebbed away every bit of his strength and wore him down. The narration states, ìOver one long, crippling hillî (kurmaskie @NUM1). This word choice reflects the writerís feeling about his adventure. Words like ìlongî and ìcripplingî show that the trip was a horrible experience, highlighting the arduous and painful nature of the journey.

Pride, determination, relief – all are things that the cyclist felt during his long bike ride. First, the cyclist started off riding on fresh legs and good directions, but after a while down the road he started to doubt the old men, “a diary with my last entry in place of old men, their wisdom, and their been a sense of direction, I made a mental move to change it.” After feeling that the direction might be rough, he rode out of pride to get to his destination, pushing onward despite his growing uncertainty. Next, the rider had great determination to get to his destination and did many things, “I gathered – a few pebbles and stock them in my mouth to take my mind off of thirst.” This quote shows that he would do almost anything to keep going, enduring discomfort to stay on course. Finally, the cyclist was fatigued when he arrived at the @CAPS1 shop because he then knew the old men were right and would reach his destination, “As I stumbled into rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink this quote shows he was polite naturally to get water but to know the men were right." Ultimately, the cyclist experienced a range of emotions, from doubt to determination, culminating in the relief of reaching his destination and acknowledging the wisdom he had initially questioned.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist when he was thirsty. A sand blasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice in his mouth could be seen. This proves that the rider was thirsty because the previous paragraph describes his last burst of energy going down a hill. He was also sweating a lot and wiping sweat from his eyes, further suggesting dehydration and the need for refreshment. The image, therefore, highlights his physical state and intensifies the feeling of thirst.

I work better when I can feel the environment. I think the same goes for cycling in the mountains; fresh air and no worries on your mind, then cycling can become fun. Like the climates into the ease, even the fresh air, the fine trees, and the environment makes him feel better, so for cyclists, the environment plays a vital role, enhancing the overall experience and enjoyment.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in a major way. The setting affected the cyclist's performance. For example, the harsh temperature started to make his pedaling sluggish, and his muscles began to ache sooner than usual. The settings also made the cyclist a little frightened; for instance, the cyclist came across a snake that he was terrified of, causing him to momentarily lose his balance. Again, the settings affected the cyclist by tempting him. For example, the river tempted the cyclist to stop riding and go get a drink of water, slowing his progress. In conclusion, the setting had a major affect on the cyclist.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. For one, a lot of the settings discouraged the cyclist. This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time- say, before the last world war- but on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. As soon as the cyclist hits this "town" he realizes that the old men's advice might not have been so great. The dry desert affects the cyclist the most. This hot climate makes the cyclist extremely thirsty, hot, and sweaty. "Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heatstroke..." The cyclist's tone here is sarcastic but he is still concerned about his health because of the heat and lack of water. The fact that there is nothing living around the cyclist also affects him. Since he’s talked to the old men for directions he hasn’t seen a glimpse of life, or buildings or anything, not even a stray animal. So this definitely discourages the cyclist and makes him lose his will to continue his journey. In conclusion, the features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist in many negative ways, from his physical discomfort to his dwindling motivation.

The cyclist tracked through a barren land trying to get to a land of rivers and valleys. Tracking through the first town, the cyclist saw a ramshackle shed, rusty pumps, and corral located in the desert of California. The cyclist was very angry that the old men led him into this barren town; however, he kept hope and traveled to the next town. There, he found an abandoned fruit juice factory and bottling plant; this discouraged the cyclist, and he started to give up. “I was going to die,” he claimed, with all hope lost. The man feels like there is nothing left, and it's the old men who caused this. Then finally, he came across a bait shop, which he found on his own, giving him huge relief. The features affect his attitude because in a barren land, you lose hope, as did the cyclist. Therefore, what's around us affects us, as in education, friendship, and survival, demonstrating how the environment significantly shapes our perspectives and chances.

In the essay, ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,'' the cyclist is affected both emotionally and physically by the features of the setting. At the start, when he came to a deserted shed with rusty pumps, he began to feel discouraged. ì[The] sight was troubling,î (page @NUM1) as the desolation hinted at challenges ahead. Later on in the essay, the terrain changes from flat land to short, rolling hills and tumbleweeds began to pass. The cyclist is definitely affected by the change in terrain. He is now exhausted but continues to pump his legs and ride on, demonstrating a physical struggle against the environment. Before the end of his ride, the cyclist reaches an abandoned @ORGANIZATION1. The setting now includes a large picture of a young boy drinking a refreshing glass of juice. The author seems almost defeated by this. ìI hung my head'' (page @NUM2) he confessed, perhaps feeling a pang of longing. In the end, once he finds an old fisherman's store, he is relieved; seeing the store from a distance excited the author, because he could finally have a drink. The author's mood and body were greatly affected by the features of the setting.

The features of the setting in "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie show that as the day goes on the cyclist becomes tired and worn out from his long ride through rough terrain trying to find his way back home; the unforgiving landscape clearly takes its toll. Then he saw some buildings down a hill and said, "With what I believed was my last burst of energy, I maneuvered down the hill" (Kurmaskie). After the arduous journey, the rider, surprisingly, gets home and immediately anticipates doing it again, suggesting an unexpected appreciation for the challenge despite the demonstrated hardships.

The main affect is the lack of water. It is in June, while riding his bike in California. Therefore it’s going to be very hot and he’ll need a lot of water to stay hydrated. When he sees that Welch’s Grape Juice factory, it just makes him think of his thirst even more. Also the terrain he is riding is not the easiest. He starts out riding on flat ground but then is riding on hills and not so flat terrain. This didn’t help his dehydration. That's why you should always carry a lot of water with you if you’re riding a bike during the summer, especially given the intense sun and exertion involved in cycling.

The affects of the settings was how hot it was and the cyclist road he was on. The rider said it was June in the summer time, very hot, making the ride physically taxing. And the roads were not smooth, they were very old and ragady, adding to the challenge.

The sun beat down, each ray a tiny hammer against the cyclist's resolve. He focused on the road ahead, a ribbon of shimmering asphalt snaking through the hills. The heat rose from the pavement, a palpable force. His water bottle, already light, offered little comfort against the mounting thirst. Each uphill climb was a fresh assault, testing his endurance. He gripped the handlebars, his knuckles white as he navigated around a particularly rough patch, the jarring impact sending vibrations through his weary arms. Despite the harsh conditions, he pressed on, driven by a silent determination to conquer the ride, pushing through the discomfort, the challenge becoming a personal test.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist because he is trying to bike up hills and down hills, which can be very tiring. Also, the hot air can dehydrate him, which can cause him to pass out. Along with the dry air, there is dry land, which means there is no place to stop for water or take a **break**. The rough **terrain** make the biking harder because it involves more energy than biking on a smooth path. Finally, the snake in the middle of the road made it hard for the biker to go around. If the snake would have bitten him he could have died from poison. Thus, the environmental conditions and unexpected wildlife encounters significantly impede the cyclist's journey, making it both physically demanding and potentially dangerous.

The setting in the essay "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" was very hot and dry, with very little shade or moisture, at some point maybe even none at all. This weather affected the author because he had no water at all, so he was getting more dehydrated the further he went, making the journey increasingly arduous and impacting his physical state.

The cyclist's predicament stemmed directly from ignoring the adage, "Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." This affected his journey because if he hadn't shown them his map and allowed them to offer their unsolicited opinions, he likely would have avoided considerable trouble. He trusted their outdated knowledge, which ultimately led him astray, demonstrating how adhering to this specific feature of the setting—avoiding advice from those disconnected from the present reality—could have significantly altered his experience for the better.

In ìRough Road Ahead: Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî by Joe Kurmaskie the setting of the terrain was hot and water draining. In the text it says ìFollowed by blackish water feeling somewhere in the neighborhood of two-hundred degreesî this proves that the cyclist is exaggerating about the very hot temperature of the high deserts of California. The cyclist humorously describes the water's extreme heat, adding to the challenging atmosphere. The setting is also water draining and had to stop in the desert town to refill his water bottle as in the text says ìI got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of a rusted water pump with all my strength.î This proves that the cyclist had to stop for water and using much power to pump it out. The struggle to obtain water highlights the harsh conditions and the cyclist's determination. In conclusion always prepare for the worst but hope for the best.

In the story, there are many features of the setting that affect the cyclist. One setting feature is the rolling of steep hills. The hills make the cyclist exhausted and even more desperate for water. For example, in the story it says, ìOver one long crippling hill, a building came into viewî. This shows that the hill was very hard and strenuous to get over. By using the word crippling it informs us that the hill was brutal and very hard to get over. This also makes the cyclist very tired and question whether or not he can even make it to his destination. Another setting feature that affects the cyclist is the absence of any civilization on his cycling path. While he was riding he notices that there is nobody around to help him if he gets in trouble or needs water. The absence of people makes him feel stressed and worried about his journey. It shows this in the story when he say, ìThere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kindî. Also it says in the story ìI was going to die and the bird would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive out door gear and a diary with the last entry on the parse of old men". This shows that there was nobody around to help him and he knew it. He thought he would die alone and that birds would eat him. He was obviously worried about the absence of people, which amplified his feelings of isolation and despair. Thus, the harsh landscape and lack of human presence significantly contribute to the cyclist's struggle.

Usually the features, setting has a major effect upon the cyclist. The features, setting relates, and describes the harsh, and eventually relief condition of the cyclist. The setting relates to the person and plays a role, which the cyclist can observe. One reason how the features of the setting affects the cyclist is it shows the various problems that are being faced with the cyclist. For example, the cool pines, no one in sight, and I am alone. The way how this interepts a clear meaning, I the cyclist needs help getting home, and eventually by traveling, he needs water, to fill his thirst. For instance, the isolation of the setting amplifies the cyclist's vulnerability, while the downhill path offers a glimmer of hope despite his exhaustion. The features of the setting had a big impact on the cyclist. When he started that ride, he was confident that the ìold timersî were right about which directions and roads he had to take to get to Yosemite National Park. Though the sun was bearing down, he refused to give up, just as he saysî The sun was beginning to beat down, but I hardy noticed.î He came up to places that were worn down and deserted, so he knew he was alone if anything happened. The desert heat had made him down his water pretty regularly, so he tried to get more, as in, "I got on my hands and knees When l tried a drop or two, it has the flavor of battery acid" paragraph @NUM1. He was so thirsty that he would drink hot water. Then he thought he has only @NUM2 miles to go, so he kept going. He weakening as he pedaled along the changing terrain as he was ìtrying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. ìWith what little energy he had last, he had passed an abandoned Well be Grape Juice factory, which probably tested his patience and sanity. He had resorted to, ìgathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouthî just to keep his mind off his thirst. He was losing hope when he came upon ì Gary and wilberís fish camp best betî then he felt relieved after he was able to get cool water. By then he's learned his lesson, to stick to his map, as the harsh, unforgiving landscape ultimately forced him to abandon his reliance on outdated advice and embrace a more reliable method of navigation.

In the author's recollection of his long and tiresome bike ride he talked about the struggles he had to face. When he set out that morning he asked some old guys on a porch for directions to Yosemite. They told him that they knew the way and that they knew a shortcut. He chose to take their advice but later regretted it. When he found the towns that they spoke of all he found was ghost towns. "Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office." He does eventually reach a town where he finds signs of life. There he asks another old guy if he knows the way to Yosemite; the guy says he has a good map. All along his ride he was plagued by the sun and lack of water. The sun made him hot and thirsty, which forced him to drink a lot of his water. When he reached his last few sips he resisted from drinking it and began losing consciousness. "I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June." His poor choices and the harsh conditions nearly proved fatal, highlighting the importance of reliable information and adequate preparation for such a journey.

A cyclist can only travel as fast as slow as he pedals. If the setting is a humid sunny day he can’t go too fast due to his lung capacity being limited in the thick air. If it is a warm but windy day he has to watch his speed to keep from getting hurt by a sudden gust. Basically unless the weather is nice or safe enough, he will not go fast, valuing safety. But his safety care comes first, so it depends on the weather mostly, but also the time of the day. If it is night [dark] the reflectors must be put on to keep from getting hit. Thus, the cyclist's speed is a careful balance between physical ability, environmental conditions, and safety precautions.

The features in the setting of "Rough Road Ahead, Do not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" affect the cyclist because they determine how easy or hard his ride is. The cyclist ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî was definatly affected by the setting. The cyclist was riding in some rough, dry, and abandoned terrain that made his journey almost fatal. He described it as, ìIn the high deserts of California in June.î It was dry, lifeless, and hot. The sun was beating on him, and he needed to frequently drink water, but he was running out, the canteen feeling lighter with each passing mile. The empty towns were what he was hoping for, a beacon for fresh water, but theyíd been very abandoned, stripped bare by time and circumstance. This made his journey very dangerous. He couldíve fallen off at any time because of heat stroke, the sun a constant threat. He wouldíve died right then and there, another casualty of the harsh landscape. He had to endure these extreme, ironical conditions for miles on end, just to find some water, the most basic necessity. When you're doing any sport or anything where you sweat, your setting is everything. The features of the setting affect the cyclist greatly. The features are old, abandoned towns and hot temperatures, also abandoned buildings. This makes the cyclist think all hope is lost. I hung my head, that smoky blues tune "Summertime" rattling around. Then to a happy mood, as I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them. The oppressive heat and desolation initially crush his spirits, but the unexpected discovery of water, even in a derelict factory, sparks a renewed sense of hope and camaraderie.

The desert is the crulest of natureís environments. Its lack of water, dry air, and punishing heat are enough to kill even the hardiest creature. In ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, cycler Joe Kurmaskie must overcome the desertís heat and lack of water to survive. As the author observes in paragraph @NUM1, ìwide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, I could drop from heatstroke.î If the human body overheats, it becomes sick and unable to properly function, rendering one vulnerable. Thus, Kurmaskie's experience underscores the brutal reality that survival in the desert hinges on respecting its power and ensuring a sufficient water supply.

The sun beat down with merciless intensity. Each step was a labored effort across the seemingly endless expanse of sand and rock. The air shimmered with heat, distorting the already bleak landscape into something almost otherworldly. My throat felt like sandpaper, a constant reminder of the dwindling water in my canteen. Dehydration was a constant threat in this forsaken place, and phones, a lifeline to the outside world, were practically non-existent. Yet, I pressed on, driven by a desperate hope. It was somewhere out here in this desolate place that, as they say, 'the negg down was only @NUM1 down the road.' The heat played tricks on the eyes, making me question every shape on the horizon. Was that a rock formation, or just another mirage conjured by the oppressive heat and my parched mind? It's easy to start questioning reality when the very ground beneath your feet seems to be conspiring against you. It made me doubt myself and what I was doing out here. The shimmering heat made me think that maybe I was just seeing things. But, the more I trekked on, the more it appeared that I was not dreaming. Finally, the more I walked on, the mirage turned into a form. The form turned into the negg down that I was looking for. It was a testament to the power of hope, and the resilience of the human spirit, that I finally saw what I was looking for.

In the setting the conditions were brutal. The author experienced searing heat, dehydration, and getting wrong directions that led him miles off course. In the narrative "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie, the cyclist was affected in a deadly negative way by the setting. The cyclist is travelling through “the high deserts of California in June.” It was hot, so hot in fact, that the author realized he could “drop from heatstroke” at any time. This unbearable heat, coupled with the “crippling” hilly terrain was enough to reduce the cyclist to a state of severe dehydration, obviously not exacting a positive effect. The sweltering heat and merciless hills of the setting would not be quite so awful if there had been locations to stop, rest and replenish the cyclist's dwindling water supply. However, “There was no one in sight, not a building, or a structure of any kind.” The cyclist was in complete isolation for over 80 miles of arid desert, the sweating sun beating down upon him as he toiled up steep unyielding hills; clearly the setting was affecting the cyclist in a horribly negative way, pushing him to the very brink of physical collapse.

When riding a bike for a very long time with no water is bad, but it is even worse when your surroundings offer no aid. In the short story Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Limit, by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist. When at the old codgers' house, he is confident in himself, because they have told him of a shortcut to Yosemite, giving him the confidence he needs. As he leaves, he is still confident. These feelings change as the settings change, affecting the mood of the cyclist. After "about 12 miles into the pedal," the cyclist arrives at the first town, he experiences despair because it is a ghost town. Still having confidence, despite the lack of water, he continues on. Now he is desperate, with no water, dehydrated, and no towns around. He begins to pedal and pedal, hoping to find a town. When he does find a town with water, the setting is relieving and better for him because he finds water. In the end, the setting affects how the cyclist fluctuates between confident, then desperate as water becomes scarce, then relieved when water is finally found, demonstrating the power of environment on human emotion.

The setting of this essay is to tell cyclists where to go without getting them lost and to never take advice from old people. When charting a course, ignore the suggestions offered by anyone past retirement age. Their sense of direction, like their knees, has likely given way to the passage of time. Stick to well-marked routes; a clearly designated bike path is always preferable. Consult a modern map application on your phone, keeping it securely mounted to your handlebars, or invest in a reliable GPS device designed for cycling. Prioritize routes with signage and landmarks. While the local elderly gentleman might insist on a shortcut through "Farmer McGregor's old pasture," resist the urge to deviate from the planned, verified path. Ultimately, trusting technology and official routes over anecdotal wisdom is the surest way to arrive safely at your destination.

The features in the setting greatly affect the cyclist; the setting was hot and rough terrain, and he was tired and thirsty. Also, he says, “Summertime ‘rattled around in the dry honey combs of my deteriorating brain’”. It is summertime where he is riding, and to keep his mind off of his thirst, he hums the song “Summertime.” He wants to show that the heat cannot overtake his body. Also, he says, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake.” He is saying that the terrain is deadly because of the snake that passed by him. He needed to show with all objections, he could overcome anything. As you can see, the setting greatly affected the cyclist, both challenging him physically and mentally as he battled the elements.

Many things can affect a cyclist. But in the story three main features of the setting affected the cyclist the most. While the cyclist was riding it was very hot. We know this by looking back at the text. It gives us this quote, “That I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” Because it was hot, the cyclist was dealing with the risk of overheating. This could make the cyclist thirsty and dehydrated. Another feature of the setting was the multitude of hills. This would create exhaustion and make the ride more physically demanding. We know their were many hills because in the text it says, “Flat road was replaced by short rolling hills.” Going over all those hills can really tire someone out and test their endurance. A third feature of the setting would be nature. Nature can affect us in many ways, by weather, by terrain, as in this case by animals. In the story the cyclist comes upon a large snake, creating a moment of potential danger and surprise. This making it dangerous and possibly causing the cyclist to feel fear or anxiety. The setting can affect anything, shaping the cyclist’s experience and challenges. It would have been a totally different story if the cyclist had been in the summer during December, not June. Thus, the heat, the hills, and the wildlife all played a significant role in shaping the cyclist’s journey.

In the essay ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,î the setting is used to alter the cyclist’s mood and as a reflection of his situation. For example, the statement ìthe cool pines and rushing river of Yosemite had my name written all over themî helps describe the cyclist’s situation. The idea of lush, cool, water vegetation gives the cyclist hope during his increasingly hellish trip. The beauty of that setting also reflects on the comfort that would come from reaching Yosemite; the good setting equals a good outcome. Later on, the cyclist comes across ìone ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mare.î This is a depressing setting symbolizing a complete loss of hope, and indeed at this point the cyclist becomes troubled by his situation. While pedaling through the desert, the cyclist becomes even more dejected when tumble weeds, which are always a symbol of a deserted area, come by. The use of setting to affect and mirror mood is nothing new. There are many examples of this literary technique throughout history. For example, in his story ìThe Heart of Darkness,î Kurtz was in a desolated land filled with wild beast to symbolize and cause Kurtz to change his personality, surrounded by uncivilized people and creating Kurtz tearing of his clothes and hunt like a dog. The setting of a desert in the uncultured part of colonial simultaneously cause and reflects on this change. The setting in the essay ìDo Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî is used as an important tool for character development.

Also, when the author writes “the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke” and when he writes “a ridiculously large snake” show the growing danger that he is getting himself into. This is true because the snakes could get a bite any time or he could just collapse from the lack of water and die; these elements highlight the hostile nature of the environment. Lastly, the name of the store is relevant because it is a fish bait store and he is thirsty. This is relevant because fish live in water and he is thirsty and seeing the sign relieves him completely, signifying a potential source of hydration and rescue. Therefore, the features of this essay explain how the features of the setting affect the cyclist.

In Joe Kurmaskie's essay, "Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit," the setting significantly affects the cyclist, particularly through interactions with long-time residents. The essay suggests that seeking advice from these individuals might not be beneficial, implying a disconnect between their experiences and the cyclist's needs. The author humorously states, "A better piece of advice for the solo cyclist would be, 'Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers who haven't left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.'" This highlights how the local setting, populated by those detached from current travel realities, can hinder rather than help the cyclist's journey. Therefore, the setting, characterized by this specific demographic, shapes the cyclist's experience by offering potentially outdated or irrelevant guidance.

In the story the fact that no one was around, there were no buildings, he had no water, and was lost, had a negative affect on the cyclist, he was doubting himself the whole time. Each rotation of the pedals felt heavier, the sun beat down relentlessly, and the vast emptiness amplified his fear. In the story "Rough Road Ahead," the setting and its features significantly affect the cyclist. For example, the cyclist mentions, "I'd read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you had left to circulate." This suggests harsh conditions contribute to extreme thirst. The setting and features of this story include a hot day in California. Another supportive quote is when the author says, "I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage." This clearly indicates a hot environment due to the excessive sweating, and the mention of a potential mirage further reinforces the idea of a hot, possibly desert-like landscape. The harsh conditions of the setting, therefore, directly impact the cyclist's experience and actions.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways. To begin, as the cyclist rode on for the first miles, he did not see anything in sight, just an endless expanse of road. This made him less determined to reach his goal. Then, in paragraph 1, the cyclist saw a building which helped him to gain strength to reach his goal. The cyclist’s determination went down as long as he was riding, facing the monotony and apparent emptiness. But then at last he came to a building that gave him relief and more confidence in himself, showcasing how environmental landmarks can psychologically impact endurance.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist by him dehydrating and running out of time and energy. The heat contributes to these struggles. "I eased past trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state" This quote proves the dehydration of the rider. "The glowing realization that I could die from a heat stroke" this quote proves the time and energy of the rider is running out due to the oppressive heat. These ideas and quotes show the challenging features of the setting impacting the cyclist's well-being.

In the story Rough Road Ahead the author takes a trail he had previously heard about. After the ride didn’t turn out to be what he expected it to be, the setting began to “set in.” The aridity of the climate would cause the author to have to struggle against himself and the conditions around him, battling the dry air that sapped his strength. Also his lack of water was a problem to begin with but the scorching sun would make him become dangerously dehydrated, turning a manageable inconvenience into a potentially life-threatening situation. It was clear that the journey would test his limits, both physically and mentally.

The cyclist runs into some pretty tough challenges. The realities of the setting affected him, because there were so many obstacles that he had to overcome; for example, he got directions from some old men who, though lively, didn’t really know what they were talking about. Then he ran out of water, so he had nothing to drink, and the road started to get bumpy, and he saw snakes slithering across his path. There were no buildings nor cars around, so he had no way of asking anybody for help if needed. He came upon an old factory that was thought to be the Welch’s Grape Juice factory, but it was abandoned and looked like it had been for a while; towards the end, he found a fishing camp where he finally got water and was around people. These different obstacles affected his mood and how determined he was to finish the journey.

The setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” has a great effect on the main character in the story. In the beginning of the story, he passes the first “town” and continues riding his bike, following the directions some old folks gave him. “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over it.” His mood at this point was already confident, but this adds to it, with words like “rushing” being encouraging to him. Then, he continues moving on the road. “Not two miles into this section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing.” At this point, he is becoming unsure of how good the directions he obtained really were, especially given the increasing difficulty. Once he is already tired, rolling hills isn’t what he wanted to find, so this adds to his doubt. Further along, he said, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind." This adds to the despair he was feeling, because he feels he is going to die in Yosemite, as any hope of assistance seems to vanish. Not seeing anyone was probably extremely discouraging, so the setting really affected him. Then he said “over the long crippling hill, a building came into view.” It is at this point that he uses the word “crippling” because he is just about exhausted and can’t go any further, demonstrating how physically and mentally taxing the environment has become for him. The change in the setting directly influences his emotions, from initial confidence to utter despair and exhaustion.

The features in the setting greatly affect the cyclist. He is riding through this deserted and beaten up town that makes him feel weird, the silence amplifying the decay. After that he starts to ride through the desert when a huge snake gets in his way and scares him even more, its sudden appearance a jolt of primal fear. When he arrives at the abandoned juice factory he is almost completely out of energy and almost can't go on any further in his journey, the oppressive heat and physical exertion taking their toll, until he finally arrives at the bait shop. Most of the features in the setting scare the cyclist but they all affect him, shaping his physical and emotional state throughout his journey.

The cyclist was beginning to feel that death was coming his way as he continued without a building in sight, just endless road stretching before him. This made him grow hysterical over the situation, yet he still had enough energy to feel sorry for himself, a potent cocktail of despair and self-pity fueling his weary legs. Then, when he finally did see a building shimmering in the distance, he thought it was a mirage, a cruel trick of the heat and exhaustion.

The location of a cyclistís ride affects the personís attitude and strength. If the road is full of hills, it takes a little more strength to maintain speed. When put in this situation, Kurmaskie writes ìIt was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself.î This shows how one gets drained by hills. Also, being in a desert situation can weaken a cyclist due to thirst. The cyclist in the reading was desperate enough to try pump water that looked ìbrackish,î illustrating the lengths one will go to when dehydrated. So, setting can break a cyclist, impacting both physical capabilities and mental state.

The setting in the passage is working against the cycler. He's running low on water, his throat parched and dry, he's almost dehydrated, making each pedal stroke a monumental effort. He can't see a town for miles, just endless stretches of shimmering asphalt and desolate landscape, compounding his desperate situation.

In ìRough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî, the author faces many obstacles because of the different terrain changes on his journey to Yosemite National Park. The cyclist then came to a huge hill and, summoning his last bit of energy, rode down, the descent offering momentary relief. He was exhausted, his body aching. In *Rough Road Ahead* by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting significantly affected the cyclist. Because he was in the California desert in June, his water supply was depleted, and he came across a ghost town, a stark reminder of nature's harshness. His hope was dwindling due to this desolation. He found a water pump, but it produced only a tar-like substance; as a result, the punishing desert and the lack of potable water made him wish he was dead. He decided never to take advice from strangers again and to trust his map instead, recognizing its guidance as more reliable than fleeting encounters. That is how the harsh features of the setting directly impacted his physical state, his mental resolve, and his decision-making.

In the essay, ìRough Road A head Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limitî the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First of all, he was traveling in the desert which means it was very dry. The cyclist is alone, traveling on flat land at first, following the direction in which the old men told him to get to Yosemite National Park in @LOCATION1. During his travels, he becomes dehydrated cycling over hills and deserts with the sun beating down on him in the hot June weather; he realizes he could get a heart stroke without water. In the story “Do not exceed posted speed Limit,” the cyclist is trying to get to Yosemite with directions that some codgers, or eccentric old men, gave him. The cyclist said the old men looked as though they “haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” Well, he takes their advice, and he gets lost about @NUM1 along on his journey. While looking forward to the “Cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite,” he was traveling through a barren desert. “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This type of setting could really bring down a cyclist's mood while thinking of Yosemite. It could make him lose all hope of ever finding Yosemite at this rate. If you have a nice setting, it makes the trip worthwhile, and your ending point even better, but the bleakness of the desert only serves to amplify the cyclist’s despair and frustration, making the prospect of reaching the desired destination seem increasingly remote.

The setting effected the performence of the cyclist and the mood of the cyclist. The rolling hills the cyclist had to get over most likely made him more tired and thirsty because he had to put more effort in to get over them. ìover one long, crippiling hill, a building came into view.î The long, big hills that he had to go up made him more thirsty, but probably more satisfied when it was all over. But he continued to move on regardless. In my life, I have never had such an experience to where I had to keep pushing and urging myself to my goal, but the closes I got, the more distractions got in the way to try and stop me, making the journey more challenging.

ìDo not exceed posted speed limitî, is a short story about a man who is bicycling through Yosemite and he asks some elderly men for direction and they lead him in this ìoldî shortcut that takes him through tough terrain and extreme famine. The features of the setting affect the cyclist in many ways throughout the story, for example, when the bicyclist came to a deserted area he said ìthere was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kindî. By this time, he was malnourished and in need of water; this extreme thirst also resulted in him passing an abandoned Welchís grape juice factory with an advertisement with a young boy pouring a fresh glass of juice in his mouth. He says ìIn an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building,î then he goes into detail about the building; this mood and feeling by this time was tired and worn out, and the advertisement didnít help the situation at all. The author's mood did change with the setting, and before it got better it was worse, showing how the harsh environment intensified his physical and emotional struggles.

The young cyclist began his day confident, looking forward to his day of riding across California. Slowly, however, as he recognizes he's been directed wrongly, his mood changes, & he begins to feel more hopeless. As he begins, he feels carefree & ready for anything. He writes, "I checked, checked my water supply & moved on." The sun was beginning to beat down, but he barely noticed it. The surroundings have little effect on him. Later on, he realizes his water was going down, & he is getting tired; his mood changed to exhaustion & defeat. Here he writes, "I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles & stuck them in my mouth; with any luck, I'd hit a bump or lodge one in my throat." He has become sarcastic and saddened by the hopelessness of his journey. Eventually, the relief of the cold water helps to bring up his spirits & sense of humor, reminding him that even in adversity, resilience and a bit of levity can help one to carry on.

In the essay the features of the setting affected the cyclist. In the beginning, the setting was at the old man's place, and the cyclist was happy and confident, enjoying the comfort and hospitality offered. When he reached the ghost town and was out of water, the harsh, desolate environment made him upset and frustrated, as his basic needs were unmet. When he saw the building, a glimmer of hope arose, and he was relieved, thinking his troubles were over. But when he found out it was abandoned, the dilapidated structure dashed his hopes, and he was sad, facing further hardship. When he finally reached the store, a beacon of civilization, he was excited and relieved, his journey nearing a successful conclusion. That is how the setting, with its varying conditions and offerings, directly affected the cyclist's emotional state and overall experience during his trip.

Weather, places, the will to continue – all are reasons that explain how the features of the setting affected the cyclist. First, the weather will affect the cyclist because in hot weather you lose a lot of water and you sweat a lot, making it hard to pedal and easier to become dehydrated. The sunny, hot weather will affect his will to ride, potentially leading to exhaustion and discouragement. I mean come on, who wants to ride when it's burning hot outside? The places the cyclist went through, like towns with stop-and-go traffic and rough, unpaved roads, would also affect him because it’s pretty tough to maintain momentum and comfortable riding conditions on varied and challenging terrain. These environmental factors significantly impact a cyclist's physical and mental state, ultimately influencing their ability to persevere.

The story “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted, speed limit” tells of a biking trip gone wrong, but the story would not be as terrifying if it had happened in a different place, as the setting plays a large role. The story begins on a pleasant summer evening, but as the man bikes, he arrives at a ghost town devoid of all life. Later, feelings of unease set in when he arrives at “one ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps and a corral that couldn’t hold the lamest mule.” Then, panic sets in as the terrain becomes hilly, and tumbleweeds and snakes cross the path, like a cold western. Finally, all hope seems lost when he reaches the grape juice factory and finds “a sand blasted picture of a young boy.” The desolate and increasingly ominous setting is a powerful tool that greatly influences the cyclist's growing fear and sense of isolation, ultimately amplifying the story's terrifying effect.

In the story, “Rough Road Ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of the setting affected the cyclist's physical abilities. The features affected his abilities because the climate and dangerous environment were hot and rough to handle. These features were hot and rough since he was in the California deserts in June. The passage that supports this is, “Tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake- it really did look like a diamondback- blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state.” Also, the features of the setting give him determination. They give him determination because each horizon he sees gives him hope. They give him hope since he knows he is that much closer to Yosemite National Park. The passage that supports this is when he notes the “distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could move it that far, I’d be fine.” In the story, "Rough Road Ahead, Do not exceed posted speed limit," by Joe Kurmaskie, the features of his setting affect both the cyclist's physical and mental abilities, showing how environment can impact both the body and mind during a challenging journey.

The features of the setting have a huge effect on the cyclist. There was a point in the story where he ran out of water and he remembered that the old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. He was tired and dehydrated but he thought he could make it along the road. So he started off and then two miles later the terrain changed and so did his outlook on this entire journey. Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills. "Sometimes life can be so cruel." These hills took a lot out of him and he was now on a highway. Before this terrain change the rider is very positive and thinks he can do this easily. "I could make that!" But after the terrain change he loses hope and almost doesn't make it. "It didn't really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean." It is obvious as you read that when the terrain becomes tough it has a huge negative effect on the cyclist, showing how the environment dramatically shaped his mental state and his physical endurance.

The setting greatly affects the cyclist trying to get to Yosemite National Park. First of all, the cyclist says he’s in Lodi, California on a “gorgeous day in June.” It’s very hot in California in June, so the biker is affected by the weather because he could die of heatstroke, especially given the exertion of cycling. Also, he is in the middle of the desert, where he faces tumbleweeds crossing his path and a large snake that are possibly poisonous in the way. That puts him in more despair, because he could get hurt by a wild animal or run out of water with no place to go get more. The features of the setting affected the cyclist; the author says he is in the California desert. This means that the cyclist must conserve water so he can stay hydrated for the trip, as the desert heat will quickly lead to dehydration. Also, there are many hills, as the author says, ìover one crippling hillsÖî with a lot of hills to climb, the cyclist uses up more energy and will become dehydrated quickly, if he isnít careful, expending vital fluids with each uphill push. Finally, there are many abandoned towns that are several miles apart from each other. This again affects how the cyclists uses his water; he thinks that there is a prospering town coming up, so he drinks his water, thinking heíll get more soon. However, when he gets there, there is no water, and he must pedal several more miles to the next town with very little water, increasing his risk. The setting has a great effect on how the cyclist acts, especially with no water, shaping his decisions and highlighting the harsh reality of the environment.

The features of the setting in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” greatly affect the cyclist. Depending on what sort of new terrain or landmark he came to, his determination increases and decreases. For example, when he saw a building come into view ahead of him, he got excited and used all his energy to get down the hill to the building. Also, when he came to the next building and found a working bathroom, he drank from the sink as his hope (of not dying) was renewed. The setting, therefore, was not just a backdrop but a force that directly influenced his will to survive. The man riding the bike in the story had many different changes in his emotions during his long trek in this story that were dependent on the setting.
